PARA.EMPHASIS: PLEASE HELP US TO CHANGE THE FAMILY LAW ACT

SPEECH.PARA: In February 1992 The Honourable Member for Lyons, (Tasmania) Mr Max Burr published a paper offering strong criticism of The Family Law Act, together with his proposals for change. SPEECH.PARA: 13 December 1993
Senator the Hon Bob Collins
Minister for Transport and Communications
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Civil Aviation Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1993 No.319, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 9 December 1993.

New rr.99AA(5) and (5A) provide that the Civil Aviation Authority may give directions or instructions about the use of airspace; r.99AA(7) provides that contravention of subregulation (5) or (5A) is an offence with a penalty of 50 penalty points. There are similar provisions for instructions in new rr.174A(1), 174D(1), 177(1), 179A(1) and 239 (complemented by r.240) which also lead to offence provisions.

The Committee asks whether these directions and instructions are subject to gazettal, tabling and disallowance. If they are not, the Committee would be concerned. The Committee believes that it is inappropriate for a statutory authority to make legislation including offence provisions with substantial penalties, which is not subject to parliamentary scrutiny.

The Regulations also refer to publication of mandatory offence provisions in AIP and NOTAMS, which the Explanatory Statement advises are Aeronautical Information Publications and Notices to Airmen. The Committee would appreciate your advice on whether these publications are subject to tabling and disallowance.

The Committee wrote to you on 21 October 1993 about aspects of the important reforms which you are implementing in civil aviation legislation. The above concerns appear to come within the matters raised by the Committee at that time and your reply to these present concerns could be expressed in that context.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
1 March 1994
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

I refer to your letter of 13 December 1993 to the former Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator the Hon Bob Collins, concerning recent amendments of the Civil Aviation Regulations contained in Statutory Rules 1993 No 319. I regret the delay in replying.

In your letter you ask whether directions and instructions which are issued under new regulations 99AA(5) and (5A) and regulations 174A(1), 174D(1), 177(1), 179A(1) and 239 are subject to gazettal, tabling and disallowance.

I have been advised by the Civil Aviation Authority that, as drafted, the new regulations require the Authority's directions and instructions to be published in Aeronautical Information Publications (AIP) or Notices to Airmen (NOTAMS). However, the directions and instructions do not need to be gazetted or tabled in Parliament, and are not subject to Parliamentary scrutiny. Neither are the AIP nor NOTAMS subject to tabling and disallowance.

I agree with the Committee's views that, as a breach of a direction or instruction may result in the commission of a criminal offence and attract a substantial penalty, the instructions and directions should be subject to Parliamentary scrutiny.
Accordingly, the Authority will be taking appropriate action to amend the relevant regulations as soon as possible, to ensure that the directions and instructions are disallowable instruments.
Yours sincerely
Laurie Brereton

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges: Whether there was an unauthorised disclosure of a submission to the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, whether a contempt was committed by the disclosure, and whether there is any remedy for that disclosure.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to speak briefly to the motion as deputy chair of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put to the Senate a few of the facts of this matter. In the previous parliament the committee took on a reference of its own interest into casinos in Australia and related matters; I will not bother detailing the points of that reference. The committee sought submissions and decided, following an inspection of those submissions, that the reference at that time should not be proceeded with. Parliament was prorogued and during that time one of the submissions that had been made to the committee, and had not been released, appeared in the South Australian parliament. It is important to note that this is a submission to a general reference to the committee and in that sense is like any submission given to any committee that has not yet been released.

PARA.TAB: At that time and subsequently, committee members were approached by the secretariat of the committee and asked whether the matter should be pursued. As I understand it, not one member thought at the time that it needed to be; that it was a regrettable thing; that it should not have happened—and it clearly should not have; but that it had not caused any great interruption to the committee's proceedings. This was an inquiry that never really got off the ground and certainly was not an NCA related matter in that sense.

However, following the release of this document in the state parliament, the South Australian government had an inquiry into matters contained in the submission and, as a consequence of that inquiry, the person who made the submission felt that he was embarrassed because the outcome of the inquiry was in some respects critical of what he had said in his submission. As a consequence of that, he complained and said that the leak of the submission had caused him embarrassment.

That having happened, it seems appropriate to have the matter investigated. While it may not have caused the committee any difficulty or substantially impaired its work, clearly the leak has caused embarrassment to a citizen who was prepared to put some views forward to a committee and he was entitled to rely on that submission being dealt with by that committee other than by being leaked to anybody.

While members individually thought at the time—and this was March last year—that it was not something that needed to be proceeded with, because it should not have happened and had not caused any great damage, it is relevant to point out that during that time there was some consternation as to whether the new committee was properly formed. This flowed from the fact that it was entitled to have 10 members and only nine had been appointed. One might argue that the committee did not exist at that time and could not do anything about it because it was not properly formed.

That leaves open, of course, the possibility that any member at that time could have used the appropriate standing orders. No doubt honourable senators and honourable members will be interested in the outcome of this inquiry, if for no other reason than that it should be quite instructive as to the relationship between the privileges of this parliament and the privileges of a state parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects, giving effect to a number of previous announcements, including some measures announced in the 1993-94 Budget. It will also make a number of amendments which have not previously been announced.

SPEECH.PARA: Fringe benefits tax measures
Employees employed in foreign locations

Under the existing fringe benefits tax law, a benefit provided by an employer to employees working in certain foreign locations in respect of travel from their work place to obtain suitable medical treatment may be exempt from fringe benefits tax. These foreign locations were to be prescribed by regulation but because of various practical difficulties this requirement is to be removed.

The effect will be that, subject to certain conditions, the fringe benefits tax exemption will apply in respect of any employee working outside of Australia where there is no suitable medical treatment available at the place where the work is carried out.
For the period prior to the amendment, transitional provisions will ensure that the exemption will continue to apply as originally intended.
The impact on revenue of this measure is negligible.
Car parking benefits

Under the existing fringe benefits tax law, the taxable value of a car parking benefit can be determined by reference to the lowest fee for all-day parking charged by any commercial parking station operator within a one kilometre radius of the car parking facilities provided by an employer.

As a result of the wording of the defined terms "all-day parking" and "commercial parking station", employers can use night fees charged by commercial parking station operators and fees charged at kerbside parking meters to value car parking benefits. The use of these fees result in a lower taxable value for car parking benefits which does not reflect the value of the benefit provided. Also, car parking provided by employers in non-CBD areas may be subject to fringe benefits tax where there are kerbside parking meters within one kilometre of the parking facility.

The bill will amend these definitions so that the taxable value of a car parking benefit determined under this method can only be determined by reference to day-time rates and kerbside parking meters are excluded from being commercial parking stations.
The amendments in this bill will prevent an unintended loss to revenue.
Non-government schools

From 1 April 1994 fringe benefits tax will be levied on the tax inclusive value of a fringe benefit and any fringe benefits tax payable will become deductible for income tax purposes. This method, known as the `grossing up' method, will ensure that broadly the same amount of tax is paid on fringe benefits as on the wages that would be required, after payment of income tax, to purchase those benefits.
A tax rebate of 48 per cent of the fringe benefits tax payable under the grossing up method is available for certain non-profit, non-government organisations known as rebatable employers.
Certain non-profit, non-government schools have inadvertently not been listed as rebatable employers. These are non-government schools established under Commonwealth, State or Territory legislation.
This bill will amend the fringe benefits legislation so that these schools will be listed as rebatable employers.
The impact on revenue resulting from this measure will be negligible.
Income tax measures
Tax-exempt infrastructure borrowings

The bill will give effect to the Budget announcement to allow tax-exempt infrastructure borrowings to be used to finance interest falling due on such borrowings during the construction phase of a new road transport, seaport or electricity generating facility.

The estimated cost to the revenue of allowing interest on infrastructure borrowings to be an eligible spending purpose is $3 million in 1993-94, $10 million in 1994-95 and $30 million in each of the 1995-96 and 1996-97 years.

A second amendment for infrastructure borrowings will extend the scope of such borrowings to infrastructure facilities constructed on any Crown lease of land. At present only facilities constructed on land held under statutory Crown leases are eligible.

Tax-exempt infrastructure borrowings will be able to be used to finance the construction of road transport, seaport or electricity generating facilities on land held under a Crown lease granted under a commercial contract by the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, or a tax-exempt authority of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory. Both parties must intend the lease to continue for at least 25 years after the facility becomes income producing.
This measure will make infrastructure borrowings available where it is appropriate to negotiate Crown leases of the land on which the facility is to be constructed.
This amendment will have no effect on revenue.
Pensions and annuity rebates

The bill proposes to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to extend the rebate that applies to superannuation pensions and roll-over annuities paid from a taxed source. The rebate will apply to pensions and annuities that are purchased by rolling over an eligible termination payment arising from the commutation of a deferred annuity or from the commutation of a pension from an untaxed superannuation fund.

The amendments will overcome some technical deficiencies in the existing law and ensure that the pension and annuity rebate provisions operate as intended. They will apply to superannuation pensions and roll-over annuities which first commenced to be paid on or after 1 July 1988 and are not expected to have any significant impact on the revenue.
Leases of luxury cars
This bill will amend the taxation legislation to ensure that lessors of luxury cars cannot use the "finance method" of returning the lease income to avoid the luxury car depreciation limits.

The use of the finance method effectively excludes from the lessor's assessable income part of the cost of the car. That part is the difference between the cost of the car and the residual value, which is treated as if it were the principal being repaid by the lease instalments.

Where the car costs more than the depreciation limit, the share of the excess proportionate to the share of the car's cost which the finance method excludes from income must be added to the lessor's income. This bill will include that share of the excess in the lessor's assessable income evenly over the period of the lease.
These amendments were announced on 8 July 1993 and will apply from that date. The annual revenue at risk is $60 million.
Exemptions for pensions and allowances
The amendments will exempt from income tax bereavement payments made under the Social Security Act 1991 in relation to certain entitlements to pension, allowance and benefit.

The amendments will also provide for income tax treatment of basic and supplementary payments in regard to mature age allowance and mature age partner allowance similar to that for age pension and wife pension respectively.
The nature of the bereavement payments is such that it is not possible to make a reliable estimate of the cost to revenue of the relevant amendments.
The revenue cost of the mature age allowance and mature age partner allowance amendments is estimated to be $5 million in each income year 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97.
Payment of instalments by companies and certain trustees
In the Autumn Sittings this year amendments were made to the income tax law to reintroduce quarterly payments of company tax, which will commence from the

1994-95 year of income. Under the new arrangements, the timing and amount of instalments due depends on the amount of a company's estimated tax for the payment year. More concessional treatment is available for smaller instalment taxpayers.

In announcing the new arrangements in the Investing in the Nation Statement of 9 February 1993, the Prime Minister stated that special rules would be introduced to prevent companies within large company groups taking advantage of the more generous payment arrangements for smaller companies. Broadly, all companies within a group that has combined estimated tax exceeding $300,000 will be required to pay tax according to the rules for large companies for that year. However, companies with estimated tax of less than $8,000 (i.e. a small company) will not be covered by this requirement. This bill implements these measures.
The grouping provisions will only take effect once the new instalment arrangements are fully implemented, i.e. the 1995-96 year of income.

This bill will also amend the penalty provision of the new company tax instalment arrangements to ensure that the penalty for an underestimation of a company's tax for the payment year will apply as intended where a second estimate is lodged by the company.
This bill will also make some minor technical amendments to the company tax instalment arrangements.
These measures will have no effect on the original estimates provided for the new company tax instalment arrangements.
Penalties for over-franking dividends
The bill will correct a deficiency in the application of the penalty for deliberate overfranking of dividends under the imputation system.

The imputation system provides for a penalty, franking additional tax, where a company deliberately overfranks a dividend and this event gives rise to a deficit in a franking account of the company at the end of its franking year.

The proposed amendments will ensure franking additional tax can be applied, as always intended, where an initial payment of company tax reduces the franking deficit tax otherwise payable in respect of the franking account deficit.
The amendments will apply to companies that deliberately overfrank a dividend after 14 December 1993, the date of introduction of this bill.
The proposed amendments will have an insignificant impact on revenue.
Heritage conservation rebate

The bill also gives effect to the measure announced in the 1993-94 Budget to provide a rebate of twenty cents in the dollar for expenditure on approved heritage conservation works of at least $10,000 on historic buildings and structures listed on Commonwealth, State and Territory statutory heritage registers.

The scheme, which will be administered by the Minister for Communications and the Arts, will consist of a two-stage approval process. The first stage will be an application for a provisional certificate, which will constitute approval to proceed with the proposed work and will specify a limit on the amount of expenditure that will qualify for the rebate. Any expenditure incurred on the work before the provisional certificate is issued will not be rebatable. Except where a taxpayer disposes of the property or dies, the taxpayer will have two years, with a possible extension of three months, in which to complete the work.

The total amount for which provisional certificates may be issued in a financial year will be limited to $9.5 million. Accordingly, selection for admission to the scheme is expected to be highly competitive.

The second stage will be the issue of a final certificate. An application for a final certificate can be made on completion of the work to the approved standard, at a cost of at least $10,000. A final certificate must be applied for before the provisional certificate expires. The issue of the final certificate will result in the taxpayer being entitled to the rebate in the tax assessment for the year of income in which the application for the final certificate was made.
The revenue cost of the rebate scheme will be limited to $2 million for each financial year.
Savings banks

This bill will repeal the current exemption from income tax provided for savings banks conducted exclusively for the benefit of depositors. This exemption is no longer relevant since integration of savings bank activity into trading bank business under the Bank Integration Act 1991. A corresponding exemption from withholding tax for certain non-resident savings banks will also be repealed.
These changes are not expected to have any revenue impact.
Exclusion of low income rebate from provisional tax arrangements
The recently enacted Budget legislation provided for a low income rebate of up to $150 to taxpayers whose taxable income for the 1993-94 and subsequent income years is less than $24,450.
The Budget statement announced that the rebate would be provided on assessment, the intention being that PAYE and provisional taxpayers will benefit from the rebate in a similar manner.
The amendments in this bill supplement the provisions which introduced the rebate by ensuring entitlement to the rebate will not be available through the provisional tax arrangements.
This measure will maintain the original revenue costs for the rebate and avoid a one-off cost increase, in the order of $110 million, to the estimated cost of $530 million for 1994-95.
Superannuation Guarantee amendments
The bill makes several amendments to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 to address a number of technical concerns and to clarify certain aspects of the legislation.

The requirement for quarterly superannuation contributions will be deferred until the 1994-95 year. Consequently, employers could contribute the minimum level of superannuation support prescribed for their employees for the 1993-94 year on or before 28 July 1994.

From 1 July 1993 Superannuation Guarantee contributions will not be payable on lump sum payments for accrued annual leave, accrued long service leave and accrued sick leave made on termination of employment.
Certain statutory authorities will be brought within the scope of the Superannuation Guarantee scheme with effect from 1 July 1993.
The industrial agreement between an employer in the maritime industry and the Maritime Union of Australia will be recognised as a valid industrial award for Superannuation Guarantee purposes.
The bill will also make a number of other amendments to facilitate the smooth operation of the Superannuation Guarantee scheme.
The proposed amendments will have no effect on the revenue.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

Debate resumed from 16 December 1993, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be dealing with two insurance bills this morning. We are now dealing with the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1993, and later we will be dealing with the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). The first bill, which is the subject of the present debate, was introduced into the Senate on 16 December last year. It was initially listed for debate earlier this session, but its consideration was delayed to enable discussion to be held between the Insurance and Superannuation Commission—the new regulator—and industry groups.

PARA.TAB: One of the most rewarding aspects of the parliamentary process is the occurrence of discussions between government, industry and the opposition to air the problems associated with bills in an attempt to come to some common ground. This took place, admittedly, only fairly recently and has resulted in a number of worthwhile amendments to the bill. But, not surprisingly, the amendments do not go as far as the industry would hope for in all directions.

While it is not expected that any budgetary impact will flow from the first bill, we really cannot ignore the provision relating to the strengthening of cover in professional indemnity contracts which will undoubtedly increase the cost of this cover for brokers and foreign insurance agents. The government assures us that it will be offset by the benefits of increased protection in favour of the insuring public. We have heard this argument before, but increased protection and increased regulation always come at a cost to the industry which is ultimately passed on to the consumer so that, in the end, the consumer pays.

This amending bill amends three acts: the Insurance Act 1973, the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 and the Insurance Laws Amendment Act 1991. In fact, the Insurance Act—the first of them—was amended as recently as 1991, and it is back before us again today. These minor amendments include, firstly, amending the valuation of shares in related body corporates to ensure consistency with the methods used in calculating the solvency of an authorised insurer holding such shares and, secondly, allowing the commissioner to issue directions about the disposal and treatment of certain assets or classes of assets where there is doubt as to the solvency of the insurer. The idea behind this measure is to protect consumers when they deal with insurers.

This bill also amends the Insurance Laws Amendment Act 1991 so that the capital and solvency requirements of registered life companies apply only to the life offices registered under the Life Insurance Act 1945 at the date of the original amendment. This is a clarification amendment only.

As I said at the time the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991 was debated, its capital and solvency provisions are a really welcome move. But, as is common practice with this government, it is not until after the event that it realises that the phasing in provisions are necessary and, accordingly, the amendment has something of a retrospective operation. I also mention in relation to the capital solvency provisions that an amendment was necessary to ensure the commencement date for new companies coming to the scheme to operate forthwith rather than on the phasing in basis for existing companies.

However, the bill's major focus is to amend the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act which was enacted in 1984. That act aims to protect consumers against negligence or misconduct by an insurance agent or broker—the intermediary. It makes insurers responsible for the actions of their agents, and provides a system of registration of insurance brokers and those agents acting on behalf of unauthorised foreign insurers. This is to some people somewhat contentious, particularly in the event of fraud. However, the overriding concept of the bill will be to strengthen the sorts of controls that insurance companies exercise over their agents. This is in addition to the powers that are exercised under the regulatory authority of the ISC.

The ISC's 1992-93 annual report indicated that in that year there were 1,034 registered insurance brokers, who placed premiums of $3.9 billion. So the legislation affects quite a lot of money transactions. The amendments to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 are based on the review of the operations of the act by the ISC, and do not include matters from the review of life insurance by the ISC and the Trade Practices Commission. Unfortunately, as is often typical of the government, a comprehensive reform of a piece of legislation cannot be done in one attempt. Again it is a dribs and drabs approach—a bit now and a little bit later.

But this does give an opportunity to correct some technical problems on the next occasion. I would prefer to have such a comprehensive review that technical difficulties, unintended consequences and the like are picked up much earlier because, as we found yesterday with the training guarantee levy, it took over 3 1/2 years to get a necessary amendment which should have been made at the time in relation to the carry-forward of losses in that particular piece of legislation.

While the coalition is in favour of measures to increase consumer protection, especially when dealing with agents and brokers, we do have some serious concerns about several provisions which are shared by the industry, particularly in the original bill. I will go to some of the offending clauses, particularly clauses 9B(3) and 9B(4). They are the run-off and the non-avoidance clauses.

The proposed subsection 9B(4) provides that acceptable contracts of professional indemnity insurance for foreign insurance agents and registered insurance brokers must contain a run-off clause made within three years. As a result of the recent negotiations, the government decided to amend this three-year period. The bill we now have before us makes for a minor amendment, but it in no way addresses the industry's major concern about the provision, apart from saying it will specify the extent of the run-off period in the regulations.

So we are seeing transferred out of the bill a contentious clause relating to a three-year period of run-off. But this contention has been taken from the legislation and placed in the regulations. We have been assured that the run-off period will certainly be less than three years, but I hope that meaningful discussions will take place between the industry and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to get to a satisfactory resolution. Again, this is a provision that should not have been transferred to the regulations but should be in the bill itself.

I do have some concerns about the explanatory memorandum in this regard because it is slightly misleading. Not that it is untrue, but the memorandum does say that the amendments, et cetera, were developed in consultation with the industry. While that is true, the final result was not always the result of consultation. The consultations took place, and then the government took a line of action. When it took that line of action I believe that perhaps there should have been further consultation. That was why the opposition asked the government to defer the legislation—so that these meaningful discussions could take place. But they took place in some haste. We trust that the result will be satisfactory.

The proposed subsection 9B(3) provides that professional indemnity contracts must contain a clause stating that insurers cannot avoid a contract or reduce their liability under the contract by reason of non-disclosure by the agent or broker, even though fraudulent. Insurance fraud is a matter which the insurance industry is addressing by the implementation of full fraud control programs. We welcome that.

In essence, the provision says that a professional indemnity insurer will have no remedy at all for non-disclosure or misrepresentation, whether innocent or fraudulent. So I ask: has the government considered the impact of this clause on the duty of disclosure which is fundamental to any contract of insurance? Commonsense dictates that the earlier professional negligence claims are reported to insurers, the better the management of a `claims made' scheme. The government amendment will only encourage insureds not to disclose actual or potential claims until they have reached the court proceedings arena. If disclosure was made earlier when the potential claim arose, it is true that insureds' premiums would go up, but by a minuscule amount compared with the amount that an insurer, who must carry the burden of many claims owing to a lack of disclosure, will charge insureds in the future to recover this loss.

From the outset it should be noted that the professional indemnity market is very small. Interestingly, the only non-avoidance requirement imposed by legislation in Australia in relation to professional indemnity is for solicitors. If the current jump in law cover premiums in New South Wales is an indication of what happens to premiums in a non-avoidable scheme, my message to consumers is: `Beware; ultimately you will bear these costs'.

Both the Insurance Council of Australia and the National Insurance Brokers Association, NIBA, have concerns about the inclusion of such provisions in professional indemnity insurance contracts. In fact, the National Insurance Brokers Association argues that together these two provisions, in terms of the original arrangements, would have increased the professional indemnity premiums for brokers by a minimum of 65 per cent. Given that the increases in premium rates over the past 12 months have been between 30 and 100 per cent, a further increase could well threaten the viability of many brokers. Hence the importance of getting this three-year run-off down to an acceptable level. I point out that, had this not been achieved, unemployment queues may well have increased as a result. Those brokers who remain in the industry would be forced to reduce the limits of indemnity they presently purchase. I certainly hope that would not happen. I have been assured by the ISC that indemnity cover is related to the scale of transactions undertaken.

The National Insurance Brokers Association also forecast that, if the proposed subsection becomes part of the law, only two insurers have indicated that they will write professional indemnity insurance business for brokers. This states clearly that the changes, whilst increasing the protection for agents, could well be counterproductive because, given the small size of the professional indemnity market, insurers may face problems in offering run-off cover owing to their reinsurance requirements. This would reduce the operation of free and open competition in a market for professional indemnity insurance also.

The National Insurance Brokers Association pointed out in its submission that presently the NIBA facility requires underwriters to provide terms for all risks proposed, and underwriters have indicated that with the broad scope of cover they would require the opportunity to be more selective in their risks, which could result in brokers not being able to purchase that cover. That indeed would be a difficulty. Underwriters have indicated that they will need to review audit certificates to ensure the solvency of brokers proposing to insure and estimate that 20 per cent of the risks will not find insurance. This process means that the underwriters in a sense become the regulators of the industry, and this I assume and hope is not the intention of the government.

The National Insurance Brokers Association again highlighted that the combination of these two provisions, run-off and non-avoidance, means that an unscrupulous agent may well buy effectively one year's cover and a three-year run-off at a premium which does not reflect the risk.

It is necessary for that reason to have a minimum run-off period—perhaps one year—which would reduce the cost in the regulations and minimise the potential I am putting to the Senate today. So, if an agent failed to disclose many impending claims and is in charge of a low risk premium, he could dump the accumulated liabilities on an unsuspecting insurer by ceasing business and recommencing with possibly a new business. I think, though, that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission would have something to say about that.

The clause related to cancellation of indemnity contracts seeks to prevent insurers under professional indemnity contracts cancelling a contract unless they give three days notice to the ISC before the date of intended cancellation of a contract. The Insurance Council of Australia queries whether the failure of an agent to give such a notice renders cancellation of the policy void and, therefore, whether insurers are left at risk until notice not only has been given to the commissioner but also forwarded to the insured in accordance with the Insurance Contracts Act 1984.

The Insurance Council of Australia also queries whether this provision requires notification where there is cancellation by the insured, its agents or a premium funder. It is hoped that the ISC response would be that this does not affect the cancellation provisions of the Insurance Contracts Act, but I seek that confirmation by the minister.

The cancellation of professional indemnity contracts by premium funders is in proposed subsection 9B(7). This states that provisions in professional indemnity contracts permitting a premium funder to cancel a loan agreement are ineffectual if the insured is unable or unwilling to comply with the loan terms. Again, the Insurance Council of Australia argues that much of the security of premium funders will be lost if they are unable to cancel loan agreements and receive a refund.

I now turn now to the commissioner's powers. The ISC certainly has a huge task in overseeing the operation of the insurance legislation, together with the superannuation legislation. It is sincerely hoped that there are sufficient resources, both monetary and human, to undertake this task. The commissioner's new powers with respect to insurance intermediaries in clause 28 aim to overcome the problems experienced investigating alleged breaches of the act, and naturally to increase consumer protection when dealing with intermediaries.

Proposed section 41A aims to give the commissioner powers to make decision-making principles in relation to registrations, suspensions and cancellations of registrations and the provision of information by intermediaries. I again merely wish to note that this is a practical step that will assist the review of the commissioner's decisions.

Clause 27 deals with the situation where the contract has not been accepted. A broker must, within 37 days, give notice to the insured advising that the risk has not been accepted, and return the money. Whilst the 37-day period obviously alleviates administrative inconvenience for brokers, it is important for a consumer to be advised immediately that the cover is not being placed—not a month later.

Clauses 29 and 30 clarify that premiums paid to subagents are taken to have been paid directly to the agent, and that premiums received by an agent must be passed to the insurer within 37 days, unless exempted. The legislation currently requires that the moneys be paid to the insurers as soon as is reasonably practicable. Insurers are bound by their agent's act and the remittance of money is a matter between the agent and the insurer. The amendment does not benefit consumers at all, so why has it been made? Insurers would prefer that no amendment be made or that the time period run from the date of inception of the contract and not as in the act.

Before concluding, I wish to make a few passing comments. The time frame for prosecution of offences under the act has been extended from one to three years owing to the difficulty in tracing offences. It takes some time for breaches to be detected by the commission. I note that initiatives by the insurance industry, such as the establishment of the Insurance Council's inquiries and complaints scheme, undoubtedly play a not insignificant role in monitoring the conduct of the industry, and that is good. I applaud proposed section 33A dealing with the notification in writing by intermediaries to insurers of multiple agency agreements. This clause also has the support of the Insurance Council of Australia. I note that each agent will be responsible for discharging its own obligations under the act and that related agents need not disclose the termination of an agency agreement by a related company. The Insurance Council of Australia believes this is a matter which warrants consideration.

Unfortunately, this is probably not the last time in 1994 that we will consider amendments to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act. The government needs to seriously review its agenda when introducing amendments to legislation. I sincerely hope that on the next occasion we look at this act the government will have consulted adequately with the industry, even after the preliminary negotiations have concluded.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1993 contains a number of amendments, most of which go to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984. It increases the obligations of the insurance brokers to protect the interests of their clients by requiring them to have acceptable professional indemnity contracts. It also clarifies the liability of insurance companies for the actions of their agents, particularly those who act for more than one insurer. Agents will in turn be required to notify insurers of the details of other insurers for whom they operate.

PARA.TAB: The Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner will be given more powers to investigate insurance agents but restrictions will be imposed on the commission's use of any information obtained. The commission will have wider scope to refuse or revoke the registration of brokers and there will be a new provision requiring agents to pass on premium moneys to insurance companies within 37 days. There is also an amendment to the Insurance Act 1973 which has the effect of reducing the value of shares held by an insurance company in related companies for the purpose of calculating the value of assets held by that company. The Democrats have no difficulties with the provisions of this bill. It improves the supervision of the industry and the protection of consumers and we will be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for his contribution and Senator Lees for her somewhat briefer contribution to this particular debate. I found both of them to be interesting and instructive.

PARA.TAB: The main objectives of this bill are to amend the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act as follows: to give the commissioner increased power to cancel or suspend registration of insurance intermediaries—brokers and agents of unauthorised foreign insurers—in certain circumstances; to require insurance agents to pass premium moneys to insurers without unreasonable delay; to clarify insurers' responsibility for the actions of their agents irrespective of whether they are sole agents or multi-agents; to raise the standard of professional indemnity cover required of registered intermediaries in order to increase the level of protection available to the insured; and to strengthen the powers of the commissioner to investigate the affairs of intermediaries and extend the time within which prosecutions may be commenced.

These objectives are consistent with the main objectives of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act, which are to protect the insuring public against the error or misconduct of insurance agents and brokers. These objectives also encourage practices consistent with the interests of the insuring public, including improved standards of conduct and quality of advice.

The Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1993 will also make minor amendments to the Insurance Act 1973. These involve the removal of anomalies in the valuation of shares in related insurance companies and investments in related unit trusts; the provision of more flexibility in the issue of directions by the commissioner where there is doubt about the solvency of an insurer; and minor amendments to provisions dealing with the principal banker of an insurer.

Before the conclusion of this second reading debate I will try to address, very briefly, some of Senator Watson's major concerns which, boiled down, relate to the professional indemnity provisions for brokers. These provisions do have a very strong consumer protection objective. The government does accept the point, which was laboured a little by Senator Watson, that they come at some cost to brokers through increased premiums. However, the government has responded to industry concerns by moving the run-off provision to regulations to enable further consultation and a phased introduction. The three-day notice of cancellation requirement is consistent with the Insurance Contracts Act.

I commend this bill to the Senate, as well as the amendment the government will move. I thank honourable senators for their contribution and ask for the support of the Senate for this important piece of legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 12, page 5, proposed subsection 9B(4), line 28, omit "3 years after entry into that last-mentioned contract of insurance", substitute "the period after entry into that last-mentioned contract of insurance that is, at the time of entry into that contract, prescribed by regulations made for the purposes of this subsection".

SPEECH.PARA: The main function of the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1993 is to give effect to the findings of an extensive review of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984. One of the major initiatives of the bill is to improve the level of protection available to persons dealing with registered insurance intermediaries. This extra protection was to be achieved, inter alia, by requiring intermediaries to have professional indemnity insurance policies which gave cover for a period of up to three years after they retired, sold their business or otherwise ceased trading.

PARA.TAB: Since the tabling of the bills at the end of the last session, it has become apparent that unpredictable market fluctuations in this class of insurance make it desirable to avoid specifying in the act a level of cover which may not always be available to intermediaries on reasonable terms and conditions. The present amendments will remove the reference in the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1993 to a particular level of cover and replace it with a regulation-making power so that the legislation can be administered on a more practical and flexible footing.

This proposed amendment will enhance the proposed supervisory arrangements. It is not expected that the amendment will have any budgetary impact. The amendment will allow the government to avoid unnecessary cost to registered insurance intermediaries and allow a better balance to be struck between their interests and the interests of the insuring public. I commend this amendment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal-National Party coalition agrees with the amendment as far as it goes. I wish to ask a number of questions, starting with clause 12, particularly on the professional indemnity contracts. I thank the minister for his response, which actually poses further questions.

PARA.TAB: The original clause, honourable senators might recall, imposed a requirement for a three-year run-off period, but the amendment that has just been moved by Minister Faulkner removes the three-year time frame and transfers the run-off period from the bill to future regulations. I ask the minister whether I was correct in my interpretation of his explanation that, while this is going to be transferred to the regulations, the government is still looking at a three-year time period, albeit a phased-in time period. I put it to the minister that the three-year time period, whether it be in regulations or in the legislation, even though it might be phased in, is still too long a period, and that raises the question of the non-availability of such a cover and the horrendous cost of such a cover.

My question is: ultimately, will the run-off clause still be three years? I know it is subject to some negotiation, but I want to make sure that there is still not this mind-set of a three-year period. Has the government really considered the extra premium cost to brokers in the run-off requirement? During my speech in the second reading debate, I indicated the sorts of increased costs that were going to apply as a result of the three-year period. Whether it is phased in or not, ultimately there is going to be this cost. So all we are really doing is deferring the problem to a future time.

Effectively, this could well mean regulation not through the ISC but through the availability of cover and the cost of cover. This will have an impact on intermediaries such as insurance brokers and others dealing with foreign companies. Does the government also concede that, despite the fact that this increase in consumer protection will assist consumers, it will ultimately be a huge cost that will be passed on to consumers? Would the minister like to respond to that first? I have a number of other questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was afraid Senator Watson would say that. I would like to respond to the first series of questions, although I was feeling very comfortable when he commenced his remarks by saying he was going to ask only one question.
—It has a lot of subparts.

—Yes. I will do my best for Senator Watson in answering it. In response to those subparts, as described by Senator Campbell, I am advised that there will be further consultation with the industry. A one-year run-off is likely. I am also advised that there will be a phased introduction of the changes. I can assure Senator Watson that there is no three-year mind-set—to use his words. I think it is also proper to say that we are aware of cost implications. I stress, as I mentioned in my contribution in moving this amendment, that there is a clear consumer objective in relation to this. We are consulting with brokers and insurers about the cost and availability of cover.
—The minister indicated that there would be a phase-in. Will that phase-in apply even though the run-off may be only one year?
—I am advised that the answer to Senator Watson's question is yes.

—I turn now to the non-avoidance provisions of the clause. The amendment provides that non-disclosure or misrepresentation, fraudulent or not, is not a ground for avoiding or reducing the liability under a professional indemnity contract. Has the government considered the impact of this amendment on the duty of disclosure which is fundamental to any insurance contract? Do the minister and his government realise that non-avoidance clauses may well encourage brokers not to disclose the actual and potential claims until they are what I call fully blown?

PARA.TAB: I further ask in relation to the same issue: has the government considered the problems associated with an insurer cancelling a contract under section 60 of the Insurance Contracts Act for a breach of duty of disclosure? It may cause problems for brokers in obtaining replacement cover in the very small indemnity market. I put those three questions to the minister relating to the non-avoidance provisions of the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer Senator Watson's questions as best I can.
—Would you prefer to take them on notice?

—I think the advisers can assist me and we can answer them now. Senator Watson gave me a commitment that he was going to ask me one question. Once he trebled that, it made it very difficult for me, struggling as I am in representing Senator Cook in what is a very important piece of legislation but one I would have to plead guilty to not being particularly familiar with. So it is a learning experience for me in relation to this piece of legislation. Perhaps Senator Watson could restate his first question and we will attempt to answer that and then move to the other two.
—Does the minister require me to restate question one of the three questions I asked in relation to non-avoidance?
—That would be easier.

—The amendment provides that non-disclosure or misrepresentation, fraudulent or not, is not a ground for avoiding or reducing liability under a professional indemnity contract. That is the issue. My question is: have the minister and his government considered the impact of this amendment on the duty of disclosure which is fundamental to any insurance contract? There is an anomaly there. I understand what the minister is getting at in relation to putting the responsibility back on the insurance company, but there is this problem of the duty of disclosure. I believe that in a legal sense there is that conflict.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the impact on the duty of disclosure has certainly been considered. The amendments allow cancellation prospectively but not retrospectively. The consumer protection objective in this amendment makes specific reference to the duty of disclosure.

—I still put it to the minister that there is a conflict. I ask that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission look at this in the light of the conflict in law that technically the provision could create. I look forward to the minister's response to my second and third questions.
—The Insurance and Superannuation Commission has examined this and certainly is of the view that there is no conflict in law. I ask Senator Watson to put his second question again.

—Does the government realise that the non-avoidance clause may well encourage brokers not to disclose actual and potential claims until they are fully blown? That could flow from the amendment that has been put in terms of the non-avoidance provisions. If that were the case, it would be unfortunate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Watson's question is that brokers are professional people who are expected to be able to know how to handle these sorts of matters in a professional, proper and appropriate way.

—I put it to the minister that this could well be a consequence of this decision and this amendment, despite the professional hype. Since there is no point in pursuing that issue, I now ask whether the minister has considered the problems associated with an insurer cancelling a contract under clause 60 of the Insurance Contracts Act for a breach of duty of disclosure? That may cause problems for brokers in obtaining replacement cover in this very small professional indemnity market, which I referred to in my speech during the second reading debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am assured that the answer to Senator Watson's question is yes, this issue has been considered.
—So the minister has acknowledged the problem in the very small market? It will be a very real problem for a number of the smaller brokers.
—I said that the issue had been considered. I would not want Senator Watson to misinterpret what I said.
—I do not think honourable senators on either side realise the significance of the words, `Yes, it has been considered'.
—I am using the words according to their straightforward dictionary definition.

—Yes, but there will be a practical problem under these circumstances in obtaining replacement cover in the event of cancellation. I put it to the minister that there will be that problem. His response was that it has been considered. I accept that.

PARA.TAB: I now move to clause 22. These are the notification provisions in relation to the cancellation of policy and the return of moneys. A broker must, if a risk has not been accepted within a 37-day period, notify the consumer of this and return the money. Why is the period 37 days? That alleviates administrative inconvenience for brokers, but I put it to the minister that consumers need to be notified immediately that there is no cover—not a month later and certainly not 37 days later. Is it not correct that there is a need for immediate notification of cancellation, not after a 37-day period? What are the consequences?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The consequences are that the insured will now get their money back, which was not necessarily the case previously, as I understand it.
—And they will be covered?
—I am advised that the amendment is consistent with the existing legislation.
—Not quite.
—I am advised that that is the case.
—The 37-day rule is a fundamental change.
—I am communicating to the honourable senator the advice that I have received. In this situation, that is really the best I can do.

—I move now to clause 27, insurance intermediaries notifying insurers of multiple agencies. Multi-agents must notify insurers of all agency agreements in place and of proposed additions to or cancellations of such agreements. In addition, multi-agents must not enter into or cancel such agreements until the agent's other principals have been notified of this intention in writing. Should not multi-agents be required to disclose the existence, variation and termination of agency agreements by related companies? If that were the case, it would certainly be in the interests of consumers. As this legislation is all about consumer protection, why not implement the recommendation I have just suggested?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that what Senator Watson is suggesting is unnecessary because the focus of the act is on particular intermediaries, not on related companies.
—The focus of the act may be in that area. I put this issue to the minister for further consideration, not today but maybe at a later date.
—That issue has been raised by the industry and certainly has been given serious consideration.

—I now refer to clause 29(b), which amends section 37 of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 to provide that agents must remit to insurers premium moneys within 37 days after the date in which the money is received. Currently, the legislation provides in section 37(3) that moneys will be remitted to insurers as soon as is reasonably practicable. Insurers would prefer that the time period run from the date of the inception of the contract or, alternatively, that the provision not be amended at all. Insurers are bound by their agents' acts and the matter of remittance of money is a matter between the agent and the insurer. The amendment does not benefit the consumers. Therefore, why was the amendment thought necessary?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is ground that Senator Watson has well tilled before, and I have attempted to cover it as best I can. The arguments that have been presented, as far as I am concerned, stand. The amendment substitutes `37 days' for the words `as soon as is reasonably practicable'. Inception date accounting is impracticable in those circumstance.

—I move to clause 41, the phasing in of capital and solvency requirements. The amendment makes it clear that the capital and solvency requirements of the registered life offices apply only to life offices registered under the Life Insurance Act at the date of the original amendment. What stimulated the government to make this amendment? Why has it taken the government since 1991 to deal with the Insurance Laws Amendment Act 1991 to realise that the phasing in requirements are necessary? I think the provision in relation to new companies needs to be clarified because it is an important requirement in terms of the new entrants.

—It is a clarification of an ambiguity in the original act. This is the first opportunity that the government has had to deal with it. We are taking the opportunity to do so now—albeit slowly this morning—but we are addressing it.

—I put to the minister that there are omnibus miscellaneous provisions amendment bills coming through this parliament from time to time. Surely these mechanisms are the appropriate way in which such matters can be expeditiously dealt with, rather than waiting for a major change to a piece of legislation which might be light years away. I put to the minister the need for greater urgency in attending to matters that have been recognised as inadequacies and to refer the issues to omnibus or miscellaneous provisions or technical correction bills that frequently pass through the Senate. Why wait for a major change in a piece of legislation before introducing such known legislative amendments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —To use the word `major' is not really being fair to the dictionary definition. This is the first opportunity the government has had to address this. This is the first opportunity with insurance or insurance-related legislation before this chamber. Senator Watson, as I think everyone accepts, is a person who takes an extraordinarily keen and close interest in these sorts of matters. It is quite appropriate timing for the government and utterly proper and defensible for the government to be bringing forward this legislation in this way. I think in Senator Watson's more reasoned moments—which are very frequent, as all honourable senators know—he would accept that the government has moved at an appropriate pace in proposing this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Faulkner) read a third time.
