That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now has before it the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993. This bill aims to increase substantially the level of protection to the public purchasing insurance products generally and, in particular, those purchasing consumer credit insurance. Consumer credit insurance is taken out by borrowers of consumer credit, such as personal loans—credit cards, for example—against a fault in case of loss of income due to death, illness, injury, or unemployment. Therefore, it plays a large role in transactions which may affect most of us at one time or another. It is essentially sold as an add-on to a finance contract and is really offered as a separate item.

PARA.TAB: I digress for a few moments into the history of review of consumer credit to illustrate just how slowly this government moves. Way back in July 1990 our former colleague from Tasmania, Senator Michael Tate, the then Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, announced an inquiry by the Trade Practices Commission into the market for consumer credit insurance. The Trade Practices Commission examined the structure, conduct and performance of the CCI market and produced a report in June 1991. A government working paper was then convened to develop responses to the Trade Practices Commission's recommendation and its report was issued in December 1992.

The last step in this protracted process was that in July last year the government announced that it would reform the consumer credit insurance system. This bill was introduced in December and its consideration in this session has been delayed to enable further discussion. I thank the Insurance and Superannuation Commission for its briefing on this bill. But the concerns of the industry and the coalition with this bill in its original form were not merely technical ones but issues that went to the very heart of the legislation.

Further amendments to the Insurance Contracts Act 1984 should be forthcoming later this year or maybe in 1995, following the Insurance and Superannuation Commission's administration of the act and a broader review of its provisions, which is presently being conducted by the regulatory authority, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

Thankfully, the insurance industry has, on its own initiative, met the challenges to increase consumer protection and has not waited for the government to act. The Insurance Council of Australia has established an inquiries and complaints scheme. I remind the Senate that last year this scheme dealt with 23,000 complaints and the cost of the operation has grown significantly, which is indicative of its use by the insured and the fact that they are certainly aware of its existence.

Unlike the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1993, this bill has an expected budgetary impact because under these provisions the ISC will now administer the Insurance Contracts Act 1984. It is estimated that the resources needed will be $130,000 in the current year and $336,000 in each following year. In addition, further resources will be obtained by amendments to the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Act 1989 and the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Act 1989 which increase the statutory upper limit on the general insurance supervisory levy from $15,000 to $17,000 and on the life insurance levy from $28,000 to $70,000.The explanatory memorandum explains that this increase is to recover the cost of administering the Insurance Contracts Act and to cover the increased costs of supervision that will arise from amendments to the Life Insurance Act which are expected to be introduced later this year.

This magnificent jump for life insurance companies is quite astounding—approximately 400 per cent. One certainly hopes that if the ISC realises its cost for supervision of the Insurance Contracts Act is higher than anticipated, we will not be confronted with amendments to increase the levy again in the near future. I seek the response of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) to that point.

This increase in the levy will have a serious impact, particularly on the competitiveness of the smaller players in this huge insurance field. This is by no means a good thing for the small companies because often it is the small companies that have the innovative, new products. It is the small companies, I believe, that can often react more quickly to market needs than the larger corporations. Huge levies of this nature, I believe, work very much to the detriment of the smaller companies and to new entrants to the industry.

The bill primarily amends the Insurance Contracts Act 1984. Many of the amendments are small, technical ones, but a number have serious implications for both insurance companies and consumers. I refer first to the new role and powers of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Previously, the act has been self-administered, which meant the government was unable to intervene easily to ensure the effective operation of the act. The downside of this change is that it can give rise to an increased bureaucracy.

This bill seeks to make dramatic changes in this regard. I recognise that the current commissioner, Mr Pooley, is skilled in this area and I pay tribute to his professionalism and the way in which he has handled this portfolio. I also pay tribute to his officers who have responsibility for administration of the act. The Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner is given extensive powers to require insurers to produce documents and information under proposed sections 11C and 11D.

The commissioner is also given power for the purpose of undertaking the general administration of the act. The legislation states that the commissioner has power to do all things that are necessary or convenient to be done in connection with the administration of the act, including reviewing documents issued by insurers given in compliance with proposed section 11C, and reviewing particulars, such as statistics and documents, given in compliance with proposed section 11D.

The latest government amendments to proposed section 11C(1) and 11D(1) qualify the commissioner's powers to require the production of documents relating to insurance cover, particularly relating to the organisational structure and the administrative arrangements of an insurer, and the statistics relating to the nature and volume of the insurer's insurance business. It is stated he can do so `for any purpose connected with the general administration of the act'. This is a significant improvement on what I believe were the previously unlimited powers given to the commissioner.

The Insurance Council of Australia recommends that the commissioner also formulate decision-making principles to enable the industry to understand the scope of the ISC's information gathering power. The ICA has concerns about the scope and meaning of certain terminology, particularly in terms of what is the scope and width of such terms as `review'. It argues they may well be extended to imply the ability to probe and also to change things. In particular, the industry body is concerned that the commissioner has power to review organisational structures and even administrative arrangements. The industry body argues this is of no relevance to the administration of the Insurance Contracts Act, desirable though it might be.

The body is also concerned that these provisions may require the production of documents and information that are confidential, commercially sensitive or have legal professional privilege attaching to them. Obviously, the insurance industry is a highly competitive one with many players, big and small, and the divulging of commercially sensitive information to the ISC, with the knowledge that it can in some circumstances pass this on to others, would be of concern to a player, particularly with regard to freedom of information type requests.

I query whether such categories of information fall within the `reasonable excuse' category. There is certainly some argument that it should. Alternatively, there should be a class of documents that should be protected under secrecy provisions. If documents are allowed to be distributed by the ISC, that is likely to lead to loss of legal professional privilege. The consequence of distributing commercially sensitive information could be financially disastrous for certain insurance companies.

I also point out that, unlike section 346 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, the secrecy provisions here are not protected under section 38 of the Freedom of Information Act 1982, which would actually permit the ISC to refuse freedom of information requests in respect of documents collected under these provisions. I put it to the parliamentary secretary—I hope he is listening—that such protection should be provided.

In addition, the effect of proposed sections 11C(4) and 11D(5) is that an insurer can refuse to provide information if it would tend to incriminate the insurer. Proposed subsection 11C(3) also exempts the provision of information dealing with insurance cover provided to a particular person unless the person or anyone entitled to a claim under that cover gives a written authorisation to the commissioner. An insurer will not be required to give the commissioner any documents from which the identity of an insured or third party claimant could be deduced.

Whilst secrecy duties are imposed on the commissioner and his staff by proposed section 11F, the ISC is permitted to distribute the documents in the performance of its duties in connection with the act by distributing the documents to other parts of government or to other persons where, in the minister's opinion, it is in the public interest to do so. I am also concerned about the potential ramifications of such provisions. However, I am pleased that the government's amendment to proposed section 11D(2) only imposes a penalty on an insurer for potentially or recklessly giving particulars or statistics that are false or misleading regarding the organisational structure and volume of business. The original provisions, I believe, were extremely onerous in terms of cost. I look forward to the parliamentary secretary moving the amendments during the committee stage.

Clearly, information obtained by the ISC could be used in court proceedings, but the industry body—that is, the ICA—asks that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission alert insurers specifically to this fact. Again, I seek confirmation of this point. Documents which are commercially sensitive, confidential or subject to legal professional privilege should not be available for use by the ISC in representative action under the act, which the act does provide for. We have no objection to the concept of representative action under these circumstances by the ISC.

The requirement on the ISC to produce an annual report is objected to by the ICA on the basis that such reports could name particular companies. I believe this requirement is essential to the review of the effectiveness of the ISC as an overseer of the act. But again this is a case where parliamentarians on both sides often differ from the industry.

I applaud clause 9, which inserts proposed section 64A. It is essential to consumer protection that purchases on consumer credit be given a cooling off period to ensure that consumers have shopped around and investigated what they are doing. This is central, given that the Trade Practices Commission report found that about 80 per cent of CCI policies are sold at the premises of a credit provider and that the remaining policies are sold by car dealers in conjunction with purchase of a car.

In light of all the discussion in the insurance industry concerning disclosure—in particular, that of commissions—proposed section 71A is not as controversial but still attracts some criticism from our parties. The section proposes to impose an obligation to provide pre-sale, point of sale and post-sale information not only to consumer credit insurance contracts but also to any other kind of insurance contract which the regulation designates this section applies to. So we are really giving it a very wide, maybe too wide, brief.

The coalition is concerned that the government may use this as a backdoor approach. The industry body, the ICA, does not believe the industry should be exposed to future regulation bringing in other classes of insurance unless it is clear that there is proper justification. They have a potential to be extremely costly to insurers, and the increased cost would in time be passed on to consumers. Given that at this point the government has not clearly specified the contents of such notices in particular, there is serious concern by and for the insurance industry. I note the Trade Practices Commission report recommended that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . measures be taken to improve the quality, timeliness and relevance of the information on CCI provided to consumers, by ensuring that clear, plain English information is available at the point-of-sale on the nature of the cover, the terms, conditions and exclusions, the "duty of disclosure", the right to choose insurance and an insurer and the right to cancel the policy at any time and that post-sale information is provided to CCI policyholders.

What is interesting is that this is one of the measures that the commission recommended to improve consumer information on CCI products, and its recommendation was the immediate implementation of such measures. Thankfully, the government's understanding of the word `immediate' is not adopted by the rest of the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the timing of this requirement, the provision is to commence on the day fixed by proclamation. Given that the provision may extend to all classes of insurance, some further time may well be necessary, particularly when one takes into account the contents of such notices and that those notices are to be prescribed by regulation.

I now turn to the central problem. I refer to clause 5, which amends section 15 of the Insurance Contracts Act, and clause 19, which omits section 87(1E) from the Trade Practices Act. These clauses aim to clarify the position in respect of what legislation will govern insurance contracts. Proposed section 15 provides that an insurance contract cannot be the subject of relief in the form of judicial review of a contract on the grounds it is harsh, oppressive, unconscionable, unjust, unfair or inequitable; or relief for insureds from the consequence of making a misrepresentation—I emphasise these words—under any other legislation. I am grateful for the government's latest amendment because it adds the words `but does not include relief in the form of compensatory damages'. I believe this is important and one of the consequences and benefits of the delay in this bill's presentation, which delay enabled this very necessary amendment to get through.

The Trade Practices Commission report says—we wholeheartedly agree—that consumers need speedy access to the courts and early resolution of their dispute if they are to avoid the consequence of failure to meet their obligations under credit agreements. The ICA and the coalition are somewhat concerned whether the amendment in its original form or its new format is actually necessary. The industry put to us that the Insurance Contracts Act provides comprehensive consumer protection in relation to insurance contracts through the duty of utmost good faith, the code in part IV in respect of disclosures and misrepresentations, and the general provisions relating to insurance contracts in part V.

The industry argued that the Insurance Contracts Act should remain the specific mechanism for consumer protection for insurance contracts and that the protection is already afforded for many pre-contractual matters under the Trade Practices Act. Therefore, we ask the government to explain why extension to other acts is necessary when these four or five provisions which are already there seem to be all-embracing. This particular provision creates an element of certainty. The provision not only adds to complexity but can create enormous concern, and maybe even increase costs. The opposition supports the legislation, together with the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Insurance Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993, like the bill we have just debated, is also a significant step in the right direction. However, the Australian Democrats believe that some of the consumer protection provisions in this legislation are unnecessarily limited and should be strengthened. This bill is a result of controversy about consumer credit insurance. This class of insurance is designed to take over loan repayments when a consumer is unable to repay loans due to death, sickness or unemployment. No-one disputes that consumers have been badly served by credit insurance. Many have been misled into buying policies as a condition of a loan, and many policies have been ridiculously expensive compared with the actual cover that they provide.

PARA.TAB: Reform of the regulation of consumer credit has been recommended by consumer groups and the Trade Practices Commission and endorsed by a government working party. The primary impact of the bill is to give the Insurance and Superannuation Commission power to supervise and enforce the Insurance Contracts Act 1984. The act, as it now stands, is self-administering, leaving consumers to take legal action when a contract goes wrong. The costs and complexities involved mean that this remedy is beyond the reach of most Australians. The Democrats therefore welcome the commission's proposed new role, which includes the power to obtain insurance and administrative documents and to take legal action on behalf of consumers.

There are new provisions regulating the provision of information on consumer credit insurance and any other classes of insurance prescribed by regulation. A 14-day cooling off period will be mandatory. Again, we welcome these developments which are a definite advance on the previous provisions.

Having said that, I say that the Democrats do have three concerns about this bill. First, the provisions which allow an insurance company to withhold incriminating information appear to unnecessarily tie the hands of the commission. We have been told that such provisions are standard in situations such as this. However, I would like to see evidence and to know why. I am particularly interested to know what powers the commission would exercise where an insurer withholds the incriminating documents. Obviously, the commission would smell a rat; it would know something was going wrong. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) to explain what action the commission could take to follow up on its suspicions.

Our second concern is that an insurer can withhold any document dealing with the insurance cover of a particular person, unless that person has given written authority. For the commission to seek authorisation it obviously needs to know the identity of the person concerned. I would ask the minister how the commission is supposed to discover the names and addresses of people who do not know that there is a problem with their insurance contracts, or do not realise that if there is a problem they can go to the commission for help.

If there is a problem with a class of insurance contracts affecting a large number of people, why should the commission not be able to get their names and addresses from the insurer so that they can seek authorisation to obtain the personal documents? There is a question of privacy here, but there is also a question of consumer protection. I suspect that most consumers would prefer the commission to have the power to protect them in such cases, especially in view of the secrecy provisions in this bill which prevent the commission from disclosing any personal information in most circumstances.

My final concern relates to section 15 of the Insurance Contracts Act which limits the legal avenues available for contesting insurance contracts. This bill, and one of the government's amendments to it, will have the effect of removing some of the real or imagined limitations imposed by section 15. That is to be welcomed as far as it goes.

The argument in favour of section 15 is that the act imposes a duty of utmost good faith on the parties to an insurance contract. That duty is so broad, the argument goes, as to encompass the remedies excluded by section 15 and more. It would be unreasonable to make two parallel sets of remedies available, hence the restrictions imposed by section 15.

My concern is that the duty of utmost good faith is so ill-defined that it may be deterring consumers from seeking legal redress. That is a view that has been put to us by the Australian Consumers Association and has been expressed by the Trade Practices Commission. There has been a minimal amount of litigation based on this utmost good faith test. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission puts this down to the self-administering nature of the act, which will end as a result of the bill.

Notwithstanding that possibility—and the commission acknowledges that it is only a possibility—I fail to see why the act cannot spell out what is meant by `utmost good faith' to make the provision useable. It seems extraordinary that the duty of parties to an insurance contract, which is a contentious and complicated matter, is encompassed by such a vague and general phrase. I would ask the parliamentary secretary, who is at the table, to respond to these three concerns, either now or perhaps during the committee stage of this bill. In recognition that this bill is a step forward and in the right direction the Australian Democrats will support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Lees and Senator Watson for their contributions. In respect of Senator Lees's three concerns, I will deal with them in the committee stage. I appreciate the comments and questions that she has asked in relation to the running sheet. Perhaps it is easier to deal with them in the committee stage also.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with some of the points that Senator Watson raised, although I have to say at the outset that his points have been raised by the industry with government. We have taken them into consideration. Senator Watson acknowledged that we have taken them into consideration in some areas in the amendments. The honourable senator may be pursuing these matters in detail in committee—I suspect he will.

There has been widespread consultation. We have accepted and taken on board some suggestions from the industry. We are not prepared to do everything the industry wants by way of amendment. We are simply going to have to agree to disagree on some of the points that Senator Watson raised.

The main objectives of this bill are to amend the Insurance Contracts Bill. It will introduce statutory disclosure requirements, pre-sale, point of sale and post sale notices for consumer credit insurers, so that insureds—I must say that is a new word to me—can make more informed decisions about their insurance purchases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like `payee'.
—Yes, it is. I am not sure whether it is new English. I get a bit concerned with some of the terminology I see emerging.
—You have enough difficulty with established English, Nick.

—Let us get on with the legislation. These notices may be extended to other classes of insurers if the need arises. It provides for a 14-day cooling off period for purchasers of consumer credit insurance products. It clarifies the right of insureds to seek redress under the Trade Practices Act for pre-contractual unconscionable conduct by insurers. It gives the Insurance and Superannuation Commission statutory responsibility for the general administration of the Insurance Contracts Act of 1984, and allows the commission to take representative legal action on behalf of insureds where this is in the public interest.

PARA.TAB: The amendments that have been tabled here and that we will deal with are mainly technical improvements that have been suggested by the parties themselves. These include clarification of the meaning of the expression `relief', presently used in section 15 of the act; clarification of the limitations on the power of the commissioner to seek information from insurers in the course of administration of the act; insertion of a penalty provision for non-compliance in place of an existing provision which requires directors or auditors of insurance companies to be responsible for the accuracy of information provided, and insertion of provisions protecting the privacy of third party claimants as well as that of policyholders.

We believe that the amendments will significantly improve the effectiveness of the bill before the Senate. I thank the opposition and the Democrats for the general support that they have indicated for this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.
Amendments (by Senator Sherry)—by leave—agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)Schedule, page 4, proposed subsection 11C(1), insert "for any purpose connected with the general administration of this Act, "after "The Commissioner may,".
(2)Schedule, page 5, proposed subsection 11C(3), omit "the person", substitute "that person, or another person having an entitlement to claim under that insurance cover,".
(3)Schedule, page 5, proposed subsection 11D(1), insert "for any purpose connected with the general administration of this Act," after "The Commissioner may,".
(4)Schedule, page 5, proposed subsection 11D(1), omit all the words after paragraph (b), substitute:

PARA.TAB: "; (c)copies of any training guides, work manuals or other materials of a similar nature used by an insurer in instructing its employees or any insurance intermediaries dealing with persons who have, or may be likely to seek, insurance cover from the insurer.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: (5)Schedule, page 5, proposed subsection 11D(2), omit the subsection, substitute:

PARA.TAB: "`(2) An insurer must not, intentionally or recklessly, give the Commissioner, in purported compliance with a requirement under subsection

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1), particulars or statistics that are false or misleading in a material particular.

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 150 penalty units.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: (6)Schedule, page 5, proposed paragraph 11D(4)(a), insert "or third party claimant" after "particular insured".
(7)Schedule, page 5, proposed paragraph 11D(4)(b), insert "or third party claimant" after "particular insured".
(8)Schedule, page 5, proposed section 11D, add at the end of the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(6) in this section:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "third party claimant" means a person, other than the insured, who is, or might be, entitled to make a claim under a contract of insurance.".
(9)Schedule, page 8, proposed subsection 15(2), insert "but does not include relief in the form of compensatory damages" after paragraph (b).

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of clauses on which I seek some clarification, and I thank the parliamentary secretary for his previous comments. Clause 4 gives the ISC extensive powers to require insurers to produce documents under proposed sections 11C and 11D. The only basis on which insurers may actually resist the production of such documents is if there is a reasonable excuse, or if the production of the document would tend to incriminate the insurer.

PARA.TAB: Section 11F deals with secrecy, but permits the ISC to distribute documents in the performance of its duties in connection with the act, for example by publishing material in its annual report, by distributing the documents to other parts of government and by distributing the documents to other persons where, in the minister's opinion, it is in the public interest to do so.

It is possible that the documents requested by the ISC could include documents that are commercially sensitive, confidential, or that have legal professional privilege attached to them. There is a case that such documents actually should be protected by these secrecy provisions. The reason for this, I believe, is that if documents are allowed to be distributed beyond the ISC, then it is likely to lead not only to a loss of legal professional privilege but may also lead to a loss of secrecy attached to commercially sensitive or confidential documents.

Similarly these documents should not be available to be used by the ISC in representative actions under the act. I put this case to Senator Sherry because, unlike the provisions in the section 346 of the Superannuation Act, the secrecy provisions here are not protected under section 38 of the Freedom of Information Act which would, in that case, permit the ISC to refuse freedom of information requests in respect of documents collected under these provisions. I find it strange that there is this difference between life assurance and general insurance. This is an issue that does need some explanation by the government.

I also seek a confirmation from the ISC through the parliamentary secretary that it will not permit the distribution of documents pursuant to its powers under the secrecy provisions where the documents are commercially sensitive, confidential, or to which legal professional privilege is attached, where they could be used in representative action taken by the ISC.

I also seek confirmation that it is a reasonable excuse for an insurer to refuse to hand over documents on the basis that they are subject to legal professional privilege, that the information sought is commercially sensitive, and/or that it is confidential, without undertakings being given by the minister and the ISC that in no circumstances will documents be passed on or used in litigation against the insurer that is actually providing them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that that is the case with the ISC power to obtain documents which are subject to secrecy provisions, where they are covered by freedom of information provisions, or where there is commercial sensitivity or legal privilege. There are common law, freedom of information and other constraints on the ISC which prevent it releasing the information in the circumstances Senator Watson was concerned about.

PARA.TAB: The ISC is a responsible body. It is subject to accountability and scrutiny by government and the parliament. Information can and will be used only in a reasonable way. Thus any information that names an insurer will be used only where it is warranted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also relates to the provision of documents. What action can the commission take in response to a refusal by an insurance company to provide what it believes are incriminating documents? Basically, what provisions are there?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, where something may incriminate a company, it cannot be forced to disclose; but it does alert the ISC to the fact that there is potentially a problem. The ISC will then naturally take a much greater degree of interest in that particular case. It would be unreasonable to force a company to disclose documents that may incriminate it. However, it certainly would alert the ISC and make it more interested, aware and keener to go further into the case. It may not be able to obtain some of the documents, on the grounds of incrimination, but it would certainly mean that it would investigate other aspects of the case as fully as it could.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask another question relating to 11C(3), which again deals with documents. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, there will be occasions when the commission should be able to discover the names and addresses of people who do not know that there is a problem with their insurance contracts or do not realise that they can go to the commission for help. Surely the commission should be able to get their names and addresses from the insurer or from the documents or whatever so that it can seek authorisation to get all the rest of the documents it needs?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Lees is suggesting in this case is that the ISC should take a particularly activist role in going out and seeking names and following those names through, presumably going to see these people. I am advised that there are a couple of problems with that approach. Firstly, to what extent can it become activist? There are limitations on staffing and resources to do that sort of highly activist work. Secondly, it would raise some privacy aspects. If a consumer has a particular concern, does he necessarily want the ISC to come in, having obtained his name, and take an early activist role? The consumer may not want that. It is a matter of balancing how far the ISC should go in being activist in that way.

PARA.TAB: I can imagine that there would be concerns expressed by some consumers if the ISC suddenly turned up, having got the name and address, and said, `We believe you may have a problem; we are here to help'. I think a lot of consumers would view that as being helpful, but some would think, `How did they get my name? Why are they turning up when I haven't asked them? I might want their help a little later on, but I don't necessarily want an officer from a government agency turning up on my doorstep, having obtained a name and address when I thought it was confidential'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —What education will there be, therefore, about these new provisions so that consumers will know where to go and how they can seek redress if they do have a problem?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there is no specific budget set aside to run a major advertising campaign alerting the public to these changes. Naturally, with changes of this nature, which I think generally improve the rights of consumers, the ISC is contacting all the main consumer groups and, obviously, the companies themselves. It has asked those consumer groups and other organisations to try through their various publications to increase the level of public awareness of these new provisions and to ensure that the public is aware of the new rights under these provisions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one final question that I flagged in my speech in the second reading debate. It relates to section 15, exclusions—that is, that the duty of utmost good faith provides an adequate range of remedies. In the view of such diverse bodies as the Australian Consumers Association and the Trade Practices Commission, the utmost good faith test is too vague to be really useful, and there has been only a very small amount of litigation based upon it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of good faith in common law, as defined in the act, will be further developed as the act is administered. Because it is very early days for administration of the act—it is not law as yet—the commission will review the way in which it administers it, based on some practical experience. If it sees that there are problems with the application of the good faith principle, there may be some further change in that area. It is particularly keen to have the concept clarified with some practical experience based on some of the problems that may emerge in the application of that principle. It is a principle that is not easy to define in provisions such as this.

PARA.TAB: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sherry) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 2 March 1994, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three bills the Senate is now debating, Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), comprise the traditional additional estimates bills for 1993-94. In these particular bills, the parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1993-94 under the appropriation budget bills which became acts Nos 1 and 2, and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act.

PARA.TAB: These additional appropriations in the three bills before us total $710 million. After allowing for prospective savings, the appropriations sought represent a net increase, in total, of $164.5 million in the appropriations for 1993-94, which is an increase of half a per cent on the amounts made available at the time of the 1993-94 budget.

The opposition does not, of course, oppose the appropriation bills. However, there are some unusual items in them that are worth drawing attention to. For example, in Appropriation Bill (No. 4), which seeks an additional appropriation of about $166 million for a variety of items, there is included a figure of $25.2 million for compensation for defendants and others in the Midford Paramount case. I remind the Senate that that was the case instrumental in the criticisms levelled in a damning report by an independent committee of inquiry into the functioning of the Australian Customs Service which has resulted in major changes being proposed for the service and the removal of Mr Kelly, the head of the service.

In these items there are various appropriations about which on occasions there has been, and may continue to be, considerable debate. Overall, I repeat that the coalition will not be opposing the bills. In this debate I wish to look at the budget outlook for the government as it moves towards the 1994-95 budget which, of course, is to be introduced on 10 May. This is a fundamental break with tradition because in the past we have always had budgets introduced in August. This time as a first the budget will be introduced for the forthcoming year before the end of the current financial year.

As part of the deals being constantly done in this place by the government with the minor parties, we have the absolute charade at the moment of the Treasurer's tax club, comprising the government and the minor parties, purporting to hold negotiations over the budget, even though the minor parties do not have any power at all to change the government's budget proposals. They, in total, including the independents, have just 10 votes in the Senate; the coalition has 36. The Democrats and the Greens will not be able to change any of the government's proposals without the opposition's support. Before I conclude, I will indicate what the coalition will and will not support.

I make the point that the purported negotiations going on between the government and the minor parties is nothing more than a charade. To the credit of several members of the minor parties, they have already woken up to that. But, as part of that negotiation, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) released earlier this week what he called The 1994-95 Fiscal Framework which is a document which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . presents the economic and fiscal framework for the 1994-95 Budget and is the basis for consultations with the Democrats, Greens (WA) and Senator Harradine as set out in the agreement reached between those parties and the Government.

I therefore assume that we can take the document as setting out the government's initial thinking as to where it is going to finish up in terms of the 1993-94 budget outturn and where it sees the main issues for the framing of the 1994-95 budget. The document is very disappointing. It has given no new information at all but just reiterated the government's strategy. As I said, the minor parties have seen through the charade and know that this is not, in any sense, a genuine platform for negotiation.

PARA.TAB: What worries me most about the document in terms of substance is that there is an underlying impression that one gets of major complacency on the part of the government about prospects for the budget for the year ahead, although the Treasurer, being the author of the document, says the fiscal framework for next year will be very tight. I will elaborate on that in a moment. Having read the document, there is a feeling that the government is smugly looking at the economic recovery, which is, undoubtedly, commencing to occur, and saying almost, `She'll be right, Jack. Things will grow in a normal cyclical way and most of our problems will be solved in that sense as a result of that. There isn't a whole lot more that we have to do'.

Nothing could be further from the truth. The fundamental problems which beset the Australian economy are very little different from what they were when the now Prime Minister and then Treasurer, Mr Keating, pulled the levers and engineered `the recession that we had to have' back in 1990. Over the last four years Australia has gone through a great deal of trauma and hardship, not just for the Australian economy as a whole but, much more tragically, for most Australians—in particular those millions of Australians who are unemployed, still, and the further million or so who cannot find full-time work or work of a nature that they would wish.

We have gone through all of that hardship without having made the necessary structural changes that will enable the Australian economy to grow on a sustainable basis in the future in a way which will enable significant long-term job creation, a reduction in unemployment, and the overcoming of the Achilles heel of the Australian economy, namely, our balance of payments.

If we do not get those structural changes right, we will continue to be on the boom-bust cycle witnessed so much in the past. There is no indication in the Treasurer's fiscal framework document for 1994-95 to suggest that the government has, in any way, learnt the lessons of the past. I will point to some examples to demonstrate my concern. In the document the government says:

SPEECH.PARA: The challenge involved in framing the 1994-95 Budget is therefore to adequately address priority areas such as unemployment, Native Title legislation, industry and regional development while maintaining a fiscal policy which will promote a durable extension of the recovery now clearly under way. Sustained high levels of economic growth require the maintenance of low inflation, low interest rates and the avoidance of a balance of payments constraint. A fiscal policy which reduces the level of public sector demands on the economy as private sector growth accelerates, and reduces the public sector's call on the national savings needed to fund economic growth, is essential to achieve these outcomes.

That is a very negative approach to the requirements of fiscal policy here in Australia. The Treasurer is saying that the government needs to reduce its budget deficit to help the national savings cause. That is technically correct, but where it is so negative is that it poses no prospect or expectation of that happening. It makes no attempt not just to reduce the public sector deficit but to eliminate it so that the government can stop doing what it has been doing right through this government's period of office, which is—to use a Paul Keating term of a few years ago—`putting its hand into the cookie jar of the nation's savings'. This government has been doing that year after year by clocking up more and more deficits of varying degrees of magnitude. Most of them, compared with the standards of the past, were record deficits—by many billions of dollars.

PARA.TAB: So it is not simply a matter of the government reducing its budget deficit. It ought to be saying that it will eliminate its budget deficit and make a positive contribution to savings, not just reduce the negative contribution that it is already making. In its paper, the government goes on to talk about the economic recovery. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The recovery has strengthened noticeably over the past six months.

That is true, but it does not acknowledge the fact that this economy was absolutely shattered by government policies which led to the very stark, brutal recession that we have had over the last four years. So the recovery is starting from a very low base indeed.

PARA.TAB: The government also omits to say that the recovery that we are witnessing in the economy is a much more muted recovery, a much smaller recovery in proportionate terms, than we saw in the corresponding period of recovery after the last recession in the early 1980s. The government then goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: There are early signs that business investment is beginning to respond to such favourable fundamentals as high levels of corporate profitability and reduced balance sheets—
It then says:
that response, however, is still being constrained by excess capacity which, although beginning to fall, remains relatively high.

So far as investment is concerned—and investment is a key plank, perhaps the essential plank in sustainable economic growth prospects for the future—it is certainly modest, to say the least. Yet the government, in its predictions for the year ahead, says that it is expecting a significant pick up in business investment next year—it uses the word `substantial'—and that is implicit in the projections of economic growth in future years.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the investment climate, the situation overseas, the turmoil that we have witnessed on financial markets over the last few days and the start of the reversal of the appreciation of the Australian dollar that was occurring—in recent days we have seen the Australian dollar fall a couple of cents against the US dollar, which is a fall of three to four percentage points—the scope for complacency about the climate in which potential investment will occur is just not there.

The government is saying it expects underlying growth in the economy next year to be around four per cent. I think that is certainly questionable on the basis of the evidence to date, but even if it were correct, one must say, `So what?'. That is no big deal. Indeed, it is a very poor result if that is the best we can do coming out of a recession of the depth that we have had in recent years.

I remind the Senate that it is not all that long ago that the Prime Minister really put his job on the line when he said, `If you can't get four per cent growth in any year you should give the game away'. The government is saying in this document that even in what it sees as a strong recovery year it is not going to do better than four per cent. I think that is a considerable concern. The government's complacency about the balance of payments is breathtaking. In this document the Treasurer says:

SPEECH.PARA: The current account deficit (CAD) in the first half of 1993-94 was also better than expected, leading to a revised forecast for the year of $17 billion or 4 per cent of GDP.

Big deal to that! He is saying that because of some recovery in the economy, the huge deficit of $18 billion—$18,000 million—that the government forecast that we would have in our dealings with the rest of the world in this current year, will be reduced by a whole $1 billion. That is just not good enough. It is an appalling result and it compares very unfavourably with the two preceding years. In 1991-92 we had a large enough balance of payments deficit. It was $12.4 billion. In 1992-93, it jumped to $15.4 billion, which was 3.8 per cent of gross domestic product.

PARA.TAB: Now the Treasurer is beaming about an improvement in the balance of payments position because the budget forecast for the balance of payments this year is not going to be quite as bad as the horrendous figure that the government was proposing at that time. One could go on and on through this document and express the same concerns that I am outlining and giving some examples of here. Time does not permit me to go further into that. No doubt they will be matters for debate on later occasions.

But it is clear beyond any doubt that the government is far too complacent about its approach to the budget for 1994-95. It is saying implicitly that there will be a budget deficit in 1994-95 of between $12 billion and $13 billion, which would be a bit of a fall on the likely outcome for this year of $14 3/4 billion—but it is nowhere near good enough. If it is to have any hope of achieving the deficit reduction to one per cent or thereabouts of GDP that it has claimed it is aiming for in 1996-97—this is the strategy that it went to the last election with, and we all know it lied its way into government at that election through making a whole string of promises that it knew it could not keep, and most of which it has broken since the last election; and the deficit reduction strategy will be, I am sure, another one of them—then it has to make a much better start on reducing that deficit than it appears to be doing in the coming budget.

The coalition has put out a budget declaration. It was announced by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Downer, a couple of days ago. It comprises four basic planks: firstly, that there should be no tax increases; secondly, that no new taxes should be introduced; thirdly, that the budget deficit in 1994-95 should be below the $12 billion or $13 billion planned by Mr Willis; and, fourthly, that there should be no overall increase in government spending. They are the four planks of basic budget policy that we are going to hold the government accountable to in the forthcoming budget. I think it will have a major task on its hands; it is going to have to do much better than it is intimating at the moment it will be able to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the appropriation bills Nos 2, 3 and 4 of 1994. Before I get into the bills themselves and the lack of funding for certain things in Australia, I wish to mention the COAG meeting that was recently held in Hobart, where the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) hijacked the debate by claiming that only the states must complete micro-economic reform. This is happening at the same time as he is attempting to centralise power more and more in Canberra and asking the states to carry out his micro-economic reform so that he and Canberra can take the credit for it.

PARA.TAB: Over the years this has been aided and abetted by certain state premiers, such as the former Premier of Western Australia, Dr Carmen Lawrence, the endorsed candidate for the seat of Fremantle. In the unlikely event that she wins on Saturday week, I will outline to honourable senators a comparison of what she has and has not done for Western Australia. It will be remembered that Carmen Lawrence sat through all those cabinet meetings of the Burke and Dowding years and, when it came to the Western Australia royal commission suffered a sudden loss of memory—nothing could be remembered! Yet a former Liberal Premier of Western Australia with his ministers—and I can remember Mr Jones coming into the royal commission—got out of parliament 10 years before Dr Lawrence and they could remember everything. It is marvellous how the younger generation in Australia has a lack of memory.

Carmen Lawrence was No. 1 to sell out state rights and individual rights in Western Australia—she gave them away. It is important that states, especially those as far away as Western Australia, do not give up state and individual rights. Yet that is exactly what she did. For example, when Dr Lawrence attended the first COAG meeting in Brisbane, she signed a blank cheque, with no conditions whatsoever, to sell out Western Australia's standard gauge line that runs from Kalgoorlie through to Fremantle. This is the only standard gauge line on the Australian standard grid that was making a profit, but she was ready to sell it out for nothing. That line makes a profit for Western Australia of $2 million a year. When the Court government came along, Richard Court and his able Minister for Transport, Eric Charlton, soon put a stop to it and refused to go into the National Rail Corporation because of the sell-out that would have occurred.

Then we have the case of Mabo, where various premiers in Australia sold out or took a soft line to Mr Keating. But not Richard Court, the Premier of Western Australia—and it was just as well that he stood up to Mr Keating because not many others did. Judging by what Carmen Lawrence said during the Mabo debate, I believe that if unfortunately she had still been premier of that state, she too would have sold out. Of course, as we know, Mr Court acted to stop the federal government taking over land management in Western Australia.

Let me move on to money matters. I refer to an article in today's Australian Financial Review which notes that, if the forthcoming Premiers Conference takes up the Commonwealth Grants Commission recommendations, there will be massive funding cuts to Queensland and Western Australia. The commission has recommended that grants to Queensland should be reduced $148.7 million to $3.2 billion, and in the case of Western Australia funding should drop $53.5 million to $1.8 billion. As usual, the big winners are the more populous states of Victoria and New South Wales. In Victoria, the Liberal government has not been in power long enough to turn the economy of that state around, but it is doing quite a job. The same comment applies to South Australia. The article states:
Commission chairman, Mr Dick Rye, said yesterday the changes to State funding proposed in the report reflected changes in State economies and the use of more up-to-date census information.

SPEECH.PARA: I leave aside for the moment the census information, but the improved economy of Western Australia, as a result of the efforts of the incoming Court government, is reflected in the fact that that state will receive a cut in Commonwealth grants. The economy is obviously looking up in Queensland, with improvements in agriculture and the mining industry. It is peculiar that even though states act to improve their own economies, their Commonwealth grants are cut off by Canberra.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Grants Commission has made a few other strange findings. One of the reasons for changing the allocation of grants to Queensland and Western Australia was that those states also reported a reduction in the proportion of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders in their populations while New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania had large increases. I find that hard to believe. I would like to see more definite statistics than those proffered in that article.

Mr Goss is reported as saying that the whole system was `seriously flawed', and I agree. Because of the time lag in Western Australia—three hours behind, but we consider ourselves three hours and more ahead of any other place in Australia—Richard Court has not had time to comment on the Commonwealth Grants Commission recommendations. Proposed road funding in the last budget has also had a big effect on these figures. I seek leave to have this article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: QUEENSLAND, WA LOSE OUT IN TOSS OF GRANTS COIN

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Grants Commission has recommended massive funding cuts to Queensland and Western Australia in the lead-up to the Premiers' Conference later this month.

Grants to Queensland should be reduced $148.7 million to $3.2 billion as a starting point for the Premiers' Conference, says the commission, and Western Australia's funding should drop $53.5 million to $1.8 billion.
The big winner under commission recommendations would be NSW, which would gain an extra $130.7 million to bring its total grants to $5.2 billion.
Northern Territory would receive a funding increase of $34.1 million to $829 million.
The recommendations have already set off the perennial debate among governments over the use of fiscal equalisation mechanisms to work out Commonwealth grants.
Commission chairman, Mr Dick Rye, said yesterday the changes to State funding proposed in the report reflected changes in State economies and the use of more up-to-date census information.

He said recommendations were made on the principle that each State should be given the capacity to provide an average standard of public services, assuming this was done at an average level of efficiency.
Previous commission recommendations on State funding had been based on the 1986 Census, with the use of 1991 figures allowing greater attention to be paid to recent demographic changes.
Since 1986, populations of Queensland and Western Australia became more closely centred on the State capital while the populations of NSW, Victoria and Northern Territory became more widespread.
Queensland and Western Australia also reported reductions in the proportion of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders in their populations while NSW, Victoria and Tasmania had large increases.
NSW and Victoria also had rises in their share of the total non-English speaking population.
But the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, yesterday angrily called on the Federal Government to reject the report which he described as "seriously flawed".
"This is not fair, we want it fixed and we've got a bloody good case to have it fixed," Mr Goss said.
The proposed cuts to Queensland follow reductions last year of $115 million, taking the two-year funding cutback to $263.7 million.
Mr Goss said Queensland was effectively being penalised for strong economic performance while NSW and Victoria were benefiting from financial mismanagement.
While the Queensland and Western Australia Governments were yesterday concerned about the funding recommendations, they were welcomed by NSW Treasurer, Mr Peter Collins.

Federal Treasurer, Mr Willis, moved to allay concerned of the Queensland Government. He said the proposed funding changes were "only indicative and will at least need to be updated for variations in State population and any changes to the size of the funding pool".

TALK.START.PARA: —I now turn to road funding, which is an ever increasing problem in Australia. Although a new budget is just around the corner, we are still operating under last year's budget, which saw the termination of the black spot program. If I remember rightly, that program was inaugurated by the Hawke government and Mr Bob Brown as Minister for Land Transport. Federal road funding in this year's budget was cut by $614 million, falling from $1.627 billion to $1.013 billion in 1993-94.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, the federal government's collections from fuel excise rose dramatically.

In 1982-83, fuel excise brought in $1.364 billion and road funding was $850 million, or 64.2 per cent of excise collection. In the 1993-94 budget, fuel excise is estimated at $8.379 billion—nearly $9 billion—and road funding has fallen to only $1.013 billion, only 12.1 per cent of collections. Worse still, in the forward estimates for 1994-95 there is a further increase in fuel excise to $9.315 billion, with road funding outlays of only $807 million, or only 8.7 per cent of collections. The result is that many local governments and municipalities have had to cut back on their programs.
I call on the government, as I have done at various times previously, to bring in the black spot program. If time permits I want to talk about Greenmount Hill in Western Australia.
For 10 years councils have had to deal with decreased road funding and it is time to bring

SPEECH.PARA: it to an end because the need for road funding is increasing, not decreasing. After World War II there was a massive laying of bitumen around Australia and a good life for bitumen roads, as I have said before, is about 35 years. If that massive program of bitumen laying started in about 1950, the life of that bitumen would have expired in 1985. If we want to keep repairing rather than replacing the bitumen, it will need far more money.

When Senator Collins was minister for transport, much was made about road funding allocated to roads but not being spent on roads. I was always a critic of untying road funding but this government went ahead and did it. Senator Collins criticised some municipalities in New South Wales, yet the same went on in the state of Western Australia. I asked him a question about $8 million that was taken off road funding in Western Australia. A letter dated 2 June 1992 from Mr John Dawkins, Treasurer of Australia at the time, to the Premier of Western Australia at that time, Dr Carmen Lawrence, states:
Dear Premier
The Prime Minister's "One Nation" Economic Statement made available to Western Australia up to $47.7 million under the National Highway System (NHS) Program.
Of these monies, some $39.7 million is to be allocated to specific NHS projects. I understand that agreement between the respective Commonwealth and State Ministers as to these projects is imminent.

The remaining $8 million has been held over, pending further consideration of infrastructure projects of benefit to the Western Australian community. While notionally allocated to the NHS program, it was anticipated in the formulation of the "One Nation" package that this further consideration would encompass other than potential NHS projects.
When making this decision we had in mind the fact that the Hatt Report on the redevelopment of Subiaco Oval was in its final stages of preparation.

Should the WA Government decide to proceed with the redevelopment project, the Commonwealth would be prepared, under certain conditions, to have this remaining $8 million allocated for this purpose in 1992/93.
The then Premier of Western Australia, in probably the only good act she did for us, wrote back to Mr Dawkins and said:

I refer to your letter of 2 June 1992 proposing that $8 million of road funding made available for Western Australian under the `One Nation' statement be reallocated to the Subiaco Oval redevelopment.
I cannot agree to this proposal, as Western Australia has very substantial needs for road funding which are not being met from existing resources.

She went on to explain that they could not do it. Yet when I asked Senator Collins in the Senate why that $8 million was removed from road funding for Western Australia and allocated to Subiaco Oval, he completely denied that it was ever for road funding. I asked:

My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I remind the minister that last week he said that he had no time for states that did not spend untied road funding on roads. What part did the minister take when the Treasurer instructed the then Premier of WA . . . to set aside $8 million of the One Nation road package for WA for non-road projects and be spent on redeveloping Subiaco Oval?
Senator Collins replied:
As the Western Australian government knows full well, the amount of money that was set aside for Subiaco Oval has not compromised the funding for the road program in Western Australia at all.
I asked the following supplementary question:
If that is the case, when will the minister restore the $8 million to WA's road funding?
Senator Collins said:
Mr President, as I just explained to the Senate, it did not come out of there—

meaning road funding. I think that Senator Collins has a big explanation to make as to why he misled the Senate that day. I believe this is part of a wider concept belonging to the sports rort situation, where $8 million was taken out of road funding, allocated to the Subiaco Oval and yet denied by the previous minister. There must be more to it than this, because there are a lot of unanswered questions. I would like an explanation sooner or later, and those opposite can be assured I will be following it up.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the decision by the ABC to turn off the short-wave transmitters in Western Australia that supply the ABC regional program for the more remote areas and out into the sea. A few weeks ago the ABC turned off those VLX transmitters in the 31-metre band and left those remote areas high and dry as far as regional ABC is concerned. Mr Murrell, acting manager of the ABC regional station, explained that it will save $2 million in infrastructure costs and $800,000 in annual maintenance costs. He said that people could put in an earth receiving dish and get the same program. They will not get the same program, for a start. The earth receiving dishes cost about $3,000, with another $2,000 to receive radio, and they do not give the right program.

What is more, an earth receiving dish cannot be strapped to a person's back or a vehicle when mobile. I have received a lot of letters from ships masters, who say that those dishes are impossible to use on a ship at sea. I look forward to the government instructing the ABC to allocate money to keep the short wave transmitters.

I will find another time to bring up the matter of Greenmount Hill funding to relieve the situation that led to the massive accident last December which cost two lives and in which 21 cars were wrecked by one runaway truck. I look forward to the government addressing some of the concerns I have raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the appropriation bills at this stage, but one could be excused for thinking that perhaps the Fremantle by-election is more important than the appropriation bills. The previous speaker, Senator Panizza, who was heard in silence, opened his comments by referring to the Fremantle by-election and, in particular, one of the candidates in that by-election, Carmen Lawrence, a former Premier of Western Australia and a former leader of the Australian Labor Party in Western Australia. I am not going to seek to canvass the issues in the Fremantle by-election; that will be done in Fremantle. An opposition as bereft of ideas as this one has not yet learned that elections are won in the electorate. They will not be won in this chamber or, indeed, in the other place.

PARA.TAB: My provocation for getting up is not so much what Senator Panizza said but, rather, what one of his colleagues said last week. It was one of the most despicable comments I have heard come out of the Australian parliament or, indeed, any parliament in this country. An individual member, obviously with the endorsement of his leader, got up and attacked a political candidate and virtually accused that candidate of murder. We also heard in this chamber—I only heard it afterwards—accusations about blood on the hands. Mr Keating, in defending attacks on him the other day, said, `You started it first'. In the past I have refused to use this place as a coward's castle, but I give fair warning that, if this type of behaviour continues to be condoned by Dr Hewson and by the leaders of the Liberal Party and the National Party in this place, I too will use those cowardly tactics to attack individuals who sometimes do not have the right to defend themselves.

Carmen Lawrence can well look after herself. I hope some of the ministers on the front bench of the Western Australian government are equally good at looking after themselves because, if this pattern of events continues, I shall get up in places like this and table evidence that will implicate them in a number of issues, not necessarily with blood on the hands. I do not want to engage in cowardly attacks on any other individual but, if these actions continue, obviously with the endorsement of the leadership of the Liberal Party and possibly with the connivance of the National Party, two can play at that game. I certainly do not want to get into it, but I will, if necessary.

Let this be fair warning, in this or any other campaigns that may be engaged in in the future, that when stones are thrown they can be thrown back. Some of the most vulnerable ministers around at the moment are certain ministers in the Western Australian Court Liberal government. I do not want to do it, but it will be done if those attacks by persons in the other place continue. Indeed, it was done here the other night by one of my Senate colleagues from Western Australia.

I mention just one other matter. Senator Panizza mentioned the Australian Financial Review. I draw people's attention to that newspaper and ask them to open the front cover and look at the large advertisement that appears at the bottom of page 2. That advertisement is canvassing for sale some 48 schools, 48 public institutions. If opposition senators want to examine appropriations, they should have a look at that and see what a Liberal Party administration is doing to community services in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in this debate on the appropriation bills, I want to make a few points about government waste. I do not think there is any doubt that the Australian Labor Party has never been able to handle money; that is well known. If we ever needed an example of that, we have had it recently with the sports rorts affair, where there was a laissez-faire attitude to handing out money without any accountability. If we look back over history, there have been plenty of former Labor governments around Australia where there was evidence of wastage and mismanagement of money. We have a budget deficit projected at something like $14.75 billion, an overseas debt of $180 billion, and a Prime Minister heading this wasteful government whose buying of teak tables, Gould prints and the like certainly does not set a very good example, not just to ministers but throughout the whole of the Public Service.

PARA.TAB: This mismanagement and wastage of money is continually being exposed by the Auditor-General. Only this morning the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Mr George Gear, raised a matter that seemed to get under his skin—the fact that the tax office had spent some $60,000 on artworks in Melbourne when it could have leased the artworks from Artbank, which was set up by the government. As chairman of the coalition's Waste Watch Committee, I am criticised by government members for asking what seem to be useless questions. Sometimes we have to go up a few dry gullies to get a few answers. With the way the estimates committee system is operating at the moment, it is very difficult to get the answers we want, so we have to put a lot of questions on notice.

In the 20 minutes available to me today I would like to raise publicly some of the matters that have come to my attention, and people can make what they want of them. They are fairly good examples right across the board of the waste and mismanagement that has been going on in the 10 years of this Labor government. Only yesterday, during the training guarantee levy debate, there were comments from the Democrats and our side of politics about the perceived waste of the conferences that are being forced on government departments by the training guarantee levy. I have a long list of things here, and I will put out a proper summation of them.

I thought it might be of interest to honourable senators to hear examples of the ridiculous waste of taxpayers' money in conferences and so-called training, and the exotic resorts that people are going to. There have been three conferences at the Beachcomber Resort at Toukley in New South Wales for which participants have paid, on average, $411 per person, $820 per person and $424 per person. One conference at the Burnham Beeches Country House in Victoria, a well-known, very up-market place, cost $24,447 for 42 people, which worked out at $582 per person. The Hyatt Hotel at Coolum in Queensland was not a bad little effort, either. Nine people went to a conference there at a cost of $11,400, or, on average, $1,266 per person. The notorious Thredbo Alpine Hotel has hosted various conferences, averaging between $980 and $1056 per person, and so it goes on.

I have a foolscap page list of some of the resorts that have been used for these so-called conferences. They include the Nautilus resort at Coffs Harbour, the Beachcomber Resort at Toukley, the Aanuka Beach Resort at Coffs Harbour, the Byron Bay Beach Resort, the Sheraton Breakwater in Townsville, Magnetic Island, Kakadu, the Burnham Beeches Country House, the Hyatt Hotel Coolum, the Rottnest Lodge in Western Australia, the East Coaster Resort and the Diamond Island Resort in Tasmania. There are hundreds of these places being used for these so-called conferences. The amounts of money are staggering, and it is all taxpayers' money. It is all being used because of the training guarantee levy that was debated here yesterday. That debate highlighted the fact that even government members are aware of the criticisms. Bill Kelty has criticised this absolute waste of money.

Some of the practices going on in government departments seem to be quite ridiculous. For instance, only this week I found out that in Hobart the Commonwealth Employment Service decided to advertise 12 trainee employment officer positions. One would think that that would be a pretty simple process. There were 850 applications. The people deciding on the applicants drew up a short list of 209 and decided to swan around Tasmania interviewing the applicants. It cost something like $90,000. If this had been done in private enterprise, it would have cost about $20,000. That might be only a $70,000 saving, but it is an example of the waste that is going on right across Australia.

Recently the veterans' affairs department in Queensland decided that it had better do something about amenities for its staff. Let us face it, the staff have a lunch hour and perhaps a tea break in the morning and one in the afternoon. The department said, `We will buy them a $7,000 billiard table; it is taxpayers' money. What else can we do? We will buy $48,500 worth of executive furniture as well'. The social security department thought it should have a corporate wardrobe, so it spent the best part of half a million dollars on a corporate wardrobe. It spent $99,000 in devising the uniforms; another $150,000 in freighting them out and promotion costs; and a further $78,000 in 1991-92, $42,000 in 1993, and $42,000 in 1994 just to show the collection. It sounds like a fashion parade.
In the Senate Standing Committee on Publications recently, I raised the fact that the cost of annual reports by government departments went up $1 million in a year. That is quite outrageous.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are required by law to have them.

—Of course we have to have them. But why would we get an increase—and even the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Publications, Eric Fitzgibbon, raised the point—of $1 million in one year just on annual reports? We know we have to have them, but why do they have to go to the extent of all this glossy promotional material, using the best material available when half the reports come in 12 months after the financial year is finished and are of no use to anybody?

PARA.TAB: The Department of Social Security decided to send out a letter with a reply paid envelope in it, but the department forgot to send the reply paid envelope the first time and so had to do it again. That cost about $17,000. It might be only a small amount, but it shows the mistakes, rubbish and waste that is going on in the Public Service. In Parliament House, for instance, $21,000 was spent on refurbishing five-year-old chairs outside. For an extra $6,000 a whole set of new chairs could have been bought but, instead, $21,000 was spent on refurbishing the old ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —They saved $6,000.

—Why would they want to spend $5,800 on buying candle holders for Parliament House from the Philippines? What is wrong with buying Australian? The government is always crowing about buying Australian, yet the powers that be spend $5,800 on buying candle holders from the Philippines.
—You can argue that, but you can't argue waste watch when the government saves money.

—I would have thought that buying new facilities for a fraction of an increase would be better than trying to do up something that is five years old. Then, of course, we have this great rort that has been going on in the Public Service with credit cards. Need I remind the Senate of some of the amounts that were raised by public servants with their credit cards, running around the country clocking up bills? These bills included $50,000 in liquor stores; $1.7 million in wineries; $295,000 in cafes and restaurants; $22,000 in country clubs; and $28,000 in furriers and florists. One has to ask oneself, `Why the hell would they want to be using government credit cards and taxpayers' money for these sorts of purchases?'. They bought things such as outboard motors, caravans and boat hire. That matter is still being reviewed.
—And dancing lessons.

—That is right; dancing lessons. Surely this government has some idea of trying to look after money and controlling the purse strings, but it does not seem that that is happening. Let us look at the Auditor-General's department. During estimates—and Senator Vanstone is in the chamber; she would know this pretty well—we raised questions about a computer system the department has been tinkering around with for the last couple of years called LOIS. LOIS cost $17 1/2 million and now the department is going to replace it because it never worked in the first place—$17 1/2 million of taxpayers' money wasted. LOIS was an absolute failure.
—Are you sure it never happens in the private sector?

—Things do happen in the private sector, but if private sector companies waste $17 1/2 million they either sack the directors or they go broke—one or the other. In this case neither is happening. No-one seems to get sacked. A few people get demoted, but the Public Service keeps grinding on and wasting taxpayers' money. Why the devil would $400,000 be sent out in workers compensation payments to public servants who were not even sick? That is another example of waste; $400,000 was sent out in compensation payments to public servants who were not even sick.

PARA.TAB: A little item that took my eye one day was the $4,944 spent on sunlounges for a RAAF base in Darwin. The reason given in the answer was `to provide personnel from the RAAF base Darwin . . . who use the base swimming pool for fitness training and recreation, with facilities similar to those found in the wider community'. I thought $5,000 on 24 deck chairs was rather extravagant. But that does not surprise me. We go on and find that the Electoral Commission spent $21,000 handing out pens and rulers just to advertise itself. Honourable senators might remember the classic case of the other department—I think it was the Attorney-General's department—which spent $18,000 on mugs or something to celebrate the fact that it was going user-friendly.
