In Parliament House, $80,000 was spent putting up those flower boxes outside the main entrance to stop people driving their cars in. One has to ask: is it going to happen again? It seems that we have had an increase in the number of security staff around this place and it would be interesting to know just how much that is costing. I have been told it is costing something like $25,000 a day. We have Federal Police around the place. I understand another $150,000 will be spent on another 32 flower boxes. We will be surrounded by flower boxes. That is to keep cars and motor bikes out, I suspect.Recently in Canberra I noted that AIDAB decided to refurbish its offices. It needed to accommodate an extra 10 staff, and so it spent $170,000 refurbishing the place to accommodate 10 extra staff. It goes on.

I have another classic. A lot of the government departments like to advertise and promote themselves. DEET is no exception. In 1993 it put out a staff budget video—a 17-minute overview of the budget and its impact on the department. That cost $28,500. It starred Kim Beazley as the minister—he was the top actor in that production—and Warren Snowdon as the parliamentary secretary, plus a few other departmental staff. The department decided that it was so successful that it did it again. In 1991 it cost $23,000; in 1992 it cost $28,000. This was just to tell the department what a good job it had done with the budget.

The Department of Defence, apart from all the glasses with the Australian logo on, spent $4,800 on three gas barbeques at Garden Island. That reminds us of the money that was spent on the barbeques here some time ago which gained some international significance.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Gareth's gazebo?

—That is right. Another that took my fancy is that the National Museum of Australia spent $65,000 on finding out how to apply to the government for funding. I would have thought that a quick phone call to the local department would have done that. Some $59,000 was spent on a dog kennel for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in Brisbane. All I can say is that it must have been some dog kennel or a pretty savage dog!

PARA.TAB: The list goes on. I do not have the time to go through the whole list of conferences. I have come across many strange and interesting items in the Commonwealth Gazette and other publications the government has put out, examples of what may be a waste of money. The Australian Taxation Office is probably one of the big spenders on conferences. It had a three-day conference at Potts Point which cost $23,000, with an average cost of $509 per day per attendee. It is no wonder that Mr Gear in the other place was concerned today about the wastage of money on art works, when we see what appear to be other extravagances of the tax office. It dabbled in an `Effective Business Writing' course and produced 500 copies of a document at a cost of $20,800. So far, I am pleased to say, 100 copies have been used—but it seems an awful lot of money. I would have thought that people should know how to write effectively when they are employed.

Middle-management development programs seem to be getting more expensive every year. ATSIC is no slouch. It spent $82,000 in 1992-93 and another $50,000 in 1993-94 on middle-management development programs. It goes on. The conference bills are huge. Australian Archives decided to have a couple of days training at Batemans Bay, down the coast. It must have been very pleasant and it cost $40,000. The Department of Finance thought it would have a middle-management training conference at Thredbo. That cost $30,000.

All these figures point to one thing; that the actions of the members of this government, from the Prime Minister down, including Mrs Kelly and her whiteboard and all the rest, are further examples that the Labor Party has never been able to handle money. History shows that. Unfortunately, it is the taxpayers of Australia that are paying the penalty.

TALK.START.PARA: —The additional expenditures in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) and associated bills, after allowing for savings, amount to about $164 million. The opposition is not opposing these bills, as they are alterations to the original budget legislation. However, I want to bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that we in Australia have a very serious long-term economic crisis in front of us. There is far too much complacency by the government about the state of our economy.

PARA.TAB: In spite of the fact that economic growth is running significantly higher than the government forecast in its budget papers last year—it is currently running at about 3 1/2 per cent of GDP growth as opposed to the 2.75 per cent that was forecast—there is a major deficiency. There is a real investment strike in this country. The level of investment is at its lowest for 40 years and, for a subset of that—plant and equipment—at it lowest level, as a proportion of GDP, for 50 years.

The current recovery in the economy cannot be sustained unless there is a very substantial increase in investment in Australia. We need an investment boom and we are not yet seeing signs of getting it. The government has to change its attitude in order to encourage an investment boom. The Commonwealth budget for the 1993-94 financial year was really irresponsible in economic and fiscal terms. The Commonwealth has deliberately gone about increasing its borrowings, purely for consumption.

When everyone else around the country, state governments and businesses, were cutting costs in order to be internationally competitive, the Commonwealth government was increasing costs and taxes, and going for a very substantial increase in the deficit. Estimates are that Commonwealth borrowings—for the general government only—will rise from $50 billion at 30 June last year to $69 billion by 30 June this year. We did not need that pump priming.

The fact that the economy is growing faster than the government originally forecast goes to prove that there was no need for the pump priming. We as a community are saddled with the additional debt. The government has to reduce the deficit—and very quickly—and encourage savings. It is only through that route, with the Commonwealth government showing the lead, that there will be any chance of investment being encouraged and taking off. So the government has to show a reduced deficit and increased savings. It has to do that by cutting costs, not by increasing taxes.

As I said before, investment in Australia is at its lowest level for 40 years. The latest national accounts figures show that private sector investment has grown by a very modest 0.9 per cent in 1992-93. The difficulty for Australia is that, in order to get the investment needed for sustaining jobs in the longer term future, we need an increased investment of two per cent of GDP. That represents an additional $8 billion or $9 billion per year. We cannot do that unless the Commonwealth reduces its deficit and there is less pressure on interest rates. The private sector will then know that this government is serious about turning the economy around in the long term.

In principle, the opposition supports the government's objective of reducing the deficit in the long term; our concern is the speed with which that reduction is achieved. Because the economy is currently running at a much faster rate than anticipated by the government, there is a golden opportunity to do something about it—to reduce the deficit more quickly and for the government to aim for a surplus as quickly as possible.

The government has signalled through the media and through the paper it recently released that it is aiming for a deficit reduction of three per cent of GDP, which is the equivalent of about $12 billion or $13 billion. We believe that we should be aiming for a deficit closer to two per cent of GDP next financial year, with the difference made up by cutting costs, not by increasing taxes. That will send two major signals to investors internationally and here.

Firstly, it will significantly reduce the pressure on interest rates. Interest rates have been going up internationally, led by moves in the USA. There is pressure internationally for interest rates to go up again and long-term interest rates in this country have tended to edge up a bit also. To stop that process escalating, a reduction in the deficit, which will mean the community making additional savings, will send the right signals to the financial markets and keep interest rates low. That in turn will encourage investment in the economy, create jobs, and lead to future economic growth.

The second key direction is the cutting of costs. The Commonwealth government has done very little to cut its cost structure. The state governments have put a lot of effort over the last several years into cutting costs but the Commonwealth government has achieved very little in real terms. If the Commonwealth government is serious about encouraging investment in Australia in the near future, it must cut its own costs—showing the financial markets that it is serious about encouraging investment in this country—thereby reducing its deficit.

Investors do not have to invest in Australia. Australian companies and Australian individuals do not have to invest here anymore. They can send their savings anywhere around the world and in fact are doing so. Many major Australian companies are currently investing heavily offshore because they are receiving better opportunities there than here. We must turn that situation around. We cannot force people to invest here. We must change the investment climate to make it attractive for people to invest here. One of the keys to doing that is deficit reduction, which is in the hands of the Commonwealth government. The coalition is suggesting that deficit reduction next year should be closer to two per cent of GDP, not the three per cent which the Commonwealth is apparently targeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, before I start I draw attention to the fact that there is only one member of the Australian Labor Party here at present and not one minister. It is very difficult to make points to which one would hope a minister would respond when there is not a minister in the chamber. The deputy government whip, Senator Foreman, might wish to make responses on their behalf. Perhaps he is about to be promoted to the front bench—there are lots of vacancies there at the moment. The Senate should be appalled by the fact that for these very important appropriation bills not one minister is in the chamber. That is a disgrace. It is a reflection of this government's absolute contempt for the parliament and its clear contempt for the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I wanted to respond to some remarks made by Senator McKiernan in relation to these appropriation bills. He made a couple of threats against opposition members about playing hardball politics, particularly in relation to Western Australia. I want to record the fact that I will be supporting remarks I made on the adjournment debate about the former Western Australian premier, Carmen Lawrence, and her hand in and knowledge of the tabling in the Western Australian parliament of a petition by the now leader of the opposition in the upper house, Mr John Halden MLC, which was the cause in part of the suicide of Penelope Easton shortly thereafter. I will be tackling that issue in the debate on the adjournment this evening.

Senator McKiernan knows the Family Law Act better than many of us and he knows the pressures and pains it can put on families. I am sure that if Senator McKiernan had knowledge of what John Halden MLC was going to do in tabling that petition he would not have had a bar of it. I know Senator McKiernan well: he is a man who, with his knowledge, would not have allowed that to happen.

The important thing that I want to talk about at this stage in relation to the appropriation bills is Senator McKiernan's throwaway line about the sale of schools. I presume he was referring to Victoria but I was only partially listening to him. That invites comparison of the record of the Australian Labor Party's financial management—or mismanagement—with that of the coalition parties.

Mr Acting Deputy President, in your home state of Victoria we saw the government ignominiously thrown out by the voters of Victoria. We saw the same thing in Western Australia when the government of Dr Carmen Lawrence was thrown out for gross financial mismanagement. We have seen it occur around Australia—and it will occur again when the Australian people next have an opportunity to vote in a federal election. I will continue my remarks when the Senate resumes after the suspension at 12.45 p.m.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—For your information, the Senate cannot adjourn at 12.45 p.m. because there is no minister in the chamber. You can continue your remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then I will continue to address this issue of financial mismanagement. The issue is looming in Western Australia because of a nasty leak from the education department of a list of 64 schools, the subject of review by the Hon. Norman Moore, the Western Australian Minister for Education. I had a long chat with the president of the parents and friends association of the Coolbellup Primary School this morning. He was very worried, as are many people associated with schools on this list, about the future of his school. Those people have a right to be concerned.

PARA.TAB: Their concerns result not only from the crass leaking of that document but also because Dr Carmen Lawrence—a former education minister who should understand these issues better than anyone else—was unable during her period of government to give any reassurance to any of these schools. Coolbellup Primary School is an example of a school that has had a cloud hanging over it—to use the words of Evelyn Walker, to whom I spoke this morning—for a number of years. Carmen Lawrence has been unable to tell people why, in the years when she was the education minister and premier, she was unable to give them any reassurance.

The important issue here is not that of the rationalisation of schools and the delivery of better education—that is certainly not the issue in the mind of the Australian Labor Party. Michelle Roberts, the Labor Party candidate for the Glendalough by-election, has used this list of schools, leaked by a Labor Party apparatchik within the education department, for base, crass political purposes. While it suits the Western Australian Labor Party to go around scaring parents and citizens by using this internal document for crass political purposes, it does not help in the process of delivering better education services or, as Senator McKiernan said, services to the community.

The Labor Party in Western Australia failed in its financial management of that state. It failed to deliver educational services to the students of Western Australia. However, the present education minister, Norman Frederick Moore, is going through a sensible process, involving consultation at the community level over a period of months, to ensure that the people of Perth and across all Western Australia are delivered the very best standard of education that the state can offer. They will be much better educational standards than were set under the total mismanagement of the Labor government of Dr Carmen Lawrence—the government so ignominiously defeated just over 12 months ago.

The important thing to remember with this school closures issue in Western Australia, which Senator McKiernan raised by reference to the advertisement in the papers this morning, is that the process of ensuring adequate educational standards and proper economic management requires a sensible and constructive approach. The use of this issue by Dr Carmen Lawrence—who should know better, having been an educator and a minister for education—is an example of the depths to which she will stoop. She has gone around to parents and friends associations, scaremongering for crass political purposes. Her scaremongering will not help—in fact it hinders—the delivery of educational services in Western Australia.

If Dr Lawrence was someone with principles and a commitment to serving the people of Australia—Western Australia in particular—she would not use this information for crass political purposes. It is a very sad reflection on the way in which the Australian Labor Party will play the game. It will do or say anything to gain power. The important thing to remember is that Norman Moore, as the Minister for Education—

TALK.START.PARA: —And doing a good job.

—He is doing an excellent job. He is someone who has been committed to education all his life. He was a teacher initially and rose to the rank of principal. He has been a shadow minister for education for most of the last 10 years. He has developed educational policies at the state level and has also assisted at the federal level through consultation with federal ministers for almost all of the last 11 years that we have been in opposition. His wife Leigh—a good friend of mine as well—is also a school principal. They are both so committed to education. Education is Norman Moore's life's work. I can reassure people in schools like Coolbellup and Osborne Park that the ultimate commitment of that minister, regardless of this disgraceful leak from within his own department, is to ensuring that the educational standards of children at all those schools are enhanced and that they have the very best opportunities in life.

PARA.TAB: I urge all who are concerned about the disgusting politics being played by people such as Dr Lawrence, Michelle Roberts, the head of the teachers union and all the other Labor lackeys, to remember the way in which they have used this issue as a political weapon when it comes to the forthcoming by-elections. I hope that people will listen to the rational and sensible arguments put by Norman Moore and the coalition parties and not be the victims of yet another disgusting and disgraceful Labor Party scare campaign.
Debate (on motion by Senator Schacht) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Richardson is still unwell and will be absent from question time today. Questions relating to the health portfolio should be addressed to Senator Crowley, who also represents the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services. Questions relating to the environment, sport and territories portfolio should be addressed to Senator Faulkner.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the massive capital gain that the Prime Minister made when, in April 1992, Mr Keating's half-owned company, Belesdan Ltd, bought land at Parkville for $120,000 and, just three months later, sold it for $350,000 to a Danish owned company, Danmeat Pty Ltd. As this represents a capital profit of almost a quarter of a million dollars in just three months, can the minister explain how the value of this land could have almost trebled in only 90 days? Was this profit declared on any ministerial register and was tax paid on it?

—That is a matter between the Prime Minister and the Commissioner of Taxation—the proper valuation of returns on these sorts of things. I have no information about that, nor do I propose to seek it, in the absence of any credible basis being advanced by Senator Baume about any conceivable conflict between public duty and private interest.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will give some credible background so that the minister can more effectively answer the question. Despite selling the land for a profit of $230,000 in July 1992, this week's annual return of the Prime Minister's half-owned company, Belesdan Ltd, for the year to 30 June 1993—which covers that period—discloses a profit of only $19,686. If the company's tax bill is based on its reported profit of only $19,000-odd, how did it cut more than $210,000 off its profit on this land sale and so minimise its tax liability by about $80,000?
—I have nothing to add to my previous answer. It may be the tax commissioner's business but it is not Senator Baume's.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to reports in this morning's press which indicate that there has been a dramatic rise in vacancies for skilled jobs, taking those vacancies to the highest levels since 1990. Is the minister able to provide the Senate with any further information relating to those vacancies? In particular, what details are available on the skilled vacancy survey referred to in the press reports?

—This is a good news story, part of the many good news stories coming with the growth in the economy. I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that the job market is the strongest it has been for many years. The Department of Employment, Education and Training skilled vacancy survey for February shows that the skilled job vacancy index is at its highest level since August 1990. Skilled vacancies rose by three per cent during January, taking the total rise over the last year to 60 per cent. Vacancies have grown in all states over the year. I am sure Senator Colston will be pleased to know that in his state of Queensland skilled vacancies are up by 66 per cent over the year. Overall, during January, 11 occupational groups reported increases in advertised vacancies. These included: vehicle trades, up by 10 per cent; natural scientists, up by six per cent; business professionals, up by five per cent; electrical and electronic trades, up by four per cent; food trades, up by four per cent; and engineers, up by three per cent. That is just for the one month of January.
—Coalition down by 10 per cent.
—And the coalition down by 10 per cent as a result. I suppose the only job vacancy that did not show up in the survey was the one for the Liberal Party leadership.
—Pitiful.

—I agree with Senator Hill that the Liberal Party leadership in this parliament is pitiful. Senator Hill described it very well; it is nothing other than pitiful. In the broader occupational areas, since February of last year the metal trades are up 161 per cent, building trades are up 119 per cent and food trades are up 83 per cent.
—How about those people you regard as boring?

—All occupational groups are at least 30 per cent above their recession low point, and the continued growth in skill vacancy provides further evidence that the recovery is certainly well under way, much to the disappointment of Senator Kemp. Of course, this growth in vacancies is flowing right through the labour market. It also reinforces results from the ANZ Bank and the Australian Bureau of Statistics series, which results are both up around 30 per cent. Again, I reiterate that this good news is very disappointing to the opposition.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Now that the Prime Minister has been reported in yesterday's Herald Sun to be holding the portfolio of Minister for the Status of Women open until he gets `a better person', in the unlikely event of Labor winning the Fremantle by-election, will the minister give an undertaking that this portfolio will not be given to the former failed Premier of Western Australia, Dr Carmen Lawrence?

—I do not accept that the former Premier of Western Australia is a failed premier. On the contrary, she was a premier of great distinction, great style, great intelligence and great charm—all of which is lacking in the present leadership of Senator Panizza's state and indeed elsewhere around the country where the Liberal Party has had anything to do with government. I will make no such undertaking; that is a matter for the Prime Minister.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is obvious that that is what the Prime Minister is thinking of doing. How can the government consider Dr Lawrence having responsibility for the status of women? How can the government justify even thinking of such a move, given that Dr Lawrence had ministerial responsibility for the Women's Information and Referral Exchange, which helped to separate scores of single women from their life savings by urging investment with the Western Women's finance group before it collapsed?

—I will not respond to that sort of sleaze from Senator Panizza. He ought to have a little more grace and distinction than to start plumbing around with that sort of question on this sort of occasion. I know that it is a by-election but Senator Panizza ought to lift his game and do better than that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Can the minister confirm the correctness of media reports that former Senator and candidate for the Mackellar by-election, Mrs Bronwyn Bishop, has flagrantly flouted the rules regarding the entitlements of her former staff and the use of her parliamentary and electoral offices?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right.
—There does seem to be a bit of a concern about what might emerge with regard to this point. I wish to say that there does seem to be—

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That question was asked from the government side. I would have thought government senators would want to listen to the answer.
—It does seem to be the case that former Senator Bishop's final duty as senator for New South Wales was to sack all her staff. When staff are terminated—
—I rise on a point of order. Would the minister indicate whether that knowledge was peculiarly within the department and was therefore leaked by the government?
—There is no point of order.
—The point is not that, but that the facts are accurate.
—So you do not deny it, do you?

—I just ignore it, because it is irrelevant. The really important question is that this is not a legitimate case in which these people receive severance payment because their employment has been genuinely terminated. The people themselves have said that they expect to be re-employed by Mrs Bishop when she is re-elected. So if one conspires to get somebody a severance payment in the knowledge that one will re-employ those people within a matter of weeks, it is a rort—r-o-r-t rort. There is no doubt about it. But that is not the end of the story, and in my view, it is in no way the worst part of the story. As a consequence of people being sacked, they lose rights of access to their office.

PARA.TAB: When senators finish their term of office they do not have to sack their staff. They can, if they really want to serve their constituents—as most senators do—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. Mr President, I seek your clarification as to whether it is appropriate for a senator who used his own parliamentary office and resources for non-parliamentary purposes a few years ago in association with the government's propaganda campaign called `price watch', to comment on the propriety or otherwise of any other senator.
—I do not understand your point of order. I cannot see a point of order there.

—There is no point of order, but there is a point. The point is that members of the opposition are feeling very sensitive about this, and they should, because the taxpayer-funded offices in this building and in Parramatta have been used by Mrs Bishop, without any legal entitlement to use them, explicitly for the purpose of conducting the campaign in Mackellar. It is now becoming clear why Mrs Bishop sought to present herself as—

—I rise on a point of order. Mr President, I have a letter in my hand signed by John Dawkins on his letterhead, supporting Carmen Lawrence in her election to Fremantle. Does that come under the same matter?
—Order! There is no point of order, and you know full well there is no point of order, Senator Kemp.

—If people want to talk about misuse of letters in Fremantle, there are a few senators in here I could talk about, but I will not—and they are all on that side. It is now clear why Mrs Bishop sought to project herself as the taxpayers' friend in here; she wanted the taxpayers to fund her campaign for Mackellar, as they have been funding her campaign against Dr Hewson.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the government seek to recover the money? As Mrs Bishop is now a private citizen, can she be summonsed before estimates committees?

—I do not think that any money has been gained by the staff to which they are not legally entitled, although there may be a profound moral obligation on them to repay the money if they are re-employed as quickly as is proposed. As to whether citizens should be called before Senate committees and cross-examined for their actions as private citizens with the taxpayers' money, that is a matter that Torquemada over there and some of the others know more about than I, but I think it would be a very interesting matter to watch.
—The bottom line is that she is a two-faced hypocrite.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a distinguished visitor, former Senator Olsen from South Australia. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you back to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a point of order. May I ask you whether `two-faced hypocrite' is unparliamentary? If so, could you ask Senator Collins to withdraw it, please?
—I did not hear what Senator Collins said but, if he said something offensive, I ask him to withdraw it.

—The reference I made to a two-faced hypocrite was a direct reference to Mrs Bishop. She is no longer a member of this chamber and I can call her what I like. I might add in conclusion that, having sat through hours and hours of estimates committees with the former Senator Bishop on this very point, she is a two-faced hypocrite.
—Order! I think that sort of language does not assist the dignity of the chamber, and I would ask you to withdraw it anyway.

—Mr President, on a point of order: it is important to appreciate that whatever you think about the dignity of the language, it is not inappropriate or unparliamentary to use such language of a person who is not a member of the parliament. I ask you to consider carefully that ruling because it cuts a swathe through a lot of free debate in this place.

—I must say that I would not mind cutting a swathe through a lot of the level of debate in this chamber because I regard a lot of the language that is used, even though it is considered parliamentary, as being quite inappropriate. I would still ask Senator Collins to withdraw, if he will, in the interests of Senate harmony.
—Mr President, I do not place any condition on my withdrawal. You have asked for it and I give it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. It relates to Senator Richardson's package of private health insurance reforms. How does the minister justify the expenditure of an additional $9 1/2 million in this financial year to fund Senator Richardson's private health insurance package when the package has not been approved by caucus, cabinet or either house of parliament? How does the minister justify the additional expenditure to the many organisations which have, in good faith, made detailed submissions about the reform package on the understanding that it was genuinely open to discussion and considerable change? Finally, since this is surely a substantial waste of money, could not this money have been better used in other sections of the health budget, for example, in the public hospital system or in community health centres?

—Senator Lees' question raises two areas of concern for me and they are matters of fact and matters of opinion for the Minister for Health. I think it would be more appropriate if I referred that question to Senator Richardson.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the minister is reluctant to answer the substance of the question, I go back to the principle. Surely the basic principle is that governments should not spend millions of dollars before the measures it is planning to implement have been before parliament or, in this case, before the government. Is there not a basic underlying principle there? Can I please have a comment?
—As I said, this matter is appropriately addressed to Minister Richardson, and I will see that that happens.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the minister aware of the reported sacking of a Canberra woman by a motel manager because she suffers from epilepsy? Is such a dismissal unlawful under the Disability Discrimination Act? What action can this employee and others in a similar position take to overturn such a decision? Is it a fact that the community remains largely unaware of the unique problems faced by people with disabilities?

—It is quite unfortunate that there has been a development in Australian politics such that serious issues of the kind that Senator Zakharov raises can be raised in this place but cannot be addressed by the opposition in any sane, rational way. The opposition has to put some political slant or slur on it.

PARA.TAB: This afternoon Senator Zakharov has raised an issue which is important. It relates to the employment opportunities of those with disabilities. I am aware of those press reports, and I am aware of the particular case, but of course I cannot give an assessment of that particular case.

However, I can say that the government's Disability Discrimination Act came into force just one year ago. It was designed to make discrimination against people with a disability unlawful in a number of areas. Amongst those areas was the area of employment. The definition of disability in the act is broad and I believe it would cover conditions such as epilepsy. The act, of course, applies throughout Australia. Complaints can be lodged with the Disability Discrimination Commissioner through the nearest office of HREOC, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

In respect of the second part of Senator Zakharov's question, regarding community awareness of this issue, I think it is fair to say that the question of general community awareness of disability issues, the problems of those with disabilities and the capacity of those with disabilities, is very low. Many Australians still do not understand the special problems that people with disabilities face, not only in their normal lives but also in exercising their rights under the Disability Discrimination Act.

As an integral part of trying to remedy this particular problem, the Attorney-General and the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services have just announced cabinet's approval for the development of the Australian disability strategy and an associated awareness campaign for the general community.

The government's aim through this program is that we will develop a framework of policies, programs, practices and procedures to improve the equality of opportunity for people with disabilities. The emphasis of this strategy will be on, increasingly, respect for fundamental human rights. On Tuesday of this week both ministers launched the national awareness campaign on what was the first anniversary of the Disability Discrimination Act.

It is the intention of the government that the focus of this campaign will be on the disabled seeking employment opportunities in both the government and the private sector and will encourage the notion that people with disabilities should be seen for what they can do, rather than what they cannot.

As well as the awareness campaign, the strategy I talked about earlier is geared towards establishing a 10-year program by the end of this year. The program will have a timetable for achieving national equal opportunity goals covering a host of areas including citizenship, education, employment, income security, telecommunications and the built environment.

The first part of the question related to the Disability Discrimination Act, and the government sees it as a fundamental role in all of our strategies for that act to ensure that people have not only rights but also the capacity to pursue them. Consequentially, we are setting up specialist legal centres in each state and territory in support of that act.

In conclusion, the government also recognises the role state and territory government can have in terms of pursuing the overall framework of strategies. We will be discussing with those states and territories the goals of the national strategy and its application to their functions and responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health: in view of another report's damning picture of the federal government's lack of ethnic health policies—I refer to the report of the Ethnic Communities' Council Queensland report Health Services in a Multicultural Queensland—a Silent Crisis—when is the government going to seriously tackle some of the major problems related to ethnic health and ethnic health services in this country? When is the government going to ensure that non-English speaking background patients have adequate access to interpreters? What are you doing to ensure that there is cultural awareness among hospital staff?

—The detail of that question would have to be referred to Senator Richardson. I do not know the report Senator Knowles is referring to and I have not found any reference to it, which is not to say it is not there. But, it is a matter I should refer to Senator Richardson. I can say that in my area of responsibility for women's health the question of delivering adequate services to women from non-English speaking backgrounds is not only a new priority but has been a priority of the national women's health program since it was established by this government. The program is cost shared with the states. One of the large priority areas is access for women from non-English speaking backgrounds to health services. In the large part, the program does not address the question of hospitals. That is a large part of what Senator Knowles asked, particularly as to the interpreter services, so I will refer that part of the question to Senator Richardson.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the minister referring the finer detail to Senator Richardson but I cannot understand why Senator Crowley would not know of these reports. As to people from non-English speaking backgrounds, the federal government has said that it proposes to consider a whole range of things in many of these reports. One report that has been around for some time is on women's issues for those from non-English speaking backgrounds. Surely there is a possibility that we will be able to get some answer out of Senator Crowley as to when the government is actually going to tackle these things and not simply consider the issues that are, once again, raised in this report today.

—I have just said that in the area of my responsibility, the national women's health program, we are delivering that service and addressing those questions right now; it is one of the seven priority areas for funding under that program. It has been receiving that funding for a variety of projects to address exactly the sorts of problems that Senator Knowles is alluding to. Quite clearly there is still an unmet demand in the community for some further services for women from non-English speaking backgrounds. We are funding those services—they are a priority. I certainly do not think that the comments of Senator Knowles about the national women's health program are entirely valid.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Can the minister advise what initiatives have been developed to support the efforts being made by Australian companies to capture a portion of the considerable projected increase in the Asian demand for processed food?

—As Senator Schacht has said, this is another important area where there are stories to be told about Australian economic success in the creation of jobs. Our processed food producers are the most significant manufacturing activity in Australia and employ over 170,000 people. They have traditionally been fundamentally focused on the domestic market for sales growth, but the government and the industry have been working together to encourage manufacturers to increasingly turn to exports. It is estimated that the Asian import market for processed food is now running at more than $US50 billion a year. Australia's geography, agricultural industry and reputation for clean and sophisticated products place us in a prime position to meet this very big and rapidly growing demand in our region, and it gives us the potential to create exports and jobs for Australians.

PARA.TAB: A growing number of our food producers are building solid export businesses in Asia. They are developing long-term plans, building sales, and meeting the tastes of the increasingly affluent middle classes there. The government has developed a successful agri-food strategy and that is providing the framework within which government and industry are working together on this important question. The industry has set itself a target of increasing its high, value added food export products from $2.3 billion to about $7 billion by the turn of the century. If that tripling does take place, then thousands of jobs will follow. There is a very important role for Austrade in this trade promotion area. I think the industry acknowledges that it is performing very actively and effectively. It has initiated a program of joint action groups working with smaller processed food companies to develop their export capacity to enhance that of the bigger companies.

The processed food exporters are also achieving better access to overseas markets through the various government assistance programs such as the export market development, the international trade enhancement scheme, and the innovative agricultural marketing program; and marketing programs are being developed for dairy, processed cereals, wine, seafood and horticulture.

The other issue where the government can be of assistance, because the primary responsibility for this lies with the companies themselves, is in reducing barriers faced by our exports. Significant gains were made in the Uruguay round. For example, seafood exports to Japan, which are already worth over $280 million, should benefit from significant tariff cuts achieved there. Dairy exports, which have already passed the $1 billion mark, with the gains made in the Uruguay round can be expected to increase further. We are also working bilaterally to reduce barriers to market access in Asian markets. There is a processed food market access committee, chaired by my department, which coordinates much of this effort.

There is very significant opportunity here for Australians, and I and other ministers will be working with the industry to use every opportunity to win better access for Australian processed food exports because it is good for our trade figures. But, most importantly, it is good in Australia for building economic growth on a sustainable basis that will mean more jobs for Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to last Friday's COAG meeting that adopted many proposals in the Hilmer report. I ask: what recommendations relating to agricultural marketing arrangements have been adopted and what is the timetable for any such changes? What effect will this have on agricultural marketing arrangements established under state legislation and on Commonwealth statutory marketing arrangements?

—The Hilmer recommendations represent a framework and processes for micro-economic reform through the application of competition policies, as Senator Boswell would be aware. The report makes no recommendations specifically relating to agriculture.

PARA.TAB: The Council of Australian Governments agreed to the competition policy principles articulated in the Hilmer report: universal application of trade practices legislation; establishment of the Australian competition commission; and national competition legislation to be considered at its next meeting in August.

The trade practices legislation currently applies to the vast majority of commerce in Australia. However, it was recognised that its application to the remaining sectors of the economy may require changes to some existing state and territory regulatory arrangements and business practices. A two-year transitional period was recommended by the Hilmer report and COAG officials will explore options for allowing a longer period for particular arrangements on a case by case basis.

As for agricultural marketing bodies, they are not exempt from the Trade Practices Act at present, unless they are unincorporated, only operate intrastate or their conduct is authorised by other legislation. There is no inherent reason why agriculture should be singled out for special treatment. The Commonwealth and most states have been improving the structure of marketing authorities and examining them against public benefit tests in a way that they will be under the Hilmer framework, and that process will continue.

Many marketing arrangements will be unaffected by the application of competition law. However, if states believe some agricultural marketing arrangements should continue to be exempt from this legislation, they can pass specific legislation to remove such arrangements from its coverage. In other cases, such arrangements can be authorised through the normal process managed by the Trade Practices Commission. The commission will, of course, authorise anti-competitive arrangements where some net public benefit can be demonstrated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the government guarantee that these reforms in electricity, water and gas will not result in higher costs to country areas of Australia? Has the government done calculations on any cost increases in rural areas?

—So far as electricity and gas are concerned, the decisions made at the COAG meeting last Friday will result in competitive markets. I am sure the prices will be lower than would otherwise have been the case for consumers of electricity and gas in the absence of the competitive frameworks thus agreed upon.

PARA.TAB: As far as water is concerned, if people in country areas want existing supply systems to be maintained then, in the absence of continuing government subsidies, it is the case that prices generally will have to increase. The extent of any increase will vary from irrigation scheme to irrigation scheme, but increases will be phased in over seven years.

It should also be noted that the heads of government agreed to a package of water reforms, the implementation of tradeable water entitlements and the devolution of responsibility for service delivery which should, of course, benefit rural water consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories—or whoever happens to be representing him. The Australian Heritage Commission is due to enter a number of areas in Western Australia into the Register of the National Estate. First, will the minister please inform me which areas will be entered onto the interim list and which areas were initially identified for nomination following the CALM-AHC regional assessment and subsequently deleted, withdrawn or deferred—and for what reason? Second, how many of the areas to be entered onto the interim list have values that are sensitive to logging and how many areas can be subject to logging operations? Third, how many hectares of the total area to be listed can be subject to logging operations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette has asked a very complex and detailed question. Obviously it will take a considerable amount of work from the AHC to answer it. However, the Australian Heritage Commission has informed me that similar questions have been put to it directly from the Western Australian Conservation Council and the statistics there will be collated as soon as possible. I would suggest that the information I can give to the honourable senator today would be at best only an interim response.

PARA.TAB: The CALM-AHC regional assessment process has identified 40 major areas and 35 rare and endemic plant sites in the region. This will be entered into the interim list of the register of the national estate on Tuesday, 8 March. Similar areas already in the register will also be removed because they do not have national estate values. All these proposed listings and de-listings are subject to the consideration of any objections. The draft report from the assessment process was published in February 1992, and released for public comment. The initial comment period of three months was extended to six months in response to requests from conservation groups, including the Western Australian Conservation Council.

The final listing decisions have been based on submissions, additional information and a review of the regional data. The final report is scheduled for release in April 1994. This report will outline reasons for the boundaries to be used in the 8 March gazettal. Many of the areas to be listed contain areas that are sensitive to logging. The AHC—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just give it to Hansard.
—Some people are interested in this. The AHC is preparing a more detailed response on this matter. Decisions about which areas will be logged are the jurisdiction of the state government.

PARA.TAB: The federal resource minister has the responsibility in relation to national estate places through export licences. The commission has provided advice to the resource minister on the impact of harvesting on the national estate and this advice has been publicly released. The commission has no direct information on which areas can be subject to logging operations. It will provide details on hectares within the resource system and any other CALM tenures.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the minister aware that the Department of Administrative Services has entered the private sector training market by advertising for public enrolments in its staff development and information technology courses? Can the minister advise whether this practice of DAS actively competing against the private sector training facilitators is to occur Australia wide? Has the minister received any complaints about this new foray? Does the minister consider it appropriate for a taxpayer-funded organisation to compete against private operators who provide jobs for thousands of Australians? Does the minister accept that this will adversely affect existing training providers? Is the government prepared to accept responsibility for the many job losses and closures which will inevitably occur unless this practice is stopped?

—It always strikes me as amazing that people think that training or other functions discharged by people working for the government do not employ anybody and that, somehow or other, if the work is done by the public sector in the private sector it is going to cost lots of jobs. Yet, next, people say that the Public Service is inefficient and that it takes a lot more people in the public sector to do the same job that the private sector could do more efficiently. Both arguments cannot be right. I am not concerned about the last part of Senator Calvert's question. I was not aware that the department was engaging in that practice.

PARA.TAB: The general situation that applies, and should apply, with regard to the Department of Administrative Services when it competes with the private sector is the principle of competitive neutrality, which was endorsed by Hilmer, which I endorse and which I wish the states would endorse, because then the functions of the Department of Administrative Services would be able to compete effectively for that market. We continue to require the department to operate on those principles. I expect that in this circumstance it will, and, if it does not, I would seek to make sure that it does. It is impossible to sustain the argument which Senator Calvert used to underpin the question. I will find out the facts of the circumstance and advise him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. In view of the success of the Australian fast ferry industry in world export markets, can the minister outline how the government assesses the prospects for this industry, particularly in relation to Asia-Pacific markets?

—I am grateful for this question because it enables me to join in the theme first articulated in question time today by Senator Schacht, and later by Senator McMullan, that there is a good news story here. Australia has taken a world technological lead by applying aerospace technology to water transport and evolving the most highly competitive means of waterborne mass transport with the aluminium catamaran fast ferry.

PARA.TAB: The government has supported the industry. The success of the fast ferry shipyards in Australia testifies to the effectiveness of the Australian government's outward looking industry policy in this sector. I will cite honourable senators a few facts. In 1989 the Australian government introduced new bounty arrangements for the shipbuilding industry, including fast ferries for export. Recently the government extended the bounty to 1997 but provided a phasing down from nine per cent to five per cent by 1 July 1996.

This industry goes from strength to strength. It has nearly quadrupled its export earnings in the space of four years. Exports grew from just over $100 million in 1988-89 to an estimated $425 million in the year 1993-94. On current trends it is reliably estimated that the industry could earn $550 million in the next financial year.

Western Australian shipyards have been a strong element in this export thrust, and the port city of Fremantle deserves a special mention in this case. Austal, an enterprising shipyard in Fremantle, is an outstanding example of this export drive by its effort to penetrate the lucrative but daunting China market. Over the past five years, Austal has delivered 22 aluminium ferries to China, worth over $150 million, most of which have been destined for the south China market.

Accepting China's determination to develop its own high-speed aluminium ferry building industry, Austal is on the threshold of finalising a joint venture agreement with Zhou Jai Du shipyards in Shanghai to produce catamarans using Austal's less sophisticated technology. Thus the joint venture will not diminish Austal's position in south China but will position it for the east China market, which is burgeoning.

This joint venture is a good example of the government's policy of encouraging stronger integration of Australian and Chinese industries, as enunciated by the Prime Minister and me in our most recent visits to the People's Republic of China. It will mean that 20 to 40 Chinese technicians will be trained at Austal shipyards to ensure that the joint venture will produce quality ferries. Austal's confidence is reflected in the expansion of its capacity in Jervoise Bay, just south of Fremantle, to produce larger ferries. The company is expected to increase its work force from 250 at present to 350 to 400 in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer to the adviser's position in DITARD to which the discredited former head of Customs, Mr Frank Kelly, has been appointed. I also refer to the joint statement released by APEC ministers on 20 November last year, establishing the APEC committee on trade and investment and stating that the committee, which will look at a variety of trade liberalisation issues, including customs harmonisation, will be composed of member country policy level officials responsible for trade and economic affairs. Will Mr Frank Kelly be a member of this committee or attend any of these meetings as a representative of the Australian government?

—I do not know the answer to that question, although I am pleased that the degree of detail provided in the question verifies all the things that I have said about APEC—the importance of customs harmonisation, the responsible duties that a senior Australian Customs official has to observe, and the importance of achieving mutual recognition of customs and other regulations.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what arrangements my department has made to be represented on the committee and whether it will be a job for Mr Kelly or some other senior official of the department. Nor do I make those decisions. They are decisions made by the departmental secretary. I am sure when they are made, if they have not been made at this point, we will be pleased to see a very senior and important figure from our department represent Australia's interests on this very important international body.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister please try to seek the information, particularly relating to the last part of the question? Given that Mr Kelly's outrageous remuneration package, comprising of $126,760 in salary and $50,445 in allowances, includes a component for international spouse travel, can the minister advise the Senate that if this international spouse travel does not relate to Mr Kelly's membership of this APEC committee, why will Mr Kelly be travelling overseas and why does his spouse need to accompany him at taxpayers' expense? How much of the $50,445 is allocated for international spouse travel? Given the findings of the Conroy report, is there no-one else available to do this job who is not tainted by the Midford Paramount scandal?

—Very highly emotionally charged words were used in that question. What should be remembered is that those words reflect on a responsible officer of the Commonwealth, the Public Service Commissioner, who made the determination as to what level of remuneration Mr Kelly should receive. On behalf of the government, I want to say that that is a despicable attack upon the integrity of the Public Service Commissioner and this Senate should not countenance it. The Senate should reject that sort of inflammatory language.

PARA.TAB: The Public Service Commissioner made a determination which sets the salary for this adviser at the level of that of a departmental secretary. All the rights and entitlements that the adviser will receive are equivalent to that level of officer. I do not know what the details are about spouse travel, but if a person is to spend a lot of time overseas representing this country, then family reunion arrangements or family travel arrangements are clearly entitlements that have to be considered by a responsible government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Last week the Queensland government passed legislation to acquire the Starcke wilderness area from the now notorious developer George Quaid to prevent overseas sale and, supposedly, to prevent inappropriate development. This was a welcome move. Yesterday the Cape York Land Council and environment groups released a management plan which would return 30 per cent of the southern Starcke area to Aboriginal ownership and see the remaining 70 per cent gazetted as a national park. Is the minister aware that the Queensland government is considering setting aside a mining reserve of 10,000 hectares between the mountainous Starcke National Park and the sensitive mangrove wetlands to the east, a development that could hardly be described as appropriate and which has extremely upset the traditional owners and is also strongly opposed by the environment groups? Is the minister prepared to offer Commonwealth funds to buy out the current exploration permit held by Starcke Gold Pty Ltd, which is a $100 Liberian shelf company?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. We have just had an example in the last three questions—I am picking on Senator Kernot here—of questioners preceding their questions with words about individuals such as `discredited', `notorious' and all the rest of it. It is really seeking to put a prejudgment into the question. Mr President, will you look at that on the basis that you set a new standard today by asking Senator Collins to withdraw his interjection?
—I am happy to look at it and give a considered response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the recent press reports that indicate the Queensland government is considering proposals for the Starcke area which could see a part of its zone allow for resource use. I have been advised that negotiations on the purchase arrangements are continuing with the Queensland government and the traditional owners. There are a number of details to be determined before acquisition can proceed, including the area to be acquired, the price, the terms of any funding arrangements and, particularly, arrangements for future management.

PARA.TAB: The purchase will not proceed if acceptable management arrangements cannot be developed which protect the conservation and indigenous values of this area. I believe that last year Mrs Kelly announced that the environment portfolio would contribute up to $1 million towards the cost of acquisition, provided satisfactory arrangements could be negotiated.

In relation to the last part of Senator Kernot's question, obviously I am not in a position to be able to make a commitment on behalf of Senator Richardson in relation to any offer of Commonwealth funds, as I am sure she would appreciate. That part of her question should more properly be referred to Senator Richardson for his consideration on his return, and I will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Firstly, what action is the government taking in relation to the continuing coal strike? This strike will cost New South Wales and Queensland coal producers $170 million in lost production if it extends beyond this week. Combine this with the damaging waterfront dispute and the only loser is Australia's trade reputation. Secondly, when will the government outline its mooted plan to reform the Coal Industry Tribunal?

—Over a number of weeks my colleague the Minister for Resources has been having wide-ranging discussions with employers, unions and the relevant state governments—that is, the governments of New South Wales and Queensland—about the best way to proceed to set up the industry for the future, to canvass all the issues that Senator Macdonald has raised and, of course, the particular issue of concern to the unions, which was the significant reduction recently made in the price for that particular contract for coal. The minister has announced that he will convene a special meeting of the Australian Coal Industry Council, the industry's key consultative body, with senior representation from the Commonwealth, the New South Wales and Queensland state governments, the companies and the unions, to discuss all of these issues on 14 March.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Recently, the New South Wales health minister was reported as announcing that $18 million would be spent this year on the breast cancer mammographic screening program across the state. As this is a joint federal-state national program, is the minister able to advise what the federal contribution is and what the progress of the program is in New South Wales?

—I am interested in the figures that Senator West referred to. She passed me a copy of the press release. It does refer to the government spending $18 million in New South Wales. It is a bit of a worry for me because I have been advised that the Commonwealth government will spend $18.6 million in New South Wales and the New South Wales government will spend $14 million. So that figure either refers to the Commonwealth contribution or it is insufficient because it is inaccurate regarding the New South Wales figure and it certainly does not provide the total picture.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to advise the Senate that yet another breast cancer screening unit will be officially opened tomorrow in Bowral, New South Wales, and another one will be opened in Bankstown in the next few weeks. These units, funded under the national breast cancer screening program, will be among 30 units in New South Wales and nearly 100 around Australia when the program is fully up and running. About 1.7 million to two million women will be screened every two years.

Breast cancer is a major health issue for women. More Australian women die from this than from any other form of cancer. About 2,500 women died from this disease in 1992. The good news is that if women regularly participate and have a breast cancer screening test every two years, they can expect to reduce their risk of death by 50 per cent. This government is justifiably proud of our national breast cancer screening program because it is one of the most comprehensive population based screening programs in the world, particularly when one considers it covers such vast geographical areas and that it delivers such high quality services in remote and rural areas, as well as the major metropolitan areas. The Commonwealth has funded this program with $60 million—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. These figures are totally incorrect. In the interests of honesty, it should be pointed out that they are incorrect.
—Order! I think you know better than I that that is not a point of order. I have no way of judging the correctness or otherwise of the figures, but you can take that up at a later stage.

—I would be very interested to find out from Senator Herron why he makes that claim. The Commonwealth has provided $60 million over the first three years of the program and the states have provided over $40 million. One of the most important problems has been the very uneven rate at which the states have spent their contribution—the very uneven rate at which the states have spent their contribution.
—We heard you the first time, Rosemary.

—I am glad Senator Patterson heard me because she is a Victorian senator and she should be ashamed of Victoria's failure to come up to scratch with the rest of the states. That is what is interesting—how far behind some states are in spending their money. Senator Herron should know that Queensland is one of the better states. It is well ahead, and so is South Australia. They are well in advance of the other states. Victoria is the state most behind in getting the breast cancer screening program up and running.

PARA.TAB: The other characteristic that has marked the establishment of this program across Australia has been the bipartisan way in which the state and federal ministers have cooperated, but in New South Wales tomorrow, the breast cancer screening program will be opened by Premier Fahey and claimed entirely as his. The fact is that more than 50 per cent of the money for that program comes from the Commonwealth government.
Opposition senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not pressure because Minister Phillips wants to join me in opening other programs across the state. I would much prefer that the breast cancer screening program continue in a bipartisan way. I have that support from other ministers for health. I am disappointed that New South Wales is claiming this program as its own. I am delighted that New South Wales is now finally getting the number of places up and running for women in that state.

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Herron interjects that we are behind. We are not behind. The promise made is the promise kept in delivering this breast cancer screening program. As I said, if women regularly use it, it will reduce the risk of death from breast cancer by 50 per cent. I would have thought that opposition senators would want to support that, not criticise it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. My question relates to the declaration issued by the minister on 4 February this year in relation to the Broome Crocodile Farm.
