—I address my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Given the incidence of dementia for those over the age of 75 and the rapid ageing of the veteran community, what is the minister doing to better inform health professionals about this complex condition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly an undisputed fact that Australians are living longer. Of course, this is in no small measure due to the excellent health care available and is also a result of better nutrition and greater emphasis on healthy lifestyles. Against the new optimism for a longer life, there is a growing awareness of the increase in dementia in the elderly. It is estimated that $1.05 billion is spent annually on dementia care. In 1992 this government sponsored the national action plan for dementia care, and current figures show that dementia affects 10 per cent of Australians over the age of 75.

PARA.TAB: This is a particularly difficult problem for the Department of Veterans' Affairs because of the average age of its clients. Currently the Department of Veterans' Affairs provides treatment and hospital services for some 342,000 veterans and their dependants, of whom 30 per cent or more are now aged 75 or over. The key factor in relation to that is that by the turn of the century that figure will have increased to 60 per cent of the entitled beneficiaries of the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

On the basis of those figures it is estimated that the number of DVA clients suffering from dementia by the turn of the century will be almost 20,000 people. This significant health problem requires the provision of appropriate community-based services, the training of health and community workers and general carers, and also public education.

My department has already implemented a series of initiatives that address some of these problems and those faced by, not only those who suffer from dementia, but also carers. One of the DVA initiatives is in the area of education for health care providers and carers of those with dementia. To that end the department is developing a dementia care package which complements the government's national action plan on dementia care.

On Monday night I launched a book entitled Dementia: A Positive View, at Calvary Hospital. This book, which my department has compiled, is a collection of articles on dementia from health professionals who are pre-eminent in their field, and also from carers. It addresses many of the varied and difficult issues of dementia care.

It also gives health professionals an opportunity to review existing practices, widen their knowledge, and increase their awareness. The book will make a very significant contribution to the management of veterans and non-veterans alike who suffer from dementia. I applaud this focus from the department on this very important question that is facing the veteran and war widow community in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Senator Vanstone asked me a question in my capacity of representing the Attorney-General—
—It was the Minister for Justice, actually.

—Senator Vanstone asked me a question in my capacity of representing the Minister for Justice in relation to a tape levy. I do have an answer for Senator Vanstone. With her agreement, I will incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
On 2 March 1994 Senator Amanda Vanstone asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Justice the following question without notice:
Following the government's failed attempts to protect the copyright of recording artists via the now unconstitutional blank tape levy—
(a) Will the Government accept that to increase the sales tax on blank cassettes will simply disadvantage innocent consumers, and be costly to run and inefficient?

(b) What is wrong with the proposal put forward by the Australian Tape Manufacturers Association, and endorsed by the Australian Consumers Association, that a licence fee to make a copy for one's own use be included in the price of any recorded music purchased?
(c) Does such a licence fee not operate very effectively for computer software?

(d) Does the Minister not understand the stupidity of continuing with the situation where Australians can buy products such as the Icehouse Big Wheel CD and be lawbreakers if they tape the CD but are given instructions with purchase on how to copy the floppy?
The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In relation to the preface to the series of questions, Senator Vanstone referred to the protection of recording artists. In fact the blank tape royalty scheme introduced in the Copyright Amendment Act 1989, and subsequently held to be invalid by the High Court (in Australian Blank Tape Manufacturers Association Ltd v The Commonwealth (1993) 25 IPR 1), was to benefit not only recording artists but also the record producers and the composers of the music and words performed. Those same interests will benefit from the new scheme of compensation for home copying of sound recordings.

I remind the honourable senator that the Opposition wholeheartedly supported the initiative when the Copyright Amendment Act 1989 was before the Senate in 1989. It was advocated in their arts policy. Senator Puplick said then. . . "a number of initiatives in the Bill were supported by the Opposition because they reflected views which the Opposition had expressed in its published arts policy, namely support for the levy on blank tapes,. . . "

A blank tape levy to compensate copyright owners for home copying of sound recordings is recognised worldwide. Many nations internationally have adopted levy schemes, including several European countries and the USA.

In international discussions convened by the World Intellectual Property Organisation consideration is being given to an international obligation to have a levy scheme. Work is also being undertaken by the Commission of the European Union.
I will answer the matters raised by Senator Vanstone:
(a) It needs to be said that the licence proposed by Senator Vanstone will increase costs for consumers.

A 1983 survey recorded that approximately 85 per cent of all blank audiotapes bought by consumers were used for home copying. So I am sure that a levy or tax would be recognised by most consumers buying blank tape for private purposes as being a fair quid pro quo for being legally able to engage in home taping. For that small percentage of consumers buying tape for purposes other than home taping music, the scheme being developed will—as did the invalid scheme—include provision for refund of the tax.

I do not accept that the proposed scheme, which is still being developed, will be costly and inefficient to run. A high priority in designing the scheme is to minimise the administrative cost and inconvenience in its implementation and operation.

(b) The proposal by the Australian Tape Manufacturers Association (ATMA) has been received only very recently, and I can assure the honourable senator that it is being given serious consideration and consultation.

The loading of a licence fee onto the price of all recorded music would disadvantage innocent consumers, those who have no home taping equipment or intentions, just as much as a levy on blank tape. The Government would also need to be convinced that the ATMA proposal would not turn out to be more costly to administer than the levy on blank tape, even if it was as fair to consumers as the levy.

The ATMA proposal may well be more appropriate in the future when technology has advanced. To that end, I will ask the Copyright Convergence Group, which is looking at future forms of transmission of copyright materials to the home.

(c) I am not aware that a licence fee is added to the price of computer software, as an identifiable component of that price. I am aware that much computer software is said to be licensed to the ultimate purchaser, and I understand that that is because the normal use of software involves copying which technically may be an exercise of the copyright owner's rights. On the other hand, the normal use of a copy of a sound recording by a private individual, namely, playing it for private enjoyment, does not amount to such an exercise. I mention that the appropriateness of existing copyright protection of software is the subject of a draft report by the Copyright Law Review Committee issued in June 1993, which it is in the process of finalising.

(d) The state of the relevant law is unsatisfactory to both copyright owners, who cannot practically control or secure a return from home taping, and to consumers, who cannot practically seek clearance to engage in non-infringing home taping. This was recognised by the Opposition as well as the Government when the blank tape royalty scheme was introduced. It remains the case.

I want to move as soon as possible to remedy this by introduction of a levy on blank tape or, if it can be shown to be more effective, by some other scheme such as that proposed by ATMA. Accordingly, I have asked for early advice on the evaluation of the ATMA proposal and the results of consultations on that proposal with copyright interests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Harradine asked me a question about family planning in Indonesia. I promised him a reply as soon as possible. I now give it to him. In relation to the first question that Senator Harradine asked, the joint statement signed on 24 February this year by Dr Haryono Suyono and Mr Gordon Bilney during their meeting in Canberra did state that Indonesia's family planning program was voluntary and non-coercive.

PARA.TAB: As to Senator Harradine's second question relating to enforcement of Indonesia's target-driven family planning program, as the honourable senator put it, the situation is this: the Indonesian government has not used targets in its family planning program since March 1993. Dr Haryono himself announced the dropping of targets in a speech on quality of care in Indonesia on 8 February 1993 when he stated:

ANSWER.PARA: By March 1993 BKKBN, the national family planning coordinating board, will no longer use the targeting system in calculating its needs to serve people for family planning. This is simply because people misunderstood our community oriented approach as a target that needs to be achieved no matter what.
His speech also highlighted the need for client satisfaction to be central to family planning programs. For example, he stated:
This commitment should be deeper and broader than simply the contraceptive technicality and its possible difficulties.

The information service network and contraceptive methods provided to participants have to be appropriate within the existing social network and the social cultural system of the community. It is hoped that the Family Planning Service Network will not disturb the balance and social harmony of the community. Family planning only wishes to become a part of the social community.

There is evidence to suggest that in the past the implementation of mass family planning programs involved methods which could be regarded as coercive. Dr Haryono's remarks in his speech in February last year quite implicitly acknowledged that. However, the Australian mission in Jakarta has reported that in the aftermath of Dr Haryono's statement last February such incidents are no longer occurring and the central government wants to prevent the community approach to family planning from employing coercive methods.

PARA.TAB: I should perhaps add that in Indonesia it is accepted for religious leaders, students, professors, community leaders and the military itself to be involved in all social programs in ways that simply would not be the case in Australia, as I am sure Senator Harradine is well aware. As well as providing information on family planning programs, these groups would be involved in motivating people to attend immunisation programs, getting village children into school, initiating village clean-ups, promoting attendance at religious ceremonies and so on.

Finally, Senator Harradine also asked why Mr Bilney did not `pull Dr Haryono up' in his comments on the promotion of Norplant as a beauty aid. I think Senator Harradine would acknowledge that it is not really appropriate for substantive dialogue with a foreign government minister to be conducted by interrupting answers to questions given at a press conference. Moreover it is the case that Dr Haryono stressed that comprehensive medical screening procedures are in place and that women cannot get access to Norplant without going through those procedures. As he put it:

ANSWER.PARA: This is the way to inform people and to get them attracted to it, but when it comes to the placement, then you have to go to the doctor, you have to go to the midwife, you have to go to the screening, you have to go to all this kind of nitty gritty before you can get something.
More generally, can I say that, as Mr Bilney and I have repeatedly made clear, Australian aid funds will not be used to implement in any way advanced coercive family planning programs.

PARA.TAB: Lastly on the subject of funding, I should add that no new program initiatives or funding commitments were announced by Mr Bilney with Dr Haryono in their joint statement. It was a statement about general principles of cooperation only, and I am advised that the particular projects listed in paragraph 6 of that statement were all references to prior commitments and acknowledged as such by the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Haryono was not in charge of the coercion for 15 years.

—Whatever may have been the case in the past, he made a speech in February last year and the evidence is, as reported to us by the mission, that a quite new approach has been implemented. No doubt it is the pressure of people around the world like Senator Harradine that has produced this result.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Administrative Services and Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) to a question without notice asked by Senator Carr this day, relating to staffing arrangements for members of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion concerns the answer given by Senator McMullan on the `Bronnie rorts'. I raised this matter because I was concerned on behalf of many of the small people around this parliament who over the years have had to enjoy the company of former Senator Bishop—the secretaries of committees, the Comcar drivers, the attendants, the people who do not necessarily have the power and authority that comes with high office in this parliament.

PARA.TAB: I was concerned because many public servants have had to come before Senator Bishop on various committees. I read, for instance, in the Australian magazine of October 1993 of examples where public servants were physically ill in anticipation of their appearance before committees on which former Senator Bishop was a member. She indicated that `If you do not have any stress, you are dead'.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order. The question, as I recall it, related to termination payments for staff as provided in the Members of Parliament Staff Act 1984. It was answered by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator McMullan). That was the question; that was the answer. The subject now being raised by Senator Carr does not relate to the answer at all. To go back to the Australian and start talking about estimates committees and how they proceeded and whether or not the bureaucrats feared the interrogation of former Senator Bishop is totally irrelevant.

—Order! A fair amount of latitude is given in the moving of motions to take note of answers, and that is normally given to the opposition benches. I would ask Senator Carr to get to the point as quickly as possible.

—The official handbook that we all live by says that in the case of a senator who resigns from parliament or dies the `employent of the electorate staff shall be deemed not to have been so terminated and to continue until the casual vacancy is filled'. That is the normal way in which proceedings are conducted in this place.

PARA.TAB: In the case of the by-election in Mackellar, it appears that former Senator Bishop has indicated her desire to dismiss three of her staff to provide 11 weeks severance pay, which they are entitled to. The point is, however, that it is one thing for a former senator to claim misuse of public money is totally inappropriate and another for her then to be engaged in that. In the case of the office of the former member for Mackellar, Mr Jim Carlton, I understand from my friends in Sydney that it is in fact still working.

The Australian public is being asked to fund not only former Senator Bishop's leadership campaign against Dr Hewson but also her campaign for election to the seat of Mackellar. Last year she claimed $100,000 for various Comcar and airfare facilities, which, of course, is in stark contrast to the abuse that she heaped upon public servants. I recall that on one occasion she indicated to a tax official that officials of the tax office should write out in longhand 100 times, `I must comply with direction 2K'. It is a pity that the same standards of decency were not applied to all people in this parliament, particularly former Senator Bishop.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a rather grubby attempt to discredit former Senator Bishop, I thought. I was disappointed that Senator McMullan would be a party to it. When one throws stones in this place and talks about moral obligations, one should accept that that applies to both sides of the chamber. Therefore, I would like to think that Senator McMullan applied the same moral standards to former staff of Mr Keating when he resigned as Deputy Prime Minister—I will not go through the names; those opposite can check the records, if Senator McMullan has got the records—who received substantial termination payments, and, in some cases, were immediately re-employed by other ministers such as the now discredited Ros Kelly and the now retired John Dawkins.
—Bronnie is a paragon of virtue; what is the relevance of that?
—What is the relevance of it?
—Yes.

—I am saying that these staff, who were simply warehoused, were paid termination payments. When Mr Keating came back into office he re-employed them. We can go down the same path as those opposite—if they so wish—but I do not think it is helpful. Perhaps we should expect this from the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) but I would have thought he would understand that he has some responsibility to staff, and former staff, in his position as Minister for Administrative Services. As I say, I am disappointed that he stooped to that level today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no intention of participating in this debate. In fact, I was waiting for Senator Gareth Evans to arrive. I will be brief. I must say that it was of particular interest to me to see this little incident on the 7.30 Report last night. In terms of Senator Hill's defence of former Senator Bishop, he knows full well and has chosen to sideline and overlook the fact that former Senator Bishop established her entire career and reputation on this question of being the scrupulous public defender of taxpayers' interests in Australia. A brief reference to the Hansard—
—We know Mr Keating is not.

—Those opposite have been dishing it out. We are talking today about former Senator Bishop, as Senator Hill knows full well—although he would like to dodge it. It is a fact that former Senator Bishop made a career of being a member of this chamber. I have sat through hundreds of hours of estimates committees with former Senator Bishop—I think we set a record from 8.00 p.m. one day until 6.00 a.m. the next—hearing questions concerned with safeguarding every dollar and every cent of taxpayers' money. I ask Senator Hill one simple question: how does one justify, if one is a paragon of virtue, a defender of taxpayers' money and not a two-faced hypocrite—which I concede is a tautology and perhaps should be ruled out on those grounds—former Senator Bishop's current actions? Senator Hill knows what I am talking about. Former Senator Bishop has built her reputation on defending taxpayers' interests. There are over 100 references in the Hansard to former Senator Bishop talking about taxpayers' money. Just as recently as December—
—You said this was going to be short, Bob.

—It is. If you stop interjecting, it will be even shorter. Just last December, in estimates committees, former Senator Bishop asked why it was acceptable for Mrs Kelly to `hand out taxpayers' money to buy votes'. How would Senator Hill portray a former member of staff, no longer a member of staff, sacked by former Senator Bishop and no longer in the public employ, still acting as a member of former Senator Bishop's staff in an office publicly paid for, an office which former Senator Bishop no longer has the right to use as a senator, using a government fax machine to send out statements for the campaign in Mackellar?
—Didn't Lavarch do that in Queensland?

—It is pathetic if the only defence put forward by the opposition of this paragon of public virtue is to cite examples of other people doing the same thing. On the question of the misuse of taxpayers' money, former Senator Bishop made a virtue of dishing it out during every single minute she was in the Senate. Former Senator Bishop had available to her an option, which she chose not to adopt, for her staff to ensure a continuity of service for constituents. Instead, she chose to give them termination payments to maximise the benefits they took.

PARA.TAB: As Paul Lyneham noted last night on the 7.30 Report, it will be interesting indeed to see whether, should former Senator Bishop win Mackellar, the same staff turn up again among her staff in just a very short time in the future. Then judgment can be made on whether this was a conspiracy to defraud the public. We will wait for judgment on that in a few weeks time to see whether those same staff are re-employed.

But, leaving that aside, how does one justify being a paragon of virtue? If one sets oneself up in these positions and turns out to have feet of clay, one deserves to be exposed. Above everyone else in this chamber, former Senator Bishop built a reputation on this basis. She has now been caught with her fingers in the till.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr raised another issue that came to the fore in Senator McMullan's answer. How did the media obtain the confidential personnel details of Mrs Bishop's staff? This information from the staff is provided to the ministerial and parliamentary services group in the Department of Administrative Services. As a result over the last 24 hours it is obvious that staff members and senators can no longer be certain that confidential employment information provided to DAS can be treated in a neutral or confidential way. It seems that DAS ought to operate as a neutral agency and that the information provided to it should not be used for political purposes. I do not know how the press got the information, but one way was for it to have been provided.
—It is in a press release.

—You are telling me it is in a press release. Government senators are presuming that those staff will be re-employed. That is a presumption that may or may not be right. The issue is that only two days ago the media reported that the Australian Federal Police was investigating the circumstances surrounding the leaking of a document obtained by the shadow minister for finance, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello). The shadow minister for finance had the Federal Police on his front doorstep to question his staff and to question him about how they got that information. Now we have the opposite situation where information about staff has been obtained, and I think that that ought to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: If that information has been obtained in an inappropriate way, then I believe it could be a breach of the Privacy Act and those people have every right to complain to the Privacy Commissioner. Honourable senators opposite say that the information was gained from a press release. I have not seen that press release—

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Financial Review.

—I do not know where the Financial Review got the information from, with all due respect. The issue is that there is a lot of other information that is associated with that data that goes to the Department of Administrative Services, such as tax file numbers and other bank account information. I want to know what sort of information was provided, how they got that information, and if it was sufficient. If, as those opposite are claiming, it was from the press release, then I will stand to be corrected. If it was not, then the question has to be asked: how did the information get there? I hope the minister will be able to answer the question here. It is of concern to me. I may have been mistaken because I have not seen the press release, and I will admit to that. If the information in the press is not in Mrs Bishop's press release, then the question must be asked: how did they get the information? I hope Senator McMullan will be able to answer that question.

—Senator Patterson has raised a very valid point. It is important where a minister is in charge of files that we make sure that the privacy of those files is respected. When Senator Robert Ray was serving in that portfolio he was very careful. I think that, therefore, he had the confidence of each member of parliament to make sure that appropriate privacies were provided. Where action has been taken, no-one would argue that the rules have to be applied and they have to be applied fairly. That is why Senator Carr's comments today were so interesting.
—Helpful as well.

—And helpful. Senator Carr is a reasonably recent senator in this parliament, but he may recall that when Mr Keating was sacked from the ministry he had quite a large amount of staff who were involved. Senator Carr probably was not there, but a lot of questions were asked at Senate estimates committees in relation to the termination payments of Mr Keating's staff. We are fortunate that Senator McMullan is here because I have lists about which I would be very interested to hear his views.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ryan, for example, received a termination payment of $12,092, and immediately went on to the staff of—would honourable senators believe it—the Hon. Ros Kelly. Ms L. Murray received $7,061.67, and went on to the staff of the Hon. John Dawkins. But of course that is small potatoes compared with a few of these figures. Dr Don Russell was on Mr Keating's staff. Perhaps Senator McMullan and Senator Gareth Evans, who are in the chamber, can tell us whether this in fact occurred. My memory is that Dr Russell went off Mr Keating's staff, while Mr Keating was out of office Dr Russell received a termination payment, and then he came back on to Mr Keating's staff.

The termination payment in relation to Don Russell was $27,000, but that is small potatoes compared with one payout—really small potatoes. Dr Edwards was a consultant to Mr Keating for quite a long period on a long-term contract. Dr Edwards's payout was $79,955—a lot of money. I believe that when Dr Edwards was re-employed on Mr Keating's staff, there was a payback but I would be interested to see whether the payback was the $80,000 or whether it was a lesser amount.

There are issues involved here. Senator Carr chose to attack the staff of Mrs Bishop. He opened this up and the standards must be applied fairly throughout the parliament. I would therefore be interested to hear from Senator McMullan about what precisely occurred in those cases because it is relevant. Of course, there are many other cases which may well be raised thanks to Senator Carr's question today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is wonderful to have the advocates of open government sitting opposite. They believe that everything should be disclosed until something is disclosed that makes them feel uncomfortable and then they say, `How did this happen? What a shock!'. When a matter relates to others, they want to set up an inquiry, call them before it and put them in gaol if they do not tell.

PARA.TAB: Here we have a situation where those opposite say that they are concerned about the facts. Let me make it very clear: no private fact with regard to any of Mrs Bishop's staff has been released by me or by anyone of whom I am aware. The issue of the release of private tax information was raised with me only twice in this chamber—both times by Mrs Bishop. On two occasions she asked me to release the private tax information of individuals. I refused and she complained about what she called a cover-up. I did not do it and I will not do it. She was the one who thought it should be done. It has happened only twice in the six years I have been in parliament and that was when Mrs Bishop came in here and asked me to release the private tax information of taxpayers and I declined. She felt it should have been released. I did not; I still do not.

Let us make it very clear how the fact that Mr Wheeler was still working from Mrs Bishop's Parliament House office became public. She put out a press release from her campaign office on 1 March, at the foot of which it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Further information: Gerard Wheeler (06) 277 3650.
So somebody rang that number and the voice at the other end said, `Bronwyn Bishop's office'—but it was not, because she had gone and the staff had resigned.

PARA.TAB: There is nothing wrong with staff getting severance payments when they resign. It is an award entitlement to which they are all legitimately entitled and I do not quibble with it. Those people are in no different a position from any others who lose their job and have an award entitlement to a redundancy payment. But when a person sacks an employee because he or she knows that the award makes provision for continuing employment, and there is an intention to continue to employ, that is a conspiracy. It is not the worker who has done anything wrong; it is the person who entered into the conspiracy.

The other bit of public information relates to how people knew that the staff of Mrs Bishop had been sacked. It was because Mrs Bishop said they were sacked. I did not know. How did the media find out? Because they asked Mrs Bishop—and my advice is that she said she had sacked them. How did the media find out that the staff might be re-employed? As far as I can tell, because I did not know, the media asked those employees and they said, `We expect to be re-employed'. I do not know whether they will be re-employed. All I know is that the media reported those individuals saying that they were going to be re-employed.

We all know of the actions that were taken by the Usher of the Black Rod in the proper discharge of his duties—there was absolutely nothing wrong there—and of the information that came to light. We did not make that information available. Most of that is information which we could not have had. It certainly was not on departmental records.

I make it clear that I am not criticising the individual employees who have received severance payments, because that is an award entitlement. I am saying that there appears to have been a conspiracy. The most significant problem is the situation with the offices, particularly the electorate office. My biggest concern is not that the office continues to be used but that, as a result of this conspiracy, that taxpayer funded office, which is supposed to be there to provide services for constituents, has had to be closed. There was no need for it to be closed. Mr Carlton did the right thing and kept his office open and is working in Mackellar. I am sure Mrs Bishop would not go anywhere near that office to get assistance from it because that would not be proper, I suppose. She would not go anywhere near it, would not dream of using it. It would not be doing anything to assist in her campaign, I suppose.

Mr Carlton has done nothing wrong; that office should be open. The three staff there are employed to provide service to constituents and the office should be open. That is the right thing. He has done nothing improper. But there are people who have advocated for years that taxpayers' money is sacrosanct. We now know why Mrs Bishop has always said that she is the taxpayers' friend: she wanted her friends, the taxpayers, to fund her election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —All this talk about leaving electorate offices open to service the constituents reminds me of Dr Carmen Lawrence, who kept her constituency office open in the seat of Glendalough for as long as she possibly could. She was not there to service the constituents; she got a bit confused. In fact, she helped the constituents of Glendalough by writing them all a nice letter during that period. She delayed leaving that office for as long as possible to delay the by-election date.

PARA.TAB: Dr Lawrence got confused. She left her home in Subiaco one day and, instead of turning right down Railway Parade to go to her electorate office in Glendalough, turned left and went down and serviced the constituents at Fremantle while she was on the payroll of the state taxpayers of Western Australia. That was on the part of someone who had built a career as a paragon of virtue. To service her constituents, of course, she wrote them all a letter introducing the new Labor Party candidate for the seat of Glendalough. So it is very good to see that members of the Labor Party are paragons of virtue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you send a letter to Fremantle recently?

—Of course I did. It was very good to see the Labor Party so keen to leave the constituency office open for someone, paid by the state taxpayer of Western Australia, to service John Dawkins's old electorate. If Senator Carr wants to talk about paragons of virtue, he should get up and balance the ledger.

—We are talking about someone who would be Prime Minister; someone who based her career on being so perfect and so honest—a career in terrorising public servants who did not have the capacity to defend themselves. If she wanted to terrorise ministers, that was fair enough—they had to defend themselves.
—She terrorised you, too, Burnsie.

—I had the unfortunate experience of having to chair many of the estimates committees where she had no ability to terrorise me, but she certainly did annoy the hell out of me. But for somebody who was so perfect and sought to make sure that other people acted with absolute honesty, we suddenly find a person who, in the New South Wales ranks of the Liberal Party, was press-ganged into becoming a senator only because she thought she could serve the community. When she decided to resign, was it because of ill health or pressure of work—

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I think a serious issue has emerged which I would like you to rule on. Senator Burns has had six years to attack Bronwyn Bishop. The very week she leaves the Senate, he decides, for the first time in six years to get to his feet. I wonder whether such behaviour is in order.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I think we could equally say that Senator Kemp has been crawling up to Bronwyn Bishop for three years. He has not changed; he still is.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The fact is that ex-Senator Bishop was able to destroy her own position quite adequately without me helping her over those six years. But she is no longer here to do that. Having so-called served the community over those years—although I do not know how she could have served the people of New South Wales because of all the time she spent in other states, travelling around the place and totting up a bill of $200,000 in travel expenses—she suddenly decides she needs to resign because she really wants to serve the community as Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: What does she do? Immediately, she decides what is to her advantage. She says, `I think I will sack my staff because in that way I can give them a severance payment and they can become involved in my campaign to get elected to the House of Representatives'. There is no consideration at all for the people whom she was supposed to represent. If she were decent she would have kept open her office to serve her constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like Carmen Lawrence.

—I am talking about former Senator Bishop. Senator Campbell is quite at liberty to raise that at another time. She did not do that. What she has done is grubby and dishonest. It is much less than honest, it is absolutely dishonest and she should be seen for what she is.
—You gutless little wonder.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The interjection by Senator Campbell was unparliamentary. Not only should he be asked to withdraw, but he should be asked to come out of the gutter as well.
—On the point of order: as Senator Kemp said earlier, Senator Burns did not have the intestinal fortitude to take on former Senator Bishop when she was here.
—What is the point of order?
—I am responding to the point. I am addressing the point of order.
—You are debating the issue.

—No, a point of order has been raised by Senator McKiernan and I am addressing the point of order. I am quite entitled to do that. If Senator Evans reads the standing orders, he will see that is the case. The point is that Senator Burns did not do as Senator Kemp said. It was just like the case of one of those Public Sector Union fellows who appeared before an estimates committee who took on former Senator Bishop. I suggested that we adjourn the meeting to allow former Senator Bishop to turn up and defend herself and these gutless people did not allow it to happen. It is most demeaning of Senator Burns to call former Senator Bishop dishonest here, where she does not have the right to get up and defend herself. He is using the cowards' castle. I say that it is a gutless act. If the word `gutless' is unparliamentary, I will withdraw it, but I regard it as an act which is most unfair.
—Senator Campbell, you are meandering a little. It may not be unparliamentary, but it is certainly disorderly in my view, and I would be grateful if you would withdraw it.
—I will withdraw.

—I emphasise that I believe the actions of former Senator Bishop in leaving this place, having regard to the way in which she dismissed her staff, and the way in which the office is obviously no longer available to her constituents, are pretty grubby. They should be criticised and remembered as she seeks to become Prime Minister. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to ask you a question regarding the allocation of rooms in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I am not sure whether this is a question for you or for the President. I noticed recently when I walked along the first floor corridor an office with a sign outside the door which reads, `Office of the Caucus Secretariat'. I wonder whether you can obtain for me—or have the President obtain for me—some information about that office and its allocation. I would like to know whether it is staffed by public servants or by Labor Party officials, who pays for the phone, fax and those sorts of things, how it came to be located on the Senate side of the building, and why it is needed. With all the ministerial offices and all the ministerial staffers, why is there such a thing as a caucus secretariat? I wonder whether you could get me some information about that.
—I will refer the question to the President, with whom the responsibility quite properly resides. I am sure he will be able to respond to you by question time on the next day of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the review of determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Privacy Commissioner. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Government Response to the Report of the Review of Determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Privacy Commissioner by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

The Report of the Review of Determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Privacy Commissioner (`the Report') by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was tabled in Parliament on 11 November 1992. The Report contains a number of recommendations for simplifying and streamlining the procedures for enforcing determinations made by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (`the Commission').

The Sex Discrimination and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1992 amended the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (`the SDA'), the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 (`the RDA') and the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (`the DDA') to put in place a new regime for enforcement of determinations under those Acts by the Commission.

The new regime maintains the protection of enabling the Court, upon application, to examine all the questions of fact and law regarding the complaint. While the possibility of a complainant facing a hearing before the Commission and then a new hearing before the Federal Court has not been overcome, the disadvantages of this system have been limited while maintaining the benefits of the Commission hearing procedures. As all determinations made by the Commission will be registered and enforceable as orders of the Court, unless the respondent initiates an application for review within 28 days of registration, it is to be expected that, in the vast majority of cases, the Commission's determination will decide the matter.

The amendments are outlined below in response to each of the Committee's recommendations. As four of the eight Committee members made separate recommendations, their recommendations have also been addressed.
Whilst the amendments were drafted without the benefit of the Report, they are substantially in accordance with the recommendations made by the majority of the Committee.

The Government notes that the Committee's recommendations also apply to the determinations of the Privacy Commissioner under the Privacy Act. The 1992 amendments to the SDA, the RDA and the DDA were part of the Government's Response to the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the Report of its Inquiry into Equal Opportunity and Equal Status for Women in Australia, entitled Half Way to Equal. Amendments to the Privacy Act to bring its determination enforcement procedures into line with those of the SDA, the RDA and the DDA were in a Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill which was introduced and passed in the 1993 Budget Sittings. That Bill also amended the SDA, the RDA, the DDA and the Privacy Act to allow an application for review of a determination to be brought outside the usual 28 day period in exceptional circumstances and with the leave of the Court. These amendments avoid any injustice which may be caused by the application of an absolute time limit on bringing an application for review.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendations of the Majority of the Committee

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 1
The Committee recommends that legislation be introduced to give effect to the following proposals:

Where there is a failure to comply with a decision of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or the Privacy Commissioner within 30 days of its making, or within such further time as may be ordered, a party interested or the decision maker be able to register the decision in the Federal Court.

At the expiration of 30 days, or such further time as may be ordered, the terms of the decision to become an order of the court unless in the meantime a party to the proceedings lodges a notice of objection.
Where a notice of objection is lodged within the time allowed then the matter will be reviewed in the Federal Court.

Where a party to a dispute before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or the Privacy Commissioner is dissatisfied with the decision, he, she or it may apply to the Federal Court within 21 days for leave to have the matter reviewed. The Court may grant leave subject to such conditions as it considers just.

In the event of the Federal Court undertaking a hearing, it may accept in evidence the transcript of the hearing before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or the Privacy Commissioner and any exhibits tendered there and may receive such further evidence as it considers just.

The new legislative regime provides that all determinations made by the Commission are to be registered in the Federal Court. Written notice of the registration of the determination must be sent by the Commission to the respondent to the determination within 7 days of it being registered. The respondent then has 28 days from the date of registration to apply for review of the determination in the Federal Court. An application for review may only be brought outside the usual 28 day period with the leave of the Court. In the absence of an application for review, the determination becomes enforceable as an order of the Court at the end of the 28 day period.

The Federal Court, when reviewing a determination, may review all issues of fact and law. Evidence which was not adduced before the Commission may not be introduced in proceedings in the Federal Court, except by leave of the Court.

The Government is of the view that the new regime of registering determinations in the Federal Court is a great improvement on the previous regime where, if a respondent before the Commission failed to comply with the Commission's determination, the complainant had to initiate an application in the Federal Court which would then hear the matter afresh.
Recommendation 2
The Committee recommends that filing fees not be charged to register determinations in the Federal Court.
Under the new procedure, no filing fee is charged to register the determination.
Recommendation 3

The Committee recommends that the Sex Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act and the Privacy Act, and, as appropriate, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act be amended to provide a mechanism for the registration of conciliation agreements in the Federal Court along similar lines to the registration of agreements in the Family Court pursuant to s.86 of the Family Law Act.

The Government has not adopted this recommendation. Conciliation proceedings in the Commission and the terms of any settlement between the parties are confidential. This recommendation raises issues about maintaining the confidentiality of such proceedings and settlements. The Attorney-General's Department, in consultation with the Commission, will further examine this recommendation.
Recommendation 4

The Committee recommends that determinations made against Commonwealth agencies pursuant to the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act and the Racial Discrimination Act be enforceable in the same way as those made under the Privacy Act pursuant to s.57(2) of that legislation.

In respect of determinations involving Commonwealth agencies, the amendments made by the Sex Discrimination and Other Legislation Amendment Act provide that the respondent agency or, where relevant, the principal executive of that agency, must comply with the Commission's determination. Where the determination involves damages, application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (`the AAT') for review. A Commonwealth agency or principal executive of such an agency can only seek review in the AAT with the Minister's permission. This regime is based on that in s.57(2) of the Privacy Act 1988 (`the Privacy Act').
Recommendation 5

The Committee recommends that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission be given power to make an order that Commonwealth agencies who are respondents to a matter pay to a successful complainant the amount or part of the amount she, he or it has incurred in bringing the proceedings.

The Government has not adopted this recommendation. The Commission does not have power to award costs against a party to any complaint. The Commission may, however, recommend to the Attorney-General that financial assistance be granted to a complainant after the Commission has inquired into the complaint. Around five per cent of all complaints received by the Commission proceed to an inquiry. The number of inquiries in which a Commonwealth agency is the respondent is, therefore, small. Were this recommendation to be adopted, the Commission would require extra resources to tax costs awarded against Commonwealth agencies. Given that the number of matters involving a Commonwealth agency that proceed to an inquiry in any year is likely to be small, the extra expense involved would be unjustified. However, matters where taxation of costs is required could be referred to another body such as the Federal Court. The Attorney-General's Department will consult with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the Federal Court and other relevant agencies on whether implementation of this recommendation is feasible.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendations of the Minority of the Committee

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 1

We recommend that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission continue to have the function of inquiring into alleged infringements of the Sex Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act and the Privacy Act and to endeavour, by conciliation, to settle matters to which the alleged infringements relate.

The Government does not propose to change the existing functions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Privacy Commissioner to endeavour to conciliate complaints of discrimination and infringements of privacy.
Recommendation 2

We recommend that the Sex Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act and the Privacy Act, and, as appropriate, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act be amended to provide a mechanism for the registration of conciliated agreements in the Federal Court along similar lines to the registration of agreements in the Family Court pursuant to s.86 of the Family Law Act.

As noted above in respect of recommendation 3 of the majority of the Committee, the Government has not adopted this recommendation. Conciliation proceedings in the Commission and the terms of any settlement between the parties are confidential. This recommendation raises issues about maintaining the confidentiality of such proceedings and settlements. The Attorney-General's Department, in consultation with the Commission, will further examine this recommendation.
Recommendation 3
We recommend that where:
the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has endeavoured to settle a matter by conciliation, but has not been successful; or
is of the opinion that a matter cannot be settled by conciliation
the legislation be amended to provide an immediate right of action to the Federal Court.

The Government does not support this recommendation. Allowing the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to conduct a hearing of matters which cannot be conciliated gives the parties an opportunity to have the complaint determined by a body with specialist knowledge of anti-discrimination and privacy laws. Commission proceedings also have the advantages, in comparison with court proceedings, of being relatively informal, procedurally flexible, speedy and inexpensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on beef cattle feedlots in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: PREAMBLE

1.The Report by the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia, tabled on 17 December 1992, has been considered by the Government. The Report addresses regulations and controls relating to the establishment and management of feedlots; the economic, social and environmental impact of feedlots; and the implications of lot feeding for animal welfare. The Government is now in a position to respond to the Report.

2.The Committee concludes that the beef cattle feedlot sector is a growing and increasingly important part of the Australian beef industry and that lot feeding is a legitimate husbandry tool. The Committee has made several recommendations aimed at promoting the development of an industry that safeguards the environment and has proper regard for the welfare of animals.

3.The Government endorses the Committee's recognition of the growing role and importance of the industry. In the Government's view, a strong, responsible, viable and internationally competitive lot feeding industry will be necessary to enable the Australian beef industry to successfully compete in meeting the demand for high quality product in the growing North Asian markets, and as such, represents an important value adding mechanism for the beef industry.

4.The Government shares the Committee's view that the industry must be properly regulated, ecologically sustainable and sensitive and responsive to community concerns. The development of the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia, endorsed by all levels of Government, the lot feeding industry and animal welfare groups will facilitate the development of the feedlot industry in a way which maximises the benefits for all.

5.The Government welcomes the Committee's endorsement of the concept of Animal Care Statements and their inclusion in the National Guidelines. The Government has also endorsed the concept of Animal Care statements as an important self-regulatory means of ensuring the protection of the health and welfare of cattle kept in feedlots. The Government encourages their adoption by all feedlots. In this context, the Government notes the proposed AUS-MEAT Feedlot Accreditation Scheme will require all accredited feedlots to submit an Animal Care Statement.

6.The Government believes the proposed self-regulatory AUS-MEAT Feedlot Accreditation Scheme, to be implemented in early 1994, will play a significant complementary role in implementing the principles contained in the Guidelines, and the Government has consequently given in-principle endorsement to the proposal.

7.The AUS-MEAT Feedlot Accreditation Scheme will gather comprehensive information on the environmental performance of those feedlots taking up accreditation which, in combination with research being funded by the Meat Research Corporation to measure and improve the feedlot industry's environmental performance, will allay some of the Committee's concerns relating to the lack of knowledge on the environmental impact of feedlots. The information gathered through these processes will be available to refine the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia.

8.However, the Government is concerned about the potential environmental impact of small opportunity feedlots, whose activities it may not be practicable to regulate under the AUS-MEAT accreditation scheme because of their small size and transient nature.

9.The Government considers that the adverse impacts of small opportunity feedlots on the environment can be minimised through the application of the principles and the national goals of the Decade of Landcare Plan, which provides for coordinated and cooperative actions to improve land management. The integrated catchment management approaches outlined in the Decade of Landcare Plans of the Commonwealth and State Governments and the guidelines being developed under the National Water Quality Management Strategy will provide a framework, at the local level, for agreeing and setting locally acceptable best management practices to achieve environmental and socio-economic objectives.

10.The Department of Primary Industries and Energy contributes towards the funding of improved resource management, including catchment management activities, under the Decade of Landcare through the National Landcare Program (NLP). The objectives of the NLP, which encourages a long term strategic approach to the management of land, water and related vegetation are:

PARA.TAB: to promote partnership between the community, industry and government in the management of natural resources;
assist in establishing institutional arrangements to develop and implement policies;
assist in enhancing the long term productivity of natural resources; and
assist in developing approaches to help resolve conflicts over access to natural resources in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: 11.The Department of Primary Industries and Energy is developing Commonwealth-State Partnership Agreements to implement and achieve the objectives of the NLP.

12.The Partnership Agreements will have two parts: an overarching statement of objectives and principles that will guide the development of joint Commonwealth/State action strategies to be implemented under the aegis of the NLP; and a number of schedules addressing agreed priority outcomes. Provision of financial assistance for initiatives will be established within a broad framework including achievement of milestones and outcomes advancing the objectives of the Agreements. The schedules will cover issues such as clean rivers and healthy catchments, sustainable production and resource management, urban water resources management, community action and awareness, and monitoring and evaluation.

13.The Partnership Agreements may provide the opportunity for the States and Territories to incorporate the issue of proper management of small feedlots within the broader priorities of sustainable natural resource management.

14.The Property Management Planning Campaign being organised under the NLP provides the opportunity for land owners and managers to acquire resource and financial management skills that will assist them in managing their properties based on the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

15.Landcare groups provide the community support and encouragement to land owners and managers to achieve sustainable resource management. These groups also provide information and skills to land owners and managers and, in most cases, have established effective networks which enable them to access State and Territory resources to complement their efforts.

16.Given the potential of feedlots to impact adversely on water quality, the Government believes that feedlot proposals should be assessed in terms of their impact on the catchment in which it will be located and in terms of its compatibility with any catchment management objectives. The Government also believes that the environmental management of feedlots, including small or opportunity feedlots, should be consistent generally with the policies and principles of the National Water Quality Management Strategy (NWQMS), and in particular, the principles and best management practices outlined in the national guidelines being developed to manage water resources in the rural environment. The NWQMS is being developed jointly by the Agricultural and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ, combining the former Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand, Australian Water Resources Council and Australian Soil Conservation Council) and the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council.

17.The main principle underlying the Strategy is to pursue the sustainable use of the nation's water resources by protecting and enhancing their quality while maintaining economic and social development. The Strategy proposes the adoption of a complementary package of regulatory and market-based measures to take advantage of the strengths of both approaches.

18.Guidelines are being developed under the strategy to provide a point of reference when issues are being determined on a case by case basis. Consistent with the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia, the guidelines are aimed at providing a shared national objective while allowing flexibility to respond to differing circumstances at regional and local levels.

19.The NWQMS Guidelines for Managing Water Resources in the Rural Environment, currently being developed, will provide nationally agreed principles for managing water resources in the rural environment consistent with ecologically sustainable development to address:

PARA.TAB: the use of best management practices to reduce the adverse impacts of all forms of landuse, including intensive rural industries, on water quality, such as nutrient pollution and salinisation; and
manage water resources in the rural environment on an integrated basis.

SPEECH.PARA: 20.In accordance with action arising out of the National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development, which provides for sustainable land and water resources management, the Government believes that the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia and the NWQMS provide the policy basis for promoting best management practices to ensure that feedlot operations do not adversely impact on the environment. The Government believes the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment (IGEA) will provide a mechanism for the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments to adopt the principles of the Guidelines and the NWQMS.

21.The draft Algal Management Strategy for the Murray-Darling Basin was released for public comment in August 1993 by the Hon Simon Crean MP, Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in his capacity as Chairperson of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council. The draft strategy also provides a framework for coordinated planning and management actions to reduce the frequency and intensity of algal blooms and other water quality problems associated with nutrient pollution arising from sources, such as intensive agricultural industries, in the Murray-Darling Basin.

22.The Commonwealth Government will move quickly to implement those recommendations which it supports and which fall within its responsibilities. Those matters which fall within the responsibilities of State and Territory Governments will be brought to their attention through ARMCANZ. While recognising that responsibility for deciding whether or not to implement these recommendations rests primarily with the State and Territory Governments concerned, the Commonwealth Government urges that a nationally consistent approach be adopted.

23.Several of the recommendations relate to amendments to the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia. In such cases the Government is concerned that the cooperative approach that was evident in the development of the Guidelines be continued, and consequently these recommendations will be passed to the Standing Committee on Beef Cattle Feedlot Guidelines for consideration when the National Feedlot Guidelines Workshop is reconvened. The Workshop is due to be reconvened in 1994 to consider the operation of the Guidelines and any amendments that may be necessary.

24.The Government will request the Subcommittee on Animal Welfare (SCAW), which developed the Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals—Cattle, to give consideration to those recommendations relating to the Model Code in the context of SCAW's commitment to review the Model Code regularly to take account of advances in knowledge. SCAW is due to revise the Model Code in 1995.

25.The Report makes recommendations relating to research into the environmental and animal welfare aspects of lot feeding. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will request the Meat Research Corporation (MRC) and the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation (LWRRDC) to give consideration to these recommendations when they are reviewing their research and development plans.

26.The MRC, along with other Commonwealth rural industry research and development bodies, is funded from industry levies matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth Government up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of the relevant industry. The LWRRDC was established to fund research related to sustainable management of soil, water and vegetation resources considered to be in the public interest and is funded fully by the Commonwealth Government. While the Government does not determine which individual projects are funded, it would expect the annual operational plans and five year research and development plans, to be submitted by these bodies for the approval of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, to include an appropriate level of research devoted to the environmental and animal welfare aspects of lot feeding. The Government has introduced legislation into the Parliament to incorporate ecologically sustainable development objectives into the MRC's charter. The Government also notes the MRC is already undertaking significant research into the environmental and animal welfare performance of feedlots.

27.It must be recognised that these Commonwealth research and development bodies are not the sole research funding organisations and that the States and the private sector also have a role and responsibility. There is a place for a coordinated research effort and in this respect the Commonwealth research and development bodies are well positioned to ensure there is an effective network of research into beef cattle lot feeding. The MRC already cooperates with the LWRRDC in programs focused on sustainable beef production.
28.The Government's responses to each of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs' conclusions and recommendations are set out in the attached schedule.
SCHEDULE
Conclusion

1.On the basis of evidence presented during the inquiry, the Committee considers that the beef cattle feedlot sector is a growing and increasingly important part of the Australian beef industry. The industry represents a significant value adding process for livestock, with gross value of production in 1992 estimated at over $800 million. With over 70 per cent of production destined for overseas markets, the industry makes a notable contribution to Australia's export performance. Feedlots also confer economic benefits on other Australian industries, particularly the grains industry, and to rural and regional economies in general.

The Committee recognises that there is concern in some sectors of the community about feedlot developments and, in particular, the threat they pose to local amenity, the environment and animal welfare. These concerns cannot be dismissed.
The Committee supports the development of the industry and considers that the feedlot industry must be properly regulated, ecologically sustainable and sensitive and responsive to the community.
Supported.

The Government welcomes the Committee's support for the development of the beef cattle feedlot industry. The Government supports the view that the industry must be properly regulated, ecologically sustainable and sensitive and responsive to the community.

PARA.EMPHASIS: National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

2.The Committee acknowledges that it is difficult to develop detailed, comprehensive standards for feedlots across Australia, as there are significant differences in climate, topography, population densities, soil types and the availability of water. It is in this context that the Committee welcomes the development of the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia.

In the Committee's view, the Guidelines provide a useful framework against which State and Territory Governments can develop detailed legislative and administrative arrangements that provide consistency and certainty to the feedlot industry and, at the same time, have due regard for the environment, the local and wider community and animal welfare.
The Committee considers that proper siting and sound management of feedlots are fundamental to achieving a responsible feedlot industry.
Supported.

The Government supports the approach adopted for the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia which provides a broad framework of generally acceptable principles for the establishment and operation of feedlots. Australia is comprised of diverse climates, environments and ecosystems and adequate environmental protection of these will not be achieved through prescriptive national guidelines. The Government considers the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia will encourage a consistent approach to the management and operation of feedlots and provide the basis for more detailed guidelines, laws and regulations to be framed to take account of the specific circumstances of feedlot developments in different geographical regions throughout Australia.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The National Guidelines and Model Codes of Practice

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation

3.Given the prospects for growth in the industry and the special nature of lot feeding, the Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in conjunction with the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand, develop a specific model code for the welfare of cattle in feedlots and that this code be incorporated into the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia.
Not supported.

Many of the provisions of the Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals—Cattle that are not specifically directed at cattle held in feedlots are still relevant to such cattle. Additionally, instances of producers maintaining both extensive and intensive cattle systems on the one property through the establishment of small opportunity feedlots have become more common. In these circumstances, the Government believes it appropriate that the one code of practice covers both husbandry systems.

The Government does acknowledge that the code could be improved to clarify the relationship and remove the inconsistencies between the body of the Model Code and the appended Code of Practice for Cattle Welfare in Feedlots developed by the Australian Lot Feeders' Association.

However, the Government will request the Subcommittee on Animal Welfare, which developed the Model Code, to give consideration to this recommendation when it is next revising the Model Code. Approved changes to the Model Code will be incorporated in future revised editions of the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia.
Recommendation

4.The Committee endorses the view presented in reports of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare and supported by RSPCA Australia, that State and Territory Governments gazette model codes of practice and guidelines endorsed by the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand to their respective legislation relating to prevention of cruelty to animals.
Supported in principle.
The Government recognises that there are both positive and negative aspects of including Codes of Practice in legislation. Areas of concern include

PARA.TAB: the possibility of pressure to lower the standards in the Codes to the lowest common denominator;
the risk of making standards inflexible;
the problem of encouraging compliance with the letter rather than the spirit of the law; and
the added cost of administration.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of legislation and regulation to embody and ensure compliance with Codes of Practice is a matter for State and Territory governments. However, the Government would welcome a consistent, standardised approach to animal welfare regulation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The National Guidelines and Animal Care Statements

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation

5.The Committee is concerned that the spirit of cooperation and goodwill that was evident in the development of the National Guidelines may be jeopardised by differing views about the form and content of Animal Care Statements. The Committee, therefore, calls on the Australian Lot Feeders Association and animal welfare organisations to resolve these differences.

On the basis of the evidence before it, the Committee endorses the concept of Animal Care Statements and their inclusion in the National Guidelines. In the Committee's view these statements are an effective way of ensuring that the health and welfare of cattle kept in feedlots are protected at all times.
Supported.

The Government endorses the concept of Animal Care Statements as an important self-regulatory means of ensuring the protection of the health and welfare of cattle kept in feedlots and encourages their adoption by all feedlots. In this context, the Government notes the proposed AUS-MEAT Feedlot Accreditation Scheme will require all accredited feedlots to submit an Animal Care Statement. The Government also notes that Queensland will make completion of an animal care statement a condition of licence for all existing and proposed feedlots, whether or not they seek AUS-MEAT accreditation. New South Wales will also seek completion of an animal care statement by all existing and proposed feedlots.

The form and content of the Animal Care Statement has been agreed to by welfare, government and industry representatives. The Standing Committee on Beef Cattle Feedlot Guidelines proposes to submit the draft Animal Care Statement to the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management for endorsement at its February 1994 meeting.
Recommendation

6.The Committee welcomes the formation of the National Feedlot Guidelines Standing Committee to monitor and review the implementation and application of the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia. The Committee regards this initiative as a clear indication of a continuing commitment to the development of the feedlot industry in a way that is both efficient and responsible.

The Committee is concerned that RSPCA Australia has not been included in the membership of the new standing committee, notwithstanding the representation of the Australian and New Zealand Federation of Animal Societies. In the Committee's view, the credibility of the standing committee would be enhanced by the inclusion in its membership of a representative of RSPCA Australia.

The Committee, therefore, recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in conjunction with the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand, consider further the membership of the National Feedlot Guidelines Standing Committee with a view to including a representative of RSPCA Australia.
Supported.

At its May 1993 meeting, the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management agreed to the expansion of the membership of the Standing Committee on Beef Cattle Feedlot Guidelines to include representatives of the RSPCA, local government and the Cattle Council of Australia.
Conclusion

7.The Committee welcomes the proposal by AUS-MEAT, entitled Feedlot Accreditation Scheme—A Quality Assurance System for Beef Feedlots in Australia, whereby only a feedlot that complies with industry standards, including environmental and animal welfare codes, and maintains quality requirements can have its product certified as grain fed for the domestic or export market. As was stated in evidence, one of the benefits of the scheme will be to force feedlots to lift performance or get out of the industry.

In the Committee's view, the proposal, which is similar to the successful AUS-MEAT Abattoir Accreditation Scheme, has considerable merit as it links accreditation with quality assurance and the commercial benefits of product description. The AUS-MEAT proposal is based on the principle of self regulation and, as such, provides the industry with a mechanism to prove itself to be "an acceptable and responsible corporate citizen in the management of a human food resource and the environment". If the industry fails to respond to the challenge of self regulation, the Committee considers that stringent government control and supervision may be necessary to ensure compliance with environmental and animal welfare standards.
Supported in principle.

The Government supports the principle of industry self-regulation inherent in the proposal for a feedlot accreditation scheme under the supervision of AUS-MEAT. The Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management also gave in-principle endorsement to the scheme at its May 1993 meeting and approved the establishment of a subcommittee of the Standing Committee on Beef Cattle Feedlot Guidelines to monitor the implementation of the scheme.

The Accreditation Scheme may, however, have limitations in its effectiveness in monitoring the performance of some smaller opportunity feedlots. These feedlots are transient by nature, making it difficult to develop an effective monitoring mechanism for their operation. In these cases, the Government will encourage the education of farmers and small lot feeders about the adoption of best management practices to minimise their adverse environmental impacts under the umbrella of the Decade of Landcare.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Identifying and Monitoring levels of Foreign Investment

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

8.The Committee supports foreign investment in the Australian beef industry, particularly the lot feeding sector, but considers that investing companies should provide a commitment which benefits the long term interests of the Australian cattle producing sector.

The Committee notes the concerns of the Cattle Council of Australia about the increase in the investment threshold from $3 million to $50 million and associated monitoring procedures of the Foreign Investment Review Board. The Committee welcomes the advice of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that, as well as commenting on foreign investment proposals over $50 million, the Department is also notified of proposals over $3 million to enable it to monitor the level of foreign investment in the meat and livestock industry and in individual enterprises.
Supported.
The Government believes the availability of foreign capital offers positive advantages to the Australian meat and livestock industry, including:

PARA.TAB: the creation of a vested interest by overseas traders in sourcing meat or livestock from Australia;
encouraging investment in up-to-date technology at a faster rate than would be the case if industry were to rely solely on the domestic capital market; and
the development of a greater understanding between Australia and overseas interests in regard to trade and marketing.
