SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Primary Industries and Energy will continue to monitor foreign investment in the meat and livestock industry, including the feedlot sector, in light of producer concerns about the potential for foreign interests to achieve a dominant position and exert market power.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Regulation of Feedlots by the States and Territories

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation

9.The Committee's examination of the legislative and administrative arrangements indicates a spectrum of regulations for feedlots in the States and Territories, ranging from the comprehensive, to the piecemeal, to the very limited.

The Committee, therefore, endorses the view that State and Territory governments should act promptly to make the changes needed to implement the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia. In so doing, the Committee considers that State and Territory governments should introduce specific legislation for beef cattle feedlots and that the Queensland legislation provides a useful model.
Supported in principle.

While a State/Territory responsibility, the Government encourages the State and Territory governments to act promptly to make the appropriate changes needed to implement the principles contained in the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia. However, the Government recognises that in States and Territories with a small feedlot industry it may not be appropriate to introduce specific legislation for beef cattle feedlots.

The Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management has requested the State and Territory governments to provide feedback on initiatives taken to bring feedlot approval and monitoring processes into line with the principles contained in the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia.
Recommendation

10.The Committee finds it unsatisfactory that there is not a uniform definition of a feedlot based on a minimum number of cattle for the purposes of regulation. This lack of uniformity is reflected in the fact that in New South Wales, regulations governing feedlots are applied to operations of 400 head or more, while in Queensland the figure is 50 head and in Victoria no capacity limit is applied.

The Committee considers that a uniform definition of a feedlot, based on 50 head or more, should be adopted by all States and Territories in specific feedlot legislation proposed by this Committee. If this regulatory approach is adopted, the Committee considers that concerns relating to the potential impact of smaller feedlots will be alleviated.
Supported in principle.
The recommendation will be referred to the States and Territories for implementation as considered appropriate.
Conclusion

11.The Committee endorses the view that local government has a legitimate role in approval process for feedlot developments. The Committee considers, however, that when discharging responsibilities relating to approvals, local authorities must have access to detailed technical information and advice. It is only on this basis that proper and informed decisions can be made.

The Committee, therefore, welcomes the development of mechanisms in Queensland and New South Wales whereby the State government feedlot advisory units provide expert technical advice and information to local government.
Supported.

The Government encourages the other States and Territories, where appropriate, to develop mechanisms whereby the State government feedlot advisory units provide expert technical advice and information to local government.
Conclusion

12.The Committee notes the efforts of the Australian Lot Feeders Association to assure the community of the integrity of the industry, particularly through its involvement in the development of the National Guidelines and the total quality assurance program.

While recognising ALFA's contribution to these initiatives, the Committee nevertheless considers that ALFA should be adopting a more critical approach to its membership and to the industry as a whole in order to exert pressure on those feedlots that, in the words of the Association, "threaten the development of the entire industry". If self regulation is to be effective, the industry must be committed to excellence in every phase of the operations of feedlots.
Supported.

The Government endorses these views, but notes that as a voluntary organisation the Australian Lot Feeders' Association is limited in the power that it can exercise over its members. In the absence of these powers, the Government believes the appropriate influence can be exerted through the proposed AUS-MEAT Feedlot Accreditation Scheme.
Recommendation
13.The Committee considers that responsible management of feedlots is essential and should be enhanced by education, training and extension services.

The Committee recommends that Commonwealth, State and Territory governments, industry organisations and individual feedlots, recognise education and training as an essential component of responsible management of feedlots and promote appropriate programs. In the Committee's view, this is an aspect of feedlot operations in which the Australian Lot Feeders Association can take a leading role.
Supported.

The Government recognises that education and training are essential components of responsible feedlot management. The Government shares with industry the funding of the Meat Research Corporation which has in place several programs aimed at developing professional management practices in feedlots. These programs include an extension component for all parties involved in the industry, from producers to local government.

The Government believes that the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia and the National Water Quality Management Strategy (NWQMS) provide the policy principles for promoting best management practices in feedlots. The Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment provides an avenue for the Commonwealth to pursue the adoption of the principles and environmental objectives articulated in these documents with the States and Territories. The Commonwealth will also encourage the education of producers and feedlotters about the adoption of best management practices to minimise the adverse impacts of these activities under the umbrella of the Decade of Landcare.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Community Perceptions of the Feedlot Industry

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

14.It is clear from the evidence that several factors, including the much publicised death of several thousand feedlot cattle in Queensland, have tarnished the public image of the industry. The industry is fully aware of the situation and advised the Committee that it is making a concerted effort to improve the industry's standing with the public. The Committee, however, is in no doubt that community perceptions will not improve unless each feedlot is sensitive to the local and wider community and responsive to concerns about the environment and animal welfare.
The Committee acknowledges the efforts of some feedlots to inform the public about their operations, thereby increasing understanding of the industry.
Supported.

The Government believes community involvement and consultation in making decisions in relation to the development and siting of feedlots will also help to improve the industry's standing with the public. In this context, the Government notes that the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia provide for public participation in the decision making process for feedlot proposals.
Recommendation

15.The Committee was told on numerous occasions that feedlots have a significant potential to pollute but did not receive assurances that the actual environmental impact of feedlots is minimal, because there is insufficient information on the matter. In this regard, the Committee notes that the report entitled An Investigation of Nutrient Pollution in the Murray-Darling Basin River System found that nutrient balances provide no obvious indication of any substantial pollution from feedlots but recognised that this finding is based on very limited data and therefore is inconclusive.

The lack of information available about the environmental impact of feedlots in Australia is of great concern to the Committee. The absence of comprehensive, accurate or specific information has hampered significantly the ability of this inquiry to make judgements about the environmental performance of the feedlot industry, or recommendations for change. It is the Committee's view that this dearth of information also has important implications for the ability of feedlot operators and regulatory authorities to predict with assurance the impact of proposed feedlot developments and to measure the actual impact of the industry as a whole.

To address the problem, the Committee recommends two courses of action by industry and government. First, the Committee urges the Australian Lot Feeders Association, having regard to commercial confidentiality, to provide data and other technical information that would assist regulatory authorities, researchers and public inquiries to aspects of environmental impact. The Committee considers that positive responses to requests for information and data will encourage confidence in the community that the industry is more than willing to be scrutinised.
Supported.
The Government urges the industry to provide data and other technical information that would assist regulatory authorities, researchers and public inquiries to assess aspects of environmental impact.
Recommendation

16.Secondly, the Committee recommends that the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand sponsor a comprehensive environmental audit of all feedlots in Australia, including opportunity feedlots, to gather information about facilities, management practices, conditions of license and of breaches of those conditions. The Committee further recommends that the information gained by such an audit be used to further refine the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia and the ALFA Code of Practice for Protection of the Environment.
Supported in principle.
The Government supports the principle of gathering information on the environmental performance of feedlots.

The proposed AUS-MEAT Feedlot Accreditation Scheme will gather comprehensive information on the environmental performance of those feedlots taking part in the Scheme. The implementation of the Scheme will be subject to monitoring by the Standing Committee on Beef Cattle Feedlot Guidelines.
However, it would not be practical to attempt to audit all small opportunity feedlots, given their transitory nature and the consequent difficulty in locating them.

The Government believes it is important to practically address the potential environmental impacts of these small feedlots and considers a more appropriate method of dealing with this problem is through encouraging the adoption of best management practices by farmers and small lot feeders. This can be achieved through the approaches to resource management embodied in the policies and principles of the National Water Quality Management Strategy and the principles and national goals of the Decade of Landcare Plan. The Government will seek the cooperation of the States and Territories to incorporate the issue of proper management of small feedlots in their priorities through the Partnership Agreements under the National Landcare Program.

The Meat Research Corporation is funding research aimed at measuring and improving the environmental performance of feedlots and abattoirs. The Corporation has budgeted to spend $3.25 million on this program over the years 1991-92 to 1995-96.

The Government would expect that the findings of the Meat Research Corporation research and the information gathered through the AUS-MEAT accreditation scheme will be used to refine the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia and would encourage their incorporation in the ALFA Code of Practice for Protection of the Environment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Research on the Environmental Impact of Feedlots

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation

17.The Committee considers that specific research relating to the environmental impact of feedlots will assist the industry and government to refine requirements for facilities and to adapt management practices. The Committee, therefore, recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand, identify and fund research programs on the environmental impact of feedlots.
Supported in principle.

The Meat Research Corporation is funding research into the environmental impact of feedlots and abattoirs. The aim of the program is to facilitate the capacity of the feedlot and abattoir sectors to competently meet emerging environmental threats and comply with current and anticipated legislative arrangements using cost effective solutions. The program will, by 30 June 1996:

PARA.TAB: collate and disseminate existing good environmental practice information;
improve knowledge of the industry's existing environmental performance; and
identify or develop and trial appropriate waste minimisation and treatment technologies.

SPEECH.PARA: The program consists of 17 projects with a budget of $3.25 million.
The Cattle and Beef Industry Cooperative Research Centre, partially funded by the Government, is also planning research into feedlot waste management.
This recommendation will be passed to the Meat Research Corporation and the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation.
Recommendation

18.The Committee notes the development of the Code of Practice for Protection of the Environment by the Australian Lot Feeders Association. The Committee, however, considers that an environmental management plan, recommended by the Code, needs to be more than a mere check list of minimum requirements. In this regard, the Committee concurs with the view expressed by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories that meaningful environmental guidelines for feedlots must include a set of environmental objectives against which performance can be measured.
As compliance with environmental standards will be a principal element of the proposed accreditation scheme for feedlots, the need for comprehensive guidelines becomes more pressing.
Supported.

The Government supports the development of a mechanism to ensure adequate protection of environmental values, but would be concerned if the guidelines were too prescriptive to prevent flexibility in dealing with the environmental and water quality objectives of different geographical locations in Australia.

National guidelines are being developed under the National Water Quality Management strategy to provide a nationally consistent approach to managing the nation's water resources in accordance with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. The national guidelines will provide the basis for the States and Territories to develop more detailed guidelines, including water quality objectives and management and implementation plans, taking into consideration the local situation or circumstances.
Conclusion
19.The Committee recognises that there are problems associated with odour from some feedlots that are incorrectly sited or not properly managed.

Although it accepts the contention of the Australian Lot Feeders Association that it is impossible to eliminate completely odour from feedlots, the Committee considers that with sound management practices the problem of odour can be minimised. The Committee is of the view that levels of odour must be controlled so that they do not cause nuisance and lower community amenity. In this regard, the Committee welcomes research being undertaken in New South Wales and Queensland on the management of odour.
Supported.

The Government agrees that odour levels form feedlots should be minimised. The Government notes that odour management is part of the Meat Research Corporation and the Cattle and Beef Industry Cooperative Research Centre research programs.
Recommendation

20.Although recognising that the survey on feedlot drainage systems, conducted in 1990, was based on a small sample, the Committee is concerned that proper attention is not being paid to waste management infrastructure in feedlots. The Committee considers that detailed information on effluent management systems of feedlots need to be gathered and suggests that this should be part of the more general environmental audit of feedlots recommended earlier in this report.
Supported.

As noted in recommendation 16, there are practical difficulties in carrying out the audit recommended by the Committee. Effluent management will be an integral part of the AUS-MEAT Accreditation Scheme, and the research being funded by the Meat Research Corporation to measure and improve the environmental performance of feedlots and abattoirs includes projects aimed at improving feedlot designs and developing better waste management practices.

Research into the development of better waste management practices is consistent with the National Waste Minimisation and Recycling Strategy, launched by the Government in June 1992. The Government continues to encourage research into, and where feasible promotion of, innovative waste management practices that are compatible with sound environmental management.
The Government will also request the States and Territories to incorporate the issue of best management practices in small feedlots in their priorities for activities under the Decade of Landcare.
Conclusion

21.The Committee welcomes the efforts of the Queensland and New South Wales Governments to upgrade the environmental performance of those older and smaller feedlots that may not have been subject to planning approval or licensing processes and commends their approach to other States. The Committee reiterates its view that the introduction of specific legislation applying to feedlots of 50 or more head of cattle will allay concerns associated with older and smaller feedlots.
Supported.

The Government encourages all States and Territories to upgrade the environmental performance of those older and smaller feedlots that may not have been subject to planning approval or licensing processes. The Committee's comments will be referred to the States and Territories.
Conclusion

22.Having reviewed the evidence on the welfare of cattle in feedlots, the Committee rejects the view that lot feeding of cattle is unnatural and should be prohibited. The Committee is of the view that lot feeding of beef cattle is a legitimate husbandry tool. However, because of the nature of this intensive husbandry system, high standards must be applied to all facets of feedlot operations particularly siting, design and management practices, in order to ensure the health and welfare of cattle.
Supported.

The Government concurs that lot feeding of beef cattle is a legitimate husbandry tool and agrees that high standards must be applied to all facets of feedlot operations particularly siting, design and management practices to ensure the health and welfare of cattle.
Recommendation

23.The Committee notes problems in feedlots associated with excessive heat load syndrome and recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy examine ways in which funding may be made available for Australian research into the physiology and behaviour of feedlot cattle and, in particular, heat stress.
Supported in principle.

As previously advised, Government funding of research and development in the rural sector is channelled through primary industry research and development corporations. The Government notes that the Meat Research Corporation is funding comprehensive research into feedlot shade requirements and heat stress related factors in feedlots.
The recommendation will be passed to the Meat Research Corporation.
Conclusion

24.The Committee is persuaded by the evidence it received that the provision of shade and shelter enhances the welfare of beef cattle in feedlots by alleviating stresses associated with extreme climatic conditions. In particular, the Committee is convinced that cattle held in feedlots situated in hot climates must have access to suitable shade. This is not to say, however, that the provision of shade should abrogate other management responsibilities relating to nutrition and feed control.

The Committee considers that the need to provide shade and shelter should be based on the health and welfare of cattle in feedlots and not on cost. The Committee notes, however, that individual feedlots in several States and regions have decided to install shade or shelter because of the economic benefits gained from the enhanced well being of the cattle.

The Committee welcomes the shade research project that is being funded by the Meat Research Corporation and undertaken by NSW Agriculture. Upon the completion of the project, the Committee considers that the results and findings should be published and widely disseminated. The Committee is disappointed that the design, construction and attributes of the shade facilities installed at Whyalla Feedlot in Queensland are not being trialled as part of the research project and encourages those concerned to examine the possible benefits of this innovative approach.
Supported in principle.

The Government agrees that shelter and shade should be provided in feedlots where appropriate. However, the Government is concerned that such requirements should be scientifically supported and believes definitive conclusions about the need for shade in various climatic zones should await the outcomes of the Meat Research Corporation funded shade research project.
The Government understands the Meat Research Corporation project is near completion and the results will be made publicly available.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Use of Chicken Litter as a Feed

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation
25.The Committee considers that the current situation in relation to the use of chicken litter is confusing and must be clarified in the interests of all feedlots in Australia.

Based on the evidence presented during the inquiry, the Committee considers that the approach of the Australian Lot Feeders Association and the Queensland Government to ban the use of chicken litter as a feed for cattle in feedlots should be followed by all States and Territories.
Supported.

The Government would be concerned if a legitimate stockfeed additive was banned for use on aesthetic grounds rather than on the basis of sound scientific evidence. Chicken litter is widely used as a feed additive in the feedlot industry throughout the world and is acceptable if correctly processed.

However, the Government acknowledges that the marketing implications of the adverse publicity generated by the deaths of cattle caused by botulism occasioned from the use of contaminated chicken litter has left the industry in a difficult position in relation to the continued use of the product. The recommendation will be referred to the States and Territories.

The Government will also request the Subcommittee on Animal Welfare to give consideration to the removal of the inconsistency between the body of the Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals—Cattle and the appended Code of Practice for Cattle Welfare in Feedlots developed by the Australian Lot Feeders' Association.
Recommendation

26.The Committee is surprised that the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia do not reflect the importance of animal welfare as a consideration for site selection of a feedlot and recommends that the Guidelines be revised accordingly.
Supported in principle.

The Government's view is that the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia do include animal welfare as an important consideration for site selection of a feedlot. Section 2 of the Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals—Cattle states "The design, location and construction of feedlot and/or a feedpad should take account of topography, climate, age and size of animals to be fed, space and feed requirements, and labour and management skills available."

Additionally, the Approval Process Guidelines provide that "The elected Local Government Authority is generally the appropriate body to give the head approval with input from relevant experts, agencies and the public. This head decision should be made having considered the full range of social, economic, environmental and animal welfare concerns, before any other licences or permissions are approved."
The recommendation will be passed to the Standing Committee on Beef Cattle Feedlot Guidelines for consideration at the National Feedlot Guidelines Workshop, to be reconvened in 1994.
Conclusion

27.Evidence to the Committee confirms that stress, disease and behavioural problems can be minimised if cattle in feedlots are able to fulfil their behavioural requirements. Pen space, therefore, is an important factor in meeting these requirements.

The Committee notes that animal welfare organisations, industry and government bodies have proposed varying minimum requirements for pen size, ranging from 9m(2) to 25m(2) per animal. The Committee's view is that the minimum pen space of 9m(2), recommended by the Australian Lot Feeders Association, is too small and considers that a minimum of 15m(2) to 20m(2) per animal, as recommended by the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare, will enhance the welfare of cattle in feedlots.
Supported in principle.

The appropriate forum for consideration of this recommendation is the Subcommittee on Animal Welfare (SCAW), which developed the Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals—Cattle. SCAW is due to revise the Model Code in 1995. Approved changes to the Model Code will be incorporated in future revised editions of the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia. The Government notes that the Model Code provides for a minimum yard space of 9m(2)/head, but recommends 15m(2)/head.
The Government will request SCAW to give consideration to this recommendation when it is next revising the Model Code.
Recommendation

28.The Committee considers that professional veterinary services should be available to complement high standards of management and organisational skills of the staff employed by feedlots. The Committee, however, does not support the view that feedlots should employ full time veterinarians, unless the size of a feedlot warrants that level of service.
The Committee considers that every feedlot should have a close affiliation with a qualified veterinarian, involving arrangements for regular visits as well as "on call" services.

The Committee recommends that the National Guidelines for Beef Cattle Feedlots in Australia should be revised accordingly. The Committee also recommends that the Guidelines should recognise that qualified veterinary supervision is integral to the health and welfare of cattle in feedlots.
Supported in principle.
The recommendation will be passed to the Standing Committee on Beef Cattle Feedlot Guidelines for consideration at the National Feedlot Guidelines Workshop, to be reconvened in 1994.
Recommendation
29.The Committee notes that the Model Code of Practice for Welfare of Animals—Cattle is quite explicit on the handling of cattle. The Code states:
The people managing and handling cattle must be competent. The skills for managing and handling cattle include the ability to:

PARA.TAB: work so that stress to cattle is minimised;
use the natural behaviour of cattle; and
recognise the early signs of distress or disease and to initiate prompt and appropriate preventative or remedial action.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is of the view that the importance of these abilities and in particular the skill to recognise early signs of distress or disease cannot be over-emphasised in the context of a feedlot.

The Committee therefore encourages individual feedlots and the Australian Lot Feeders Association to initiate training programs to develop the skills and abilities of those who handle and manage cattle in feedlots.
Supported.

The Government endorses the Committee's recommendation that individual feedlots and the Australian Lot Feeders Association initiate training programs to develop the skills and abilities of those who handle and manage cattle in feedlots.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, I welcome the government's response to the committee's report on beef cattle feedlots. In particular, I note its support for 28 of the 29 recommendations or major conclusions contained in the committee's report. The committee tabled its report in December 1992 and unanimously recorded its support for the development of the industry, but considered that it must be properly regulated, ecologically sustainable and sensitive and responsive to community concerns.

PARA.TAB: The government response sets out in detail the work that has been done, and will be done, to achieve these objectives, including the recent introduction of an Aus-meat feedlot accreditation scheme. National guidelines for beef cattle feedlots in Australia have also been developed and endorsed by all levels of government, the lot feeding industry and animal welfare groups. I welcome the government's support for those recommendations made by the committee to fine-tune these guidelines and the model code of practice for welfare of animals.

In relation to environmental concerns, the committee noted that feedlots should not pose a threat to the environment if they are properly designed, managed and regulated. However, the committee expressed concerns that more research needs to be done on the environmental impact of feedlots. In this regard, I particularly welcome the government's response that the Meat Research Corporation is funding research into the environmental impact of feedlots and abattoirs. I understand this program of research will consist of 17 projects with a budget of $3.25 million. By June 1996 it aims to collate and disseminate existing good environmental practice information; improved knowledge of the industry's existing environmental performance; and identify or develop and trial appropriate waste minimisation and treatment technologies.

I consider that the committee's inquiry into beef cattle feedlots was timely and its recommendations practical and constructive. I hope that the committee's work in this area will encourage a strong, viable, responsible and internationally competitive beef cattle feedlot industry.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs tabled this report in December 1992, as the chairman, Senator Burns, has already said, following 12 months of investigation, during which time we received 27 submissions, conducted eight public hearings, took evidence from 44 witnesses and visited 10 feedlots, from Texas in the north to Wangaratta in the south.

PARA.TAB: We restricted our inquiry to beef feedlots, although the actual reference was simply to lot feeding in Australia. The committee was of the view that dairy feedlots—there is one at Broken Hill; it is an outstanding feedlot—involved different criteria, and the majority of submissions received related to beef feedlots, in any event.

The government response today is largely supportive of the committee's findings. That does not surprise me, as it should not surprise anyone involved in the inquiry. The recommendations we made were sound and appropriate for the development of an industry that has significantly contributed to the export wealth of this country. It is a major player in the domestic beef industry and an example of agricultural value adding—the rural buzz word of the 1990s. It is quite interesting that this committee, of which Senator Burns is chairman and I am deputy chairman, is now going to hold an inquiry into value adding in Australia.

I do not wish to traverse in detail the entire committee report and the government's response. They are on the public record for anyone who wishes to have a look at them and for anyone who is interested. However, I do wish to comment on some of the recommendations.

I am disappointed that the government did not appreciate the area of conflict currently existing between the national guidelines for beef cattle feedlots in Australia and the model code of practice for the welfare of animals—cattle. One could argue the relevance of model codes and how well they are adhered to in any situation. It is probably true to say that the large scale feedlots are so controlled in any event as not to breach the model code. However, there is still potential for substandard husbandry in opportunity feedlots—those feedlots run by farmers on their properties to take advantage of particular market situations.

I am encouraged that at least the government has referred the matter to the appropriate committee for consideration when the code is next revised. I am pleased the government has responded to the committee's suggestion to include the RSPCA on the committee which will look into national feedlot guidelines. I also welcome the involvement in that committee of the Cattle Council of Australia and local government representatives. I am also pleased that producer concerns about the large involvement of foreign investment in Australia's feedlot industry—notably that of the Japanese—will continue to be monitored. There is no denying that we need their investment but it must be mutually beneficial. In relation to that issue, we need to make sure not of the amount of foreign investment we have here but the amount of competition flowing from that foreign investment both in Australia and in different countries.

I also endorse the involvement of local government in feedlot development. It is, after all, local government that has to contend with local complaints about noise, effluent, traffic, the building of roads for feedlots and so on. Local government must maintain the roads surrounding the feedlots. Of course, those roads get a great deal more use when feedlots are installed. To that end, local government and other authorities must be kept informed of the environmental impacts feedlots have on the community.

To date, technical data has been scanty and vague. The long-term implications relating to the siting of some feedlots are not being monitored. The committee has recommended that the Australian Agricultural Council sponsor a comprehensive environmental audit which the government has endorsed in principle. An important point to be borne in mind is that when local councils build feedlots in their areas they are not taxed out of existence. Local councils recognise that feedlots produce income for their district. One must also recognise that they bring employment to the districts which can only be beneficial. Therefore, local councils must give help to the feedlots to make sure that those benefits adhere to that district.

The economic significance of the feedlot industry cannot be over emphasised; it has altered the face of agriculture irrevocably. It is currently estimated that there are 480,000 cattle in feedlots throughout Australia, and there are 1,000 feedlots in Australia at the moment. While the capacity of feedlots to produce cattle is now in excess of 550,000, about 1.1 million cattle now go through feedlots every year in Australia. By the turn of the century that figure will rise to a million cattle in feedlots at any one time, with sales out of those feedlots of around two million head of cattle. So there will be great expansion. Some $800 million worth of gross value of production is now coming out of those feedlots. It will help our exports and every other part of the beef industry.

On that issue, I think we have to be mindful of the fact that the Australian Lotfeeders Association has requested the Meat Research Corporation to investigate the quantity of cattle and grain that will be available in the year 2000 to sustain the industry. The markets will be there, and it is very important that we make sure that there will be enough grain and enough cattle to fulfil that aim. We should prepare for that now.

Another part of the equation will be the role that the cooperative research centres, such as the one in Armidale, play in monitoring consumer demand. Monitoring consumer demand has been pursued exceptionally well by this industry; it has done a much better job in that regard than a lot of other industries. It is very important that this effort continues.

The feedlot industry has affected the types of cattle being bred, methods of selling and the volume of crops grown for the feedlot industry. Their economic significance cannot be overstated. In praise of Australia's beef cattle producers I have to say that they have responded magnificently to this new industry. A number of cattle breeds and, more importantly, cross-breeds are being developed especially for the feedlot industry and the Japanese trade. It has provided a wonderful floor to the industry and is responsible for the particularly buoyant outlook for cattle, as indicated in the ABARE conference last month.

The perennial argument about grass-fed versus grain-fed and saleyards versus direct selling will not be resolved in the short term and indeed that may never happen. However, the development and expansion of the feedlot industry has undoubtedly made an indelible mark on the Australian beef industry. There is now more direct selling now and more bypassing of the saleyards. Once the cattle have gone into a feedlot and the money has been spent on them, they are handled with kid gloves so that there is no bruising, no stress to the animals so that the meat on the hoof at that particular stage gets to the abattoirs in top condition and in order.

Husbandry in the feedlots that we visited deserves our commendation. The aim is to look to the interests of the animals and also to the profit at the end of the process. Bruising has been reduced to an absolute minimum as a result of feedlots. We now produce beef to specification for just about any market anywhere in the world. I would like to think we can produce beef better than anyone else, but of course cattlemen in the United States and South America make the same claim.

Australia seeks to produce meat at a most affordable price. What worries me, however, is that, despite the cost, meat consumption in Australia is static at around 36 kilograms a head and has fallen over the last ten years. This is a great pity. The AMLC is concerned at the static number, and one can only assume that if it did not pursue a massive promotional campaign, the consumption rate would fall even further.

The question asked at the ABARE conference was: why does the consumption rate remain low? The answer given was that until consistency is achieved in taste and tenderness, people will continue to buy chicken and other alternatives. By the way, I do have a pecuniary interest: I breed beef. I make that clear to any honourable senators who have any illusions that I do not. Beef producers and processors need to be aware of those market criticisms and address them. The process must involve moving to a better description scheme, brands or some other form of identification so that butchers know in every case where the meat they buy came from, otherwise buyer resistance will continue.

The feedlot industry, however, has provided an opportunity for the retail sector to sell consistent beef product, just as the chicken industry is consistent with its product. It is now the responsibility of others in the beef industry to work more closely to benefit. If housewives in Japan are able to buy first-grade consistent product, so too should Australian housewives. That they are not able to indicates a breakdown in the system. The technology and the feedback are available. To a large extent, we have the advent of the feedlot industry to thank for that. The feedlot industry will never entirely supplant the grass-fed beef industry, but it creates an enormous expansion of choices for producers. Therefore, the feedlot industry should be supported.

I welcome the government's response to our report and I am encouraged by its positive approach. I wish the industry well because we in Australia handle value adding very well. Now that the government has not bent to the arguments put forward by some of the environmental minority groups, it is supporting an industry that is doing a great job. It is to be hoped that the industry will go on to bigger and better things to produce income for Australia, a better standard of living and a better standard of animal welfare care for all animals in those feedlots in future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

There is only one issue that I would wish to address today and specifically bring to the attention of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. That relates to the activities for the operation to and from the Tiwi islands of the Tiwi barge services. This is highlighted on page 16 of the report where there is comment on those particular activities.

I have had representations in the Northern Territory that the Tiwi barge enjoys quite a considerable franchise with regard to the operation of freight services to the Tiwi islands. That is important, and I respect that commercial development, but at the same time I would hope that ATSIC grants to various Aboriginal organisations are not predicated on the exclusive use of the Tiwi barge only.

We must always ensure that the competitive market place properly applies, and that other barge operators and other freight services are not frozen out because of the availability of backup for government grants to various operating organisations through their subsidy programs and subsidy met programs at the expense of the grants flowing to other organisations which have some exclusive use.

This is an area that I would ask ATSIC to consider and monitor very closely. But in all other respects, whether it is in the area of tourism, pastoral operations, the forest operations or the pearling operation, it is very pleasing to see the inter-relationships of the Tiwi island people, and the involvement of the Department of Employment, Education and Training in many of these programs.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a significant and important report. Because of the focus of this Senate in the last 12 months on many issues either arising from appropriations for Aboriginal and Islander people, or alternatively, in dealing with the legislation that related to native title last year, it has been a most important year.

PARA.TAB: I would also highlight that 1993 was the Year of Indigenous People, and therefore much activity flowed, and much attention was attracted to this particular portfolio. The report of ATSIC is comprehensive, and in this five minutes I cannot do justice to the areas that I would like to comment on. In particular, I would like to commend the work of the commissioners and the staff of ATSIC in dealing with what is obviously a hard and comprehensive series of changes that are going on in the Australian community at this time.

We are all well aware of the initiatives of the government that have been backed up by this parliament in the necessary areas of priorities for reconciliation in our community and, at the same time, the other activities and responsibilities that must be attracted to ATSIC.

As I am sure many of my colleagues on all sides and within all parties of the parliament would agree, we cannot expect activity in the Aboriginal and Islander portfolio not to be without controversy. Change can only be achieved in this portfolio by pushing many of the issues through controversial debate and through extensive consultation with Aboriginal and Islander people.

The one area that I would choose to focus on in the few minutes available to me here is the program generally known as CDEP, the community development and employment project scheme which was introduced in 1977. This scheme has expanded in recent years with a lot of government largess, but at the same time it is important to focus on the effectiveness of it. In general I would praise most of the projects that have been accepted and adopted, and the efforts of many Aboriginal people throughout Australia in that area.

But again, it is not without controversy and it is not without the deserving need to concentrate on the areas that need criticism or need critical comment in much of that program. I would suggest that in many of the areas of the CDEP scheme there needs to be an involvement of a joint venture arrangement, either with state and territory governments or alternatively with many operators in commercial ventures throughout Australia. Only when we can introduce the skills and the talents that are available in the wider community into such an important area of employment and projects, can Aboriginal people fully benefit from such a scheme.

I would draw attention to the many pages in the report that refer to all of the evaluations, the audits and the schemes that impact on CDEP. They are important. I would highlight in particular the table on page 42 of the annual report which schedules and sets out the undertakings of the types of activity undertaken across the various divisions of the state regional areas, and then the activities.

I do highlight that in that particular schedule much of the focus is on what I would term a non-commercial bias or activity in employment. Therefore, I hope that ATSIC will be open to the challenge of reorienting much of that schedule away from areas—and I am not criticising them—where the major focus is on women's activities, youth activities, administration, child care, providing a garbage collection and health services.

These are necessary local government and municipal functions, but in turn they do not produce a new dollar. Employment in those areas does not generate dollars for the benefit of Aboriginal people. I would like to see the scope of much of the CDEP focused into the areas of park rangers, pastoral leases, retail, wholesale, tourism, furniture making, and market gardening—areas which I would identify as being important and which have a much more commercially oriented focus.

There are many other matters that I would like to comment on in this report, in particular areas such as rural industries around Australia and the reviews that are under way. I am aware that ATSIC has recently commissioned a major and expensive consultation on the whole area of land management. It certainly needs a lot more attention, but in general this report is a faithful and proper report on the activities of ATSIC for the financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend this report and seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Central Land Council organisation operates essentially in the central to lower regions of the Northern Territory and is administratively based in Alice Springs. The number of communities on which its activities impact is very large. The council covers the areas bounded by the Western Australian, South Australian and Queensland borders.

PARA.TAB: I note that, probably for the first time in a number of years, this report has taken a particular emphasis. In past years I have commented that the annual reports of the Central Land Council have been very appropriate and have appeared to be administratively correct with the council carrying out its functions of looking after its constituency interests of the Aboriginal people in Central Australia.

A lot of the focus in this report for 1992-93, whether it is the authors that are involved or whether it is a shift in emphasis or change of people involved, now largely reflects a very political view. There are quite a number of comments, I would say, that take swipes at and criticise the Northern Territory government without, I would argue, good and just reason and without the balance of activity that I would like to have seen. I am disappointed that the Central Land Council has moved in that direction. This sort of commentary was generally reflected for a number of years in the reports of the Northern Land Council. I hope that it is not just a matter of a few staff changes where staff have transferred from one place to another and suddenly we end up with a report that does not achieve its objective.

These reports should be a reflection on the activity of the important organisations that they serve. They should reflect the efficiency of the administration across so many areas that are inter-involved, and it should be accepted that the land councils are not in themselves political organisations. They are not alternative levels of government; they do not have municipal or local government functions. They ought not to be imposing into the area of state or territory-type politics.

To a certain extent it is interesting to note the number of Labor politicians whose photos appear in both the report of the Central Land Council and the Northern Land Council this year. Of course, whilst I am sure many state and territory ministers, and perhaps opposition members and senators also, had consultations or detailed discussions with these organisations, there is not a visual accreditation of that side of it. Rather, it is a trenchant criticism that I do not believe genuinely reflects much of the discussion that would happen at the level of the board of directors from the people that I know with whom I have had many valuable and appreciated discussions throughout the year.

I note that in the financial sections once again the Central Land Council has reported very properly on the areas relating to royalty payments, et cetera, that flow. This of course is important. In the area of finances, both the Central Land Council and the Northern Land Council reports, the latter of which I hope to comment upon shortly, rely very heavily on additional top-up funds that have been made available to these organisations in addition to the statutory rights that they receive under the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account from mining royalties. But the extent to which their administration has blown out beyond all proportion, in this case some $3 million to $4 million beyond what is statutorily provided, is at the expense of development in other Aboriginal organisations or for other Aboriginal people. To that extent, I am disappointed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important report because it focuses primarily on the area of corporate activity and investment relationships that are undertaken by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation. In past years I have commented on the activities of this organisation, and I am pleased to note once again the very important focus on commercial developments that do have an employment related scope for Aboriginal and Islander participation. I know personally the chairman of this organisation, Gatjil Djerrkura of Nhulunbuy on the Gove Peninsula. Mr Djerrkura's commitment, along with a number of other commissioners, is reflected in a very satisfactory report.

PARA.TAB: It is important to note that the summary of investments that were undertaken in the financial year reflect investment approvals of some $33 million. That is very pleasing to note. In the review of the activities of this organisation again I am pleased, especially from a Northern Territory perspective, to note that much of the activity is diverse. In this case it reflects on participation in a goldmine at Mt Todd; in tourism participation at Nitmiluk Gorge, formerly known as the Katherine Gorge; in a fishing lodge on Bathurst Island; at the Kings Canyon Resort in Central Australia, which again has a major tourist focus; and in Alice Springs in a joint venture of Central Australian Aboriginal groups with the former proprietors to operate a motor vehicle dealership and service centre. Given the usage of motor vehicles by Aboriginal people in many remote communities, this sort of project is to be commended.

I feel that this is a very satisfactory report that ought to be noted. It should receive wide publicity, perhaps much wider publicity than a lot of the social commentary that is often attracted to this portfolio.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This trust account has received a great deal of political focus in the last 12 months. I have certainly continuously raised its activities and its financial dealings in the estimates committees. In May of last year a very serious report was produced through ATSIC and its audit offices by a consulting firm, Walter and Turnbull. What transpired was a discovery that reinforced many previous findings that had not been acted upon, that there had been a very serious depletion of the trust funds of this particular organisation. I think from recollection the depletion was in the order of $10 million, which is of course a major loss, given that the income from this trust account is derived almost entirely from mining royalties that are properly due as the personal and private property of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: The Walter and Turnbull report of May was subsequently followed up with a strategy that was developed by ATSIC and Walter and Turnbull, and that was reported to the September and October estimates committees. I am very critical of much of the administration of this particular trust account because the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, ought to have been aware for a number of years of the mucking about, which is the only way I can describe it, that happened with this very important area of activity.

The fact is that the advisory committee comprised the directors of the Central Land Council, the Northern Land Council and the regional director of ATSIC for the Northern Territory who had almost total control indirectly of this considerable trust fund in that period, and they allowed that serious erosion to happen. I have pointed out that both of those personnel from the CLC and the Northern Land Council have moved on. Mr Mick Dodson has moved on to become the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Social Justice Commissioner. I hope that the federal government absolutely scrutinises every activity that he undertakes and reviews them in light of the activities in which he had a culpable hand when allowing this very serious depletion of funds that is properly the property of Aboriginal people.

Mr David Ross, the past director of the Central Land Council, has recently taken up a senior ATSIC position in Canberra, and has therefore come out of the scene as well. I hope that part of the politics of those moves has been that the minister has seen it necessary to replace all three members of that advisory committee. Whether Mr Dodson or Mr Ross have gone to other jobs, or Mr Castine from ATSIC has disappeared out of the face of ATSIC, is indicative of the seriousness of this particular account.

We must not walk away from the very important requirements where there is an obligation of trust. It is similar to a solicitor operating a trust account. This is very much the personal property of Aboriginal people, and the fact that there was such a serious depletion of funds will mean for many years Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory will be denied access to proper grants for sport, which are terribly important.

Much of the activity of the Aboriginals Benefits Trust Account reflects on land management and funds that have been made available for the purchase of pastoral properties. In that area we must always ensure that it is not just the one-off grant of land, whether it is under the guise of a pastoral lease which then subsequently disappears off the operating viability of the pastoral estate but into an Aboriginal land estate, but a recurrent level of funding that will go on to support the community based areas that are so very important.

The report is dutiful in that it indicates the problem, but I do not believe it highlights the seriousness of the issues raised and the problems that were experienced by this trust account during the financial year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 23 February, on motion by Senator Panizza:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise to honourable senators that I am, once again, critical of the annual report of the Northern Land Council. For the last three or four years I have always risen at this point to express my concerns about much of the activity and the financial and administrative complexity of the Northern Land Council. Last financial year I had cause to raise some very serious issues in the Senate estimates with regard to the operation of the Northern Land Council. It is pleasing that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) found it necessary to institute a major inquiry by the Auditor-General into the activities of the council.

PARA.TAB: The Senate will be aware that that report was tabled in December 1993 and recommended some 52 areas of significant change to administration of the council. Also pleasing is that the new Director of the Northern Land Council, Mr Darrell Pearce, is grappling with each and every one of those recommendations. I wish him well. It is hoped that by the end of this financial year he will have the budget in some degree of order and all of the issues that were raised in the Auditor-General's report—which were very serious in nature across a whole range of activities—will be properly brought into view

Again, I am critical of the politicisation of much of the activity of the Northern Land Council. Under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, the Aboriginal councils have very specific administrative and proper constitutional representation needs for Aboriginal people. Both the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council far exceed the charter given to them under that organisation, and the politics would happen better in other places.

This report, like that of the Central Land Council, reflects much of that unnecessary political sniping and commentary based on the activities that many of these people are experiencing. I do not believe it is a reflection of the wide Aboriginal constituency to which they look to the land councils for a proper role. I am not denying the right for that political voice to be properly expressed and heard, but I do not believe it is through the agencies of these organisations. In that sense, the report reads much more like what should be on feature pages of weekend newspapers by appropriate Aboriginal leaders around Australia, and ought not be presented in parliamentary reports in such an editorial manner with political comment.

Once again, unfortunately, the audited statements of this particular organisation have had to be qualified by the auditor. This is a serious matter, particularly when it has gone on for a number of years and the auditors have found it necessary to qualify their report. It is an indictment on the auditors that they did not qualify their reports in past years sufficiently or adequately, because what arose in the December 1993 report into the Northern Land Council reflected on the administrators and bureaus of the land council, and very seriously on the ministers and those who must accept political responsibility in this area. But, when the auditors can call into account issues of capital expenditure, approving budget items by more that 20 per cent, and can note that the Northern Land Council distributed over $500,000 contrary to the disclosed intention, these are indeed serious matters of administration to be addressed.

Akin to my comments as to the Central Land Council, I note also that the top-up funding that was required for administrative purposes in this case of over $4 million for the Northern Land Council was at the expense of Aboriginal people throughout the northern part of Australia. That amount was required for administrative costs in addition to the $3.8 million allocated by statutory right under the legislation. In this financial year, the administration costs in this particular land council came to well within the order of $8.8 million.

It is noted also that there has been a very serious depletion in the cash flow and cash available to this land council. The accumulated fund in the balance sheet as at 30 June 1993 was over $2 million; this year it is down to $667,000. There has been a depletion in that particular account which is very considerable and demands urgent attention. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
