SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move the motion in the amended form that was circulated in the chamber yesterday, copies of which were given to party leaders earlier yesterday. I think that Senator Gareth Evans is prepared to give that leave because he forecast there would otherwise be a barren procedural debate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee for an Inquiry into Certain Government Accountability Matters, be appointed to examine and report, on or before 30 June 1994, on the following:
(a)the operation of the program now known as the Community Cultural, Recreational and Sporting Facilities Program, with particular reference to:

PARA.TAB: (i)the nature and extent of the respective roles of the administering Department and Minister and his/her advisers and staff in the process of selection of successful applications; and
(ii)the role of the bureaucracy and in particular the administering Department and the Department of Finance in safeguarding against fraud and political bias; and
(iii)the role of the Auditor-General in safeguarding against fraud and political bias; and

(b)with respect to the future administration of similar programs, any safeguards or guidelines which might be put in place to ensure proper accountability for the expenditure of public moneys, including:

TAB.TAB: (i)examples of successful programs;
(ii)standard principles to be adopted in selection procedures;
(iii)the availability of documented reasons for decisions; and

SPEECH.PARA: (iv)the improvement of current auditing procedures.
(2)That the Committee consist of seven senators, as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a)two nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)three nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and

PARA.TAB: (c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(d)one nominated by the Greens (WA) and Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: (3)That:
(a)the committee appoint a Commissioner to assist it with its inquiry;
(b)the Commissioner be a person who is or has been a judge of a superior court, or is or has been a Senior Counsel;

PARA.TAB: (c)the committee is to act in accordance with the following principles:

SPEECH.PARA: (i)that it at all times take care to protect, so far as it is proper and reasonable to do so, the privacy, confidentiality, rights and reputations of individuals, whether appearing as witnesses before the Committee or otherwise; and

(ii)that it summon witnesses to appear personally only when satisfied that the circumstances demand it, that, so far as is possible, witnesses be given notice of the matters proposed to be dealt with, and that witnesses be given an opportunity to reply in writing before appearing to give evidence; and

(iii)that it give specific consideration in the case of each proposed witness to the desirability of hearing evidence in camera, if it is proper and reasonable to do so, and that each witness be given an opportunity to apply for any or all of his or her evidence to be given in private.
(4)That the Committee proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5)That:

PARA.TAB: (a)the chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee;
(b)in the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair shall be determined by the Senate;
(c)the deputy-chair of the committee be appointed from time to time by the chair from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair;

SPEECH.PARA: (d)That the deputy-chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting; and

PARA.TAB: (e)in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy-chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

SPEECH.PARA: (6)That the quorum of the committee be four members.

(7)That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(8)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(9)That the terms of reference of the inquiry be appropriately advertised in the media and members of the public be invited to make written and/or verbal submissions to the committee on matters related to the reference.

(10)That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(11)That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(12)That the committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

Part (1)(a) is something of an abbreviation of the previous terms relating to past administration practices but part (1)(b) is expanded to deal with future administration practices, which we regard as a very important aspect of this inquiry. Other changes to the terms of the motion we are now debating are that the committee consist of seven senators, broken up as set out in the motion circulated, and that the committee be supported by a commissioner who is or has been a judge of a superior court or is or has been a senior counsel. The purpose of that is to ensure objectivity and, from the point of view of the public analysis of the work of the committee, to ensure that the public is confident that the findings are not driven by political motivation.

PARA.TAB: The judge or senior counsel could play a prominent role in the examination of witnesses and in advising the committee on areas of its inquiry and on its findings. In fact, I would hope that the committee would invite the judge to put findings of his own into the record of the committee's determination. In other words, I would hope that the report of the committee would include an independent assessment of the facts by this judge or senior counsel.

This is a very serious matter because we are determining the proper response of the Senate to what amounts to a prima facie case of political corruption. We believe that evidence now before the parliament would lead an objective person to come to no other conclusion than that this particular program was not motivated by the objective of helping communities in the development of their facilities but was primarily motivated by the intention of the ALP to use public funds for political benefit. I put it to the Senate that when one looks at the materials that have now come out of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts and at the materials that were available earlier that came out of the estimates committee and other inquiries of this Senate—I will run through some of that material shortly—there is no other real conclusion that one can reach.

If that is correct, what action should the Senate take? The government is putting to us and to the Australian people that it has been brought to account already in that a minister, Mrs Kelly, has resigned; that the parliament should therefore be satisfied and the matter forgotten. In many ways, the attitude of the government was demonstrated by the action of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in putting the architect of this scheme, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Richardson), the only other minister who had administered this scheme, back in charge when Mrs Kelly resigned. That demonstrates that there is no acknowledgment on the part of the government that there is anything for which it must publicly account at all.

If we accept that attitude, then, in our opinion, the Senate would be abdicating one of its primary responsibilities; that is, to do everything reasonably possible to bring the government to account for improper conduct in the administration of the public purse. We believe it would be a very disappointing day if the Senate did not pick up the challenge clearly before it to analyse the material that we say amounts to political corruption. If the committee and the judge appointed to the committee are of the conclusion that it did amount to political corruption, they must say so, and allow the public to require a proper accounting by the government for its misconduct.

I remind the Senate of the responsibility of the parliament. I do that by making two references. One comes from the first page of the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts—which part, I suspect, was written by the officials rather than the Labor majority. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament must do all that it can to ensure that public monies are not only properly appropriated but that they are used in the most effective and efficient way possible in the best interest of the people.

That sentiment, which we totally support, is supported by the Auditor-General at page 2 of his letter of 9 February 1994 to the honourable member for Fraser, Mr Langmore, as chairman of the House of Representatives committee. He says:
Public confidence in the actions of ministers requires that the propriety of their decisions is seen to be beyond reproach.
He continues:

You are very well aware that care needs to be taken to avoid anything which would weaken public confidence in the processes of government and which would result in damage to the standing of the Parliament as an effective reviewer—-on behalf of voters. . . This would raise the danger of reinforcing any cynicism in the community about the political process.

I think that sums it up well. It is clearly saying to the parliament, `You have a responsibility in this matter to take it to its logical end. Do not allow the government to avoid responsibility by taking the easy way out and accepting the resignation of a minister'.

PARA.TAB: Let me pursue that one step further. If the minister had resigned because of a finding of political corruption, that would be a different matter—but that is not what occurred. When we look at the committee of inquiry of the House of Representatives, which basically looked at the scheme as administered by Mrs Kelly—not what had gone on before in the administration of the scheme under Senator Richardson—we find that the majority of that committee were not even prepared to make a finding that she should be censured. All that the majority really said was that she was incompetent in relation to her administration.

The majority of that committee did not face up to the primary challenge that was before them of determining whether or not there was political corruption on the part of former Minister Kelly in the administration of this program. In effect, she was found guilty by the majority of not keeping adequate records to enable a proper accounting of the reasons for which she favoured one application over another. According to the majority of that committee, she should be criticised for that lack of proper accounting; for her maladministration. There is no doubt about that; but that was not the principal challenge before the committee.

The principal challenge that was before that committee, and is still before this parliament, is whether she was giving $30 million of taxpayers' money to certain groups in a way that was designed to maximise the political benefit to the ALP. I regret—but I guess it is a factor of the numbers in the House of Representatives—that the majority of the committee did not address that particular question.

I should take it one step further and say that the primary distinction between this place and the House of Representatives is that the government does not have the numbers in this place and it cannot get away with what it was able to get away with in the House of Representatives; that is, bringing down a report that although critical of her—no doubt that helped in the negotiations with the Australian Democrats—did not address the principal concern of the Australian people.

When one, however, looks at the political bias that is evident in the distribution of these funds, one is again reminded of that by the Auditor-General who picked up the allegations of political bias—as shown on page 10 of the Auditor-General's report No. 9—when he referred to the fact that Labor seats, which accounted for 53 per cent of the House of Representatives seats, received 73 per cent of the number of grants and 66 per cent of the value of grants approved. He said that, on average, the total value of grants to a Labor-held seat was $257,000 and to a coalition seat it was $141,000; and, on average, the total value of grants to a marginal Labor-held seat was $326,000 and to a coalition-held seat it was $163,000—facts that obviously caused the Auditor-General deep disquiet.

He nevertheless acknowledged that it might be possible that this prima facie evidence of political bias might be able to be explained away for some other reason, such as if it could be demonstrated that, astonishing though it may be, the grants did go to the areas of greatest need. The Auditor-General acknowledges that he had not done that task; in other words, he does not see it as his responsibility to go that one step further and make that assessment as to the motivation of this scheme and whether it is just being used by the government as an enormous slush fund for political advantage. But this parliament not only can but should do that task.

The dissenting report of the committee details a number of major shortcomings in the inquiry that took place in the House of Representatives. In particular, the dissenting members were concerned that the former departmental secretary, who was secretary during most of the period in which the fund operated, Mr Tony Blunn, was not called to evidence. The majority voted against calling him to give evidence. Ms Kaye Dal Bon, whom I will refer to in a minute, and who had been critical of the administration and what the department was being required to do, by the determination of the majority was also not called to give evidence; nor were Mr Phil Ruff and Mr Ken Bennett from the minister's staff, who had a key role in the ALP's marginal seats campaign.

It is a fascinating coincidence, Mr President, as you would no doubt have noted, that the person who had responsibility for the ALP's marginal seats campaign was Senator Richardson. We find that the chief staffer who had the responsibility for it was working on the staff of former Minister Kelly, advising her on the distribution of these funds which, by another incredible coincidence, seem so much to favour ALP marginal seats. He obviously should have been required to give evidence. However, the majority of the committee were not of that view.

Apart from the inquiry therefore being inadequate in that it did not call all available evidence to reach its conclusions—in other words, it made conclusions not on the full availability of evidence—it did not in the majority report address the other evidence of political bias that came out during the course of the inquiry. Page 5 of the dissenting minority report quite adequately lists many examples of that. In this debate today I do not want to go through them all but I have mentioned that three-quarters of the grants went to ALP seats, which seemed to be an amazing coincidence. I mentioned the fact that the quantum of each grant was much greater for ALP electorates and that the average value of grants to marginal Labor electorates was much higher than for other Labor electorates.

Let us remember that some of those other Labor electorates, the safe Labor electorates, contain the lowest incomes in our community. One would have thought, without any other evidence on the table, that they may well have had greater need and greater demand for these public funds than those that happen to be marginal Labor seats. Interestingly, in South Australia the metropolitan seat with the lowest per capita income would be Port Adelaide and probably the next lowest would be Bonython. Yet they received only approximately half the money—about $200,000—that was made available for each of the marginal Labor seats. Of them Hindmarsh received $461,000, Adelaide $430,000, Grey $368,000, and Makin $400,000—an amazing coincidence!

Some people on this side of the chamber who take a particular interest in rural Australia will no doubt say the poorest of all in Australia at the moment are in the rural communities. For example, Wakefield, which may well be that seat, got $171,000—less than half the average that this minister gave to each of the marginal Labor seats in South Australia. Again, perhaps there is an explanation that I have missed; but the coincidences, really, are just too much to accept. As we go through this list that was produced by the dissenting minority in the House of Representatives inquiry, one notes that Labor target seats were listed here as being favoured seats—for example, Bendigo, Corinella, Hotham, Melbourne Ports, Wills, Hindmarsh, Adelaide, Makin, Kennedy, Herbert, Leichhardt, Hinkler, Moreton, Rankin, Calare, and on it goes.

Approved category 3 applications favoured ALP electorates over coalition electorates by 59 to 18; and in Queensland by 15 to one—and on it goes. The only application ruled ineligible by the department but that had funding approved was in a marginal ALP seat, the seat of Dickson. The only grant above $50,000 provided without matching funding was in a marginal ALP seat, the seat of Hinkler.

Six of the seven late applications funded were in marginal ALP electorates. Other late applications of course were rejected. The only cases of grants being made in excess of $250,000 per project ceiling were in ALP electorates—the seats of Watson and Perth. Many grants, including those in coalition electorates, were made to organisations with strong links with the ALP. In some cases, ALP candidates announced successful grants, even though the sitting coalition member had not been advised.

In Bendigo the minister personally directed potential applicants to the ALP candidate, Mr Helper, not to the coalition member of parliament. The minister initiated extensive consultations with many ALP members in determining which grants should be successful in their electorates. Contacts with coalition members of parliament were rare. Extra funds were supplied and a record number of grants were announced just prior to the 1993 federal election. No new funds were provided for the program in the post-election budget.

Applications were classified by electorate before the application of grants was decided. We know about the notorious leaked minute to the Honourable R. R. Willis from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, which referred to potential grants in his electorate and stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Could you please look at the attached and pass on your comments by Friday afternoon.

It had a big `confidential' on it. We note that that electorate was stated at the top of the minute to be a safe Labor electorate. In other words, when the minister considered the applications, she had before her a designation of the electorate according to whether it was politically important in the forthcoming election. That fact itself is so vital in assessing what her motivation really was in choosing one application over another.

PARA.TAB: Successful applicants were notified by personal letter from the minister and unsuccessful applications merely got a letter from the department. Do you remember, Mr President, the explanation of Senator Richardson as to why the department was not being involved? It was because it was a difficult matter and he did not want to cause embarrassment. Yet when people were unsuccessful he was quite happy to have the department write to them and tell them they were unsuccessful. If they were successful, of course, there was a political benefit in his writing—or, in this case, former Minister Kelly writing—to the successful applicants to tell them what he had been able to achieve for their benefit.

Completed projects are required to erect a plaque to commemorate the government's contribution. Electorates which demonstrated a need by providing the largest number of applicants did not get the largest number of grants, and one can go on. The mere fact that there was no published criteria in itself demonstrates that the basis on which the minister chose one applicant over another can only be described as highly suspicious. Honourable senators can read the full list of the evidence of bias that was simply collated by some members of the House of Representatives and included within that report. At the very least it must, in the eyes of any reasonable person, raise a very deep disquiet.

What I have been talking about is the administration of former Minister Kelly. But the architect of the scheme, the first minister administering the scheme, was Senator Richardson. Senator Richardson in this place the other day tried to suggest that he might have inherited it from former Minister Brown, the minister who became somewhat notorious in here for other reasons relating to his business arrangements with the Prime Minister. In fact, he did not inherit this scheme from Mr Brown. Mr Brown's scheme was a national scheme. The scheme that Senator Richardson put together—very shrewdly, one must acknowledge; politically shrewdly—was a community based scheme whereby he had the opportunity to determine which communities should benefit, and deliberately, in his intention that the department should not take a role in the selection of those.

It is the only example I know—honourable senators might remind me of others—of a scheme divvying out public money in this way; where there is no advice from the department as to the merits of one applicant over another but, rather, it is determined by the minister in his office with his political staff, in the case of Senator Richardson, or on the whiteboard, in the case of former Minister Kelly, with her political staff. I do not know of any other instance where it was done in this way. So one again asks why. I have demonstrated that the explanation given by Senator Richardson that it would be too awkward for the department simply does not wash. Why is it too awkward in relation to grants under this scheme and not in relation to grants under the arts scheme, the environment scheme or one of the others? No explanation is given for that.

As I said, when we look at what happens in practice, the fact that the department was hauled back in to tell the unsuccessful applicants that they had missed out, really demonstrates that his case fails. What one must suspect is that the department was not involved because the minister wanted to divide this public money in a way that benefited the party rather than to ensure that the best applicants, the most needy applicants, the most worthy cases were, in fact, those that were rewarded.

Senator Campbell, Senator Parer and Senator Baume—and they have not received sufficient credit for it—picked up this area of concern back in 1990, with the first grants being made by Senator Richardson. We put these matters to Senator Richardson, as you remember, Mr President, in question time two days ago. We wanted to bring this matter on yesterday because it was the day following Senator Richardson's failure to give a reasonable explanation as to why, for example, in Western Australia, 75 per cent of the 1990 grants went to Labor held electorates which comprise only 57 per cent of the electorates in Western Australia. There is no explanation as to why the marginal seat of Canning received 35 per cent of Western Australia's total allocation. There is no explanation as to why, in Queensland, seven marginal seats received 75 per cent of the grants and five of those seven were Labor held and two were marginal coalition. There is no explanation as to why, in New South Wales, one-third of the funding went to just four marginal Labor seats, with 14 per cent going to just one seat, the seat of Calare, Mr Simmons's; two marginal Labor seats, Calare and Hunter received $400,000 of the $1 million that was spent on Labor seats.

The minister had the opportunity in this place two days ago to explain how that occurred in a way that could convince the Senate that it was for reasons other than political bias, that he was not part of what we can only fairly describe as political corruption, and he failed to give any real explanation of that at all.We know that he had gone out publicly earlier and said that they went to Labor seats because the Labor seats were the poor in the community and had the greatest need. That was the defence he made for former Minister Kelly some days before.

What we have now been able to demonstrate is that the seats which had the lowest per capita income in fact did not get the same benefits. The seats that really benefited, disproportionately benefited, were those for which disproportionate political gain could be achieved. That is the evidence that has built up from 1990 right through to the recent inquiry, which I have described as a sort of part inquiry into the sports rort affair by the House of Representatives.

Without a satisfactory explanation that no-one on the government side has yet put, one can only conclude that that is evidence that would lead any reasonable person to the conclusion that not only was this a politically biased program but also it was set up primarily for a political purpose to advance the Labor Party's interests and put in the hands, firstly, of the architect of the ALP's election strategy, Senator Richardson, for that objective and then carried on by Mrs Kelly on his instructions. For that, they should be condemned and they will not be condemned unless this chamber, with its numbers, is prepared to do the hard work and make the findings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "that", substitute:
The Senate

PARA.TAB: (1)notes with concern the conclusions of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the Community Cultural, Recreational and Sporting Facilities Program about the manifest inadequacies of documentation and accountability processes in the administration of this program;

(2)endorses the recommendations of the Auditor-General in the Audit Report No.9 and the House of Representatives Committee on the improvement of decision making and accountability processes in the future for this and similar programs and request the Government to report to Parliament by 13 May;

(3)supports the Government's commitment to re-draft the foreshadowed Auditor-General Bill to strengthen the definition of the powers and mandate of the Auditor-General in line with Report 296 of the Joint Public Accounts Committee;

TAB.TAB: (a)supports the Government's undertaking to have such a re-drafted bill debated in both Houses early in the Spring session;
(b)urges the establishment of a Parliamentary Audit Committee as recommended in Report 296 and supports the consideration of measures to further strengthen the independence of the Auditor-General;

PARA.TAB: (4)supports the immediate reconvening of the Parliamentary Working Group established to develop a Code of Conduct for Ministers, Members and Senators, and calls upon it to produce a report, no later than the commencement of the Spring Session on 23 August, addressing the question of a Ministerial Code of Conduct, including the proper extent of ministerial discretion in disbursing funds under direct grant programs.

(5)in the context of measures to ensure greater accountability of ministers and members of both Houses of Parliament, endorses the principle of a register of Senators' interests, and, to ensure speedy consideration of that matter, which has been before the Senate for 10 years, orders that:

TAB.TAB: (a)the notice of motion and order of the day relating to a proposed committee and register of Senators' interests have precedence over other government business on 14 March 1994; and
(b)the following provisions apply to consideration of those motions:
(i)the following time limits apply to the further consideration of the motions specified:
MotionMinutes
Registration of Senators'
Interests—proposed resolution150
Proposed new standing order 22A30

(ii)this resolution apply to the motions as if they were questions for the passage of stages of bills, and have the same effect as an allotment of time for the consideration of bills under standing order 142, except that:

(A)at any time during the consideration of each motion any Senator may move a motion to extend the time allotted for that motion, and that question shall be put and determined without debate, but no more than two such extension motions may be moved; and

(B)at the expiration of the time allotted for each motion, any amendment to that motion which has been circulated by any Senator but not moved shall be put and determined, and any Senator who has circulated amendments may speak for not more than five minutes to all of those amendments together before the question on the amendments is put.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier this week, the sports rorts was a symptom and we have asked the government to treat the disease, which is lack of accountability. I turn first to the reason that accountability is a serious matter. I want to assure Senator Hill that I agree with him when he says that this issue is a serious matter. Where we disagree is the way in which we should address it.

PARA.TAB: In Australia, through the 1980s and into the 1990s we have had a series of royal commissions and inquiries into alleged and proven political corruption—the WA Inc. inquiry, the Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland, the South Australian State Bank inquiry, and the various inquiries conducted by ICAC in New South Wales. I think it is true to say that there is a collective body of wisdom which basically says that what was appropriate in the 1970s and 1980s—pork-barrelling and beyond—is no longer appropriate in the 1990s. State governments have changed hands because of the public's strong views on this issue of accountability.

The Keating government is the one government which has continued through the 1980s into the 1990s. I do not believe it has had to face up to the higher standards of public accountability that are expected in Australian political life today. I think the public gallery in the House of Representatives showed that quite vocally and graphically last Thursday. That is why I attempted to negotiate with the government an accountability package which I believe will go a long way towards addressing the public's views on the higher standard of accountability expected of Australian politicians. I want to take a moment to look at the substance of my amendment and explain the various sections.

It is important to point out in parts (1) and (2) the context of this accountability package, because in parts (1) and (2) the government acknowledges the context. It acknowledges the existence and the concern with the conclusions of the House of Representatives standing committee. It acknowledges and endorses the recommendations of both the Auditor-General's report No. 9 and the House of Representatives committee on the improvement of decision making and accountability processes in the future for this and similar programs. The outcome of this will be a report back to parliament by 13 May. My amendment goes on from a context of acknowledgment to action. Part (3) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . supports the Government's commitment to re-draft the foreshadowed Auditor-General Bill to strengthen the definition of the powers and mandate of the Auditor-General in line with Report 296 of the Joint Public Accounts Committee;
Part (3)(a) states that we will debate this early in the spring session. Part (3)(b) reads:
. . . urges the establishment of a Parliamentary Audit Committee as recommended in Report 296 and supports the consideration of measures to further strengthen the independence of the Auditor-General;

TALK.START.PARA: —What about his rent?
—That is a separate matter, but it is one that I am happy to deal with later. Part (4) is also in the context of an acknowledgment. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . supports the immediate reconvening of the Parliamentary Working Group established to develop a Code of Conduct for Ministers, Members and Senators, and calls upon it to produce a report, no later than the commencement of the Spring Session on 23 August—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that under Leo McLeay? It is chaired by Leo McLeay.
—Senator Kemp is wrong. I will tell him why in a minute and it will give me pleasure to do so. Part (4) continues:

SPEECH.PARA: addressing the question of a Ministerial Code of Conduct, including the proper extent of ministerial discretion in disbursing funds—

not just under this program but across all direct grant programs. That is something that we should look at. We have to ask: is it appropriate that ministers have this discretion? My personal view is that $30 million is highly inappropriate, but I am sure a case can be argued for ministers having some discretion at a certain level.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp raised the question: is this the working group chaired by Leo McLeay? Yes, it was, but it no longer is. I am glad he mentioned Mr Leo McLeay because I am reliably informed by a Democrats member of this working party that Mr Leo McLeay said, `I do not know why we are meeting. If we did not have ethics we would not be in parliament, would we'. The second thing to point out is that this working group, established after the Marshall Islands affair—I remember all the emotion on both sides of that debate—lapsed due to lack of interest because the opposition did not appoint an opposition senator to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did.

—After 12 months; that shows how seriously the opposition regarded the issue of accountability after the Marshall Islands incident. The point is that it is being reconvened, it is cross-party and it has as its priority a code of ministerial conduct.

PARA.TAB: We all know that, just as the standards of the 1980s for what is expected of us as individuals are no longer appropriate in the 1990s, the duties of ministers, the complexity of legislation, the increase in the amount of technological change probably means that we have different needs of and put different demands on ministers these days. It could well be that there is a more appropriate use of delegation, but complicating that is the factor, as the Pearce report pointed out, that we have had a huge increase in the number of ministerial staff as compared with departmental staff. I am not saying that that is inappropriate; I am simply saying that there has been a real blurring of the lines as to what is appropriate responsibility for all of these people, including ministers, and it is about time we sorted it out.

Part (5) of my amendment addresses the matter of a register of pecuniary interests of senators. It ensures speedy consideration of this matter, which has been before the Senate for 10 years. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was either incredibly ill-informed or incredibly mischievous when he said on the Real Life program that it was the fault of the Democrats that this had not happened. The fact of the matter is that it has not been for lack of Democrats support. Certainly there has been some negotiation on amendments but we have been ready to vote for this register for a long time now. The reason it has not been brought to a vote is that we have had a filibuster. We talked it out, the government took it off the agenda and it has not come back. Part (5) of my amendment means that, if this amendment is carried, the matter will come up for debate on 14 March when we return to this place. That is the substance of my amendment.

I want to tell honourable senators why I oppose Senator Hill's motion—why I do not think an inquiry is the best route to follow in this instance. I acknowledge the importance of Senate committees. I acknowledge the importance of the way in which we have shared the chairs of those select committees in this chamber—I acknowledge that—but I also acknowledge the opportunities for politicisation of those committees.

I am interested in the difference between Senator Hill's first terms of reference and his name for the committee, and the redrafted ones. The first name was a `select committee for an independent inquiry into sports grants'. The second one is a `select committee for an inquiry into certain government accountability matters'. That is a big improvement; a very interesting acknowledgment of the language and focus. I think the first draft shows a very clear indication of focus and motive.

In plan A, the first draft proposes a commissioner, who is or has been a judge of a superior court, be appointed to assist the committee. The second draft proposes to appoint a commissioner who is or has been a judge, or is or has been a senior counsel. The first draft proposes a quorum of three members, a neat little subcommittee—it could even be three Liberals. The second draft proposes a quorum of four members. The first draft proposes advertising the inquiry's sittings in the media. The second draft widens this to inviting the public to make written or verbal submissions. The first plan proposed a six-member select committee with the standard two Labor members, three coalition members and one Australian Democrats member. The second draft proposes a seven-member committee consisting of two Labor members, three coalition members, one Democrat member and a member nominated by the Greens (WA) and Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is telling stuff.

—Senator Kemp says that this is telling stuff. I say to him that words are very revealing. Plan B, while I think it is definitely an improvement, offers absolutely no guarantee that this committee would not become the usual politicised witch-hunt. There is no guarantee about the behaviour of senators. There is no guarantee that they would be prevented from—
—Move amendments in the committee.

—No, I am following my chosen and well thought through route. Senator Chamarette says that she will close the committee down if it becomes a witch-hunt. I have had a lot of experience, in my limited time here, on committees. I am on one at the moment which could easily become a witch-hunt. I can assure the Senate that it is a very difficult task. I have found it incredibly embarrassing at times to be sitting in the middle of a huge brawling match involving people at both ends of the table. It is not easy to control that and it is not a matter of simply saying in a press release, `We can close this down and prevent it from happening'.
—You enjoy that.
—I enjoy it when it is behaving like a real committee—because it has a very important job to do.
—You are playing a very constructive role in it.

—Thank you. Why no inquiry? I argue that a costly inquiry will not, in fact, tell us anything significant that we do not already know. What do we already know? We know what happened. We know it was pork-barrelling. We know it was on a large scale. We know that it went on under Mrs Kelly—and most likely under Senator Graham Richardson. We know that it was intricately and intimately linked to a marginal seats campaign. We know that. We know what happened, and we know most of how it happened. We have to make sure that it does not happen again. Two reports and two inquiries have exposed most of the detail of this matter; it is not a matter of clairvoyance. I have to weigh up, given my commitment to Senate committees, whether I think this is the most appropriate avenue to go in this instance.
—There is no other way.

—I believe there is another way. I believe that the accountability package that I am presenting in this amendment goes as far as we can, at the moment, towards achieving real reform in the matter of accountability. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard correspondence between the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) and me which explains and supports the details of my amendment.

The Senate

(2) endorses the recommendations of the Auditor-General in the Audit Report No.9 and the House of Representatives Committee on the improvement of decision making and accountability processes in the future for this and similar programs and request the Government to report to Parliament by 13 May;

(3) supports the Government's commitment to re-draft the foreshadowed Auditor-General Bill to strengthen the definition of the powers and mandate of the Auditor-General in line with Report 296 of the Joint Public Accounts Committee;

(b) urges the establishment of a Parliamentary Audit Committee as recommended in Report 296 and supports the consideration of measures to further strengthen the independence of the Auditor-General;

PARA.TAB: (4) supports the immediate reconvening of the Parliamentary Working Group established to develop a Code of Conduct for Ministers, Members and Senators, and calls upon it to produce a report, no later than the commencement of the Spring Session on 23 August, addressing the question of a Ministerial Code of Conduct, including the proper extent of ministerial discretion in disbursing funds under direct grant programs.

(5) in the context of measures to ensure greater accountability of ministers and members of both Houses of Parliament, endorses the principle of a register of Senators' interests, and, to ensure speedy consideration of that matter, which has been before the Senate for 10 years, orders that:

TALK.START.PARA: —The main difference between what my amendment is proposing and what a Senate inquiry may or may not achieve is that my package delivers a committed outcome. A Senate inquiry may make findings and recommendations; and the House of Representatives and the government may ignore them, as often is the case. I argue that it is more constructive for us to use existing parliamentary avenues, such as the estimates committees, which the opposition has used in this matter very effectively.

PARA.TAB: It is even possible to suggest that the Auditor-General has a look at the administration of the program under Senator Graham Richardson. It is possible, too, to use the avenue of negotiation. I prefer negotiation to confrontation in most cases, and that is why we have this package to present to the Senate today. I am not a fan of continuing the politics of muckraking, and that is the big risk in the opposition's proposal. I am sorry, but I really have to say that it is part of the opposition's motives.

Senator Hill said that the matter must not be forgotten. I agree with him. What do Australian people want from this situation? They wanted Mrs Kelly to resign, I believe, and she did. They want to make sure it does not happen again. My package will commit this government to a much greater degree of accountability than ever before, and one which is a substantial improvement. I wonder whether the opposition, if and when it ever wins government, would be prepared to sign a statutory declaration here and now that, if in government, it will never be tempted or seize an opportunity to indulge in a little bit of old-fashioned pork-barrelling, which I am now saying is inappropriate. I wonder whether the opposition could give us that cast-iron guarantee.

We have the example of Dr Hewson making an election promise. I wonder whether making an election promise to the tune of $30 million and then finding the money to pay for it qualifies under Senator Hill's definition of corruption. Is the opposition attempting to buy votes in that way and tie them to government expenditure?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is different with all these innocent community groups all over Australia putting in their good claims. They had no chance of winning anything because that was not going to win votes for the ALP.
—We know that. Let me conclude by citing a well-read article on Senate committees by Mr Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: estimates committees in the 1993-94 budget hearings . . . cost . . . $8 million in round terms.

PARA.TAB: That figure did not include time spent on Senate . . . proceedings by ministers and their staff . . . Finance Department in its coordinating role, the costs of typing and printing documentation . . . the cost to the parliament of mounting estimates committee hearings—the cost of staff, research done by the parliamentary library, the Hansard costs, or money spent on coverage of hearings by parliament's sound and vision unit.

I only mention that as something that should be considered. We are tempted to think of the inquiry as the only avenue open to us—and it is, if one's motives are those of crudest politics. But there are constructive opportunities that we in this parliament can take. I have chosen to take the route of negotiation. I argue that this accountability package is a step towards more open and honest government without having to wade through a cesspool to get there. I argue that we should replace Senator Hill's motion with a forward-looking, not a backward-looking, accountability agenda which recognises the mistakes that have been made and seeks to move on. I conclude by quoting from the editorial in the Australian newspaper of 2 March 1994:

The Coalition has in the aftermath of Mrs Kelly's resignation sought aimlessly to spin out the sporting grants affair. It wants to establish a Senate inquiry that could only amount to a fishing expedition. By contrast, . . . the Democrats produced a sensible case for reform. The Government and Coalition would do well to respond in a positive fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what it is about—avoiding the politics of muckraking and taking the opportunity to put a constructive, forward-looking agenda in place. It is much more cost effective and, I would say, a much more of-the-nineties, appropriate way of moving forward.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill's motion is the wrong motion at the wrong time and the government will oppose it. It is not about exposing the issues involved, because that has already been done. It is not about bringing the government to account for deficiencies revealed in the process, because that has already happened. It is not about forcing the government to acknowledge that more needs to be done in addressing the public interest issues of accountability that are involved, because the government has already acknowledged—and I will again today in more detail—that more does need to be done. It is not even about identifying what further improvements need to be made in the accountability process, because there are many proposals for improving that accountability process already on the table, including, in particular, the Democrats' amendment, which I indicate at the outset the government will support.

PARA.TAB: The motion is not about any of those positive things. What the motion is about, and what this inquiry would be about, is wasting time, wasting resources and wasting a very large amount of taxpayers' money in what Senator Kernot has very accurately described as a political fishing or trawling, muckraking exercise and one which, moreover, would do no more than retread ground already very well trodden, and not in a way that would add in any respect to the public interest considerations that are involved.

Let me track over each of those points again in a little more detail. An inquiry, as I said, would not be about exposing the issues that have been involved in the administration of this program or, indeed, any other program like it, because there have already been two very far-reaching inquiries which have done just that—the Auditor-General's report, with its recommendations, and the House of Representatives committee report, with its findings, very adverse to the minister and to the government, and its recommendations.

What new information could we possibly get out of this inquiry that is not already on the table? We know all about the processes that were followed—the guidelines, the respective roles of the department and the minister's staff, the Auditor-General's and other people's views about the question of fraud and about what needs to be done in the future. There is nothing new in it. It is a backward-looking waste of everybody's time.

Senator Hill, of course, claims that a further inquiry is needed because the Auditor-General's inquiry and the House of Representatives committee inquiry did not sufficiently investigate the whole question of allegations of political bias. Of course, that question was very squarely raised by the Auditor-General. He concluded, having looked at it, and with full access to all the documentation involved, that he could not resolve it. That question was also looked at by the House of Representatives committee which, in its majority report, found that, while there might be an inference of bias, there was no reliable documentary basis for going beyond what the Auditor-General had concluded. And this was in a report by a Labor majority which did not pull its punches; a report which talked about serious inadequacy of the minister's record keeping; which talked about the minister's management being deficient; a Labor majority report which was so scathing and so devastating, so negative in its impact, that the minister felt she had no obligation but to resign.

What we have seen in this exercise is the way in which statistics can be employed to conclude almost anything, and will continue to be employed in that way, in an environment where conclusive proof is simply not available, and it is not available, of course, because the documentary evidence, as we all know, does not exist. Of the statistical games that have been played, I can retail, for instance, the very adverse publicity given to Mrs Kelly's administration of this program at one stage during the proceedings, where it was said that only nine per cent of her approvals were in the category one area, which was obviously of the best qualified projects; 80 per cent of them were of much less qualified category two proposals; and 11 per cent were in category three.

When those same statistics—and they were devastating in their impact, I think, in creating a climate of concern about this affair—were properly looked at, they were quite different in their impact because it became clear that nine per cent of the total number of grants made happened to be of the category one type, but since only a very small number of grants had been in category one to begin with, even though 58 per cent of all grants coming forward in category one had been approved by Mrs Kelly, because those grants in total were only a small proportion of the overall number, the figure was as low as it appeared to be—nine per cent.

I give that as one passing example. In fact, she approved 58 per cent of category one applications, 26 per cent of the 2,000 or more in category two, and 14 per cent of category three applications. A different perception was brought to bear on exactly the same figures, producing a different prima facie conclusion about the nature of the enterprise involved.

Similarly, that was the case on the question of late applications mentioned by Senator Hill. There was a very detailed answer given in Hansard on that question of late applications, why those were accepted and others were not, in response to a question on notice by Dr Wooldridge. That did not get the attention it deserved by way of explanation. Similarly, the Pine Rivers band issue and the saga associated with that, which equally had a rather devastating public impact in creating the perception that something had gone fundamentally wrong, was readily and quickly explained as a case where there had been a difference of view in the department as to whether the grant in question was of a capital kind. The department said, `Contact the minister; make representations to the minister if you don't like our finding'. The grant applicants did so and they got a decision accordingly.

I mention these examples not in order to track back over this territory but to remind honourable senators of how much does depend, when one is engaged upon these sorts of inquiries, upon what kind of information is out and about and how one chooses to scrutinise it. I say, quite simply, even if honourable senators do not give weight to the majority report of the committee, even if they give all the weight to the report of the minority—the issues that Senator Hill was emphasising—they are never going to get any further than we have got so far today, because the inherent nature of this particular material is not such as to produce conclusive results on the question of political bias. It will never do so because of the manifest inadequacy of the documentation involved. It will never do so because of the whole way in which the program was administered—in a way that was over-reliant on the discretion of the minister.

When one has a program which is administered on this basis, with very little reliance on objective criteria, material coming from the department, and a great deal of reliance on individual discretion being exercised by the minister, one is always going to have arguments about political bias and those arguments are never going to be resolvable.

What we had in this particular inquiry was all those issues clearly and frankly exposed. They were exposed, bringing out the statistical compilations in a way that is going to give rise to endless further argument but no further conclusions. So why a new inquiry is not going to expose any further, in any public interest relevant way, the issues that are involved is because the inherent nature of the material that is going to be before such an inquiry, if it were to be set up, is not such as to enable firm conclusions to be drawn. That is what happened in the House of Representatives committee, with all its coercive powers. That is what would happen in a Senate committee with whatever powers it was vested with.

The second point I make is that this inquiry would not be about bringing the government to account for deficiencies that have been revealed. The government has been brought to account. We have been lacerated. We are lying bleeding and wounded on the floor and one minister has lost her ministerial head as a result of it. And that is the ultimate sanction in the political business. We cannot get a more savage kind of reprisal than that. The ultimate political price has been paid.

The government has been brought to account, not only through the wounding months when this particular issue was being so much the subject of adverse public comment, but in a very direct and immediate way through the fate of this particular minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are constantly shafting the Auditor-General.

—Let me come to that. The third point I want to make is that this would not be about forcing the government to acknowledge that more needs to be done in addressing the issues that arise. I say that because the government has already acknowledged that more needs to be done. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), so far from shafting anybody, in his contribution to public debate on this issue in a Perth radio interview he did the following day made it absolutely clear that he frankly acknowledged that there had to be much greater accountability in the way this particular system operated. There had to be much greater reliance on departmental documentation and classification and much less reliance on ministerial discretion. That is not shafting the Auditor-General; that is agreeing with the central recommendation of the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: The central recommendation of the Auditor-General has been already frankly accepted, openly accepted, at the highest level of this government. The government is prepared to accept that more can be done and that more specifically can be done to strengthen the powers of the Auditor-General. Mr Beazley has made that clear in public statements, in the documentation that has just been tabled and incorporated in Hansard by Senator Kernot. He has indicated that, in the context of this debate, we would be prepared to go down the path of redrafting the Audit Act, introducing that redraft for speedy consideration and addressing in the course of that redrafting process a whole series of issues that have been raised by Senator Kernot going to the independence and the capacity of the Auditor-General to do his job. We have acknowledged, frankly, that more can and should be done in that particular area. I do so again now: we will go down that particular path.

I make the further point that any such inquiry exercise would not be about identifying what further improvements could be made in the accountability process because, to a very large extent—I think to a comprehensive extent—those sorts of issues are before us. Maybe there will be some further issues brought out by honourable senators in the course of this debate. The issues are before us in the form of the 16 specific recommendations about this program that were made in the Auditor-General's report from page 17 onwards—some of which, by their nature, are applicable to similar discretionary programs elsewhere and not specifically confined to this. Similarly, with the five recommendations in the House of Representatives committee report on page IX, which spell out again some very specific suggestions for improving the operation of this particular program. Those sorts of proposals are clearly a general application to similar kinds of grant programs elsewhere.

We have the agenda of issues that have been identified. It has been identified in Senator Kernot's amendment now before us. It is an agenda which extends to picking up and applying those specific recommendations of the Auditor-General and the House of Representatives committee; an agenda which goes to the reconvening of the parliamentary working group and the development and implementation of a code of ministerial conduct; an agenda which obliges us, mercifully at last, to pick up the pecuniary interest question; and, most importantly of all, an agenda which goes specifically to the question of a whole series of potential improvements to the Audit Act.

I make it clear that, if there is any doubt about what the government would do if this particular amendment were passed, if there is any doubt about whether the government would actually take notice of such an amendment and act accordingly, I will seek leave to put that matter beyond doubt by making an appropriate ministerial statement at the conclusion of this debate if this amendment is accepted and adopted by the Senate in the way that is being proposed. So it will not be just a matter of the Senate passing a resolution; it will be a matter of having some very firm ministerial commitments on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell us now?
—I wait to see the outcome of the debate. I make the point—
—They are right in principle.
—They are right in principle but, if they are worth doing, they are worth doing now—they are not worth holding fire for another three months, four months, five months or six months to see what—

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—
Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Hill and Senator Kemp what they want the inquiry for. Do they want the inquiry to go to the accountability issues that they say the inquiry is about? Do they want the inquiry to go to the refining and shaping of further proposals to improve accountability, in which case, of course we should wait and see what the outcome of the inquiry is? Do they want the inquiry to go to that, or do they want the inquiry to be a good political wallow for another three months, four months, five months or six months, getting whatever political nourishment they think they can derive from it? And, my God, they need some political nourishment at the moment. My God, they need some diversion. My God, they need some attention focused elsewhere than on themselves and their own internal problems.

PARA.TAB: Of course I know why those opposite want an inquiry. If I were in their shoes in opposition, I would want an inquiry for exactly those same reasons: to get going on a fishing, a trawling expedition to see what might turn up, Micawber-like. That is what those opposite are about. They are not about acting in the public interest to identify the rights and wrongs of a particular program. They are not about getting into this sort of inquiry in order to identify with more precision, more specificity and more detail particular accountability provisions or improvements. If they were about doing any of those things, I might just be tempted for half a minute to believe that there could conceivably be some justification for this inquiry. But that is not what they are about; they are about a political muck-rake exercise.

If there is any lingering doubt that that is what they are about, let us have a look at the way in which they propose to construct this inquiry. Let us have look at the membership of the committee. What do they propose to do by way of the membership of this committee? They propose to have three members from the Liberal-National Party coalition; two members out of the 30 government senators—that is, three from their side and two from ours—one from the Australian Democrats; and one, God help me, from the Greens; and, with the utmost respect, Senator Harradine. We have a 3, 2, 1, 1 situation. We have a situation where the government is being asked—for the first time, I believe, in the history of this Senate—to accept a committee situation where we have just two out of the seven places on this particular committee, and that is outrageous.

We have lived in the past with standing committees where the majorities have been constructed on a 3, 3 basis—three on the government side and 2, 1 for everyone else. We have lived with situations in standing committees where they have been constructed on a 4, 4 basis—four for the government and 3, 1 on the other side. We have even lived from time to time with select committees, because we have had no choice, constructed on a 3, 3, 1 basis—three for us, three for the coalition and one for the other minority parties and Independents in this place. We have never, in the history of this Senate, been asked to live with a situation of just two members out of seven on a committee like this. That is a demonstration, clear and stark, of just what a travesty of an exercise those opposite propose this committee to be. It is there. It is self-evident on the face of the matters of the motion, and they stand condemned by it.

The other very peculiar feature of this motion that those opposite ask the Senate in all seriousness to accept is the proposal for a judicial commissioner or person assisting the committee. The only time that has ever been implemented in the past was the very special, unique, hopefully never to be repeated circumstance in 1984 where two former judges were appointed as commissioners assisting the Senate committee in the context of the Senate Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge.

The conduct of a High Court judge—the potentially criminal conduct of a High Court judge—was something that went absolutely and fundamentally to the heart of the administration of justice at the highest levels in this country. It was obviously an issue of manifest seriousness; obviously an issue involving potentially criminal behaviour; obviously something demanding professional resources and skills that were beyond those of members of the Senate at that time; obviously something demanding very special circumstances—very special institutional arrangements.

What on earth is there about this particular committee that justifies or demands anything of the kind, or anything at least of the vast fees—quite apart from anything else—that are involved in setting in train an exercise of this kind? What is it about, except to lend some kind of spurious cover or colour of judicial decency to what is an inherently indecent political exercise? That is all that is about. It can have no other rationale; no other justification. Nobody has accused any aspect of this particular program of having been maladministered in any criminal way. There has been no hint or skerrick of evidence of any kind. It is not that kind of exercise.

The kind of exercise is a program that was manifestly maladministered in ways that we know about, and that we know what to do about for the future. We know what to do about it for the good reason, in the first place, that we paid the political price and, in the second place, because we have become acutely conscious of the kind of administration that is simply not justifiable, is not sustainable in the public interest in these particular matters.

That is what it boils down to. As Senator Kernot said, there is a hard, stark choice involved in this particular matter. We can go down the path that is being urged upon the Senate by Senator Hill. This is backward-looking, wholly political exercise, designed not to advance the public interest in accountability; not designed to create new machinery, new ideas, new proposals, new ways of dealing with particular administrative problems that have shown up in the past, but simply a political exercise designed to give possible solace, possible nourishment to a party desperately needing and feeling the urge to have such a diversion—feeling the urge for such a circus.

We have that sort of choice on the one hand—a backward-looking, politically-motivated manifest exercise of that kind—or we have, with the Democrats proposal, a forward-looking effort, designed to directly engage, without any further delay, without any further need to delay, in a series of specifically focused, quite precisely targeted efforts to improve accountability, which the government in that context is prepared to accept.

The government does accept that things went wrong; that things went fundamentally wrong in the administration of this particular program. We accept—we have said so at the highest levels; I am saying so now—the need for accountability to be improved, not only in the administration of this project, of this kind of program if it should continue in the future, but in other ways that have been identified in the course of this debate, including through stronger institutional arrangements for the Auditor-General.

We do accept that things went wrong. We do accept the need for greater accountability in this particular way. We do not accept the need for justification for this kind of inquiry. What we are about is good government, and doing that which is necessary to get good government to the extent that there have been lapses and shortfalls in that respect.
We are not about giving solace, nourishment or comfort to a tawdry political exercise of the kind that is being proposed by the opposition on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Before paragraph (1), insert the following preamble:
"That the Senate, while noting and welcoming the Government's intention to introduce an overdue, basic accountability package, namely:

PARA.TAB: (a)introducing and debating, in the spring session of Parliament this year, amendments to the Audit Act 1901 significantly to improve the powers and independence of the Auditor-General; and

TAB.TAB: (b)responding, by 13 May 1994, to the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled The community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program—a review of a report on an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General, and the Audit Report No.9 1993-94 by the Auditor-General into that program; and
(c)formulating a code of conduct for Ministers of State,

PARA.TAB: hereby resolves:"

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Omit paragraph (3), substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(3) That:
(a)there be a Commissioner Assisting the Committee appointed by resolution of an absolute majority of the committee, upon terms and conditions approved by the President;

TAB.TAB: (b)the Commissioner Assisting be a person who is or has been a judge of a superior court, or is or has been a Senior Counsel;

(c)the Commissioner Assisting is to be notified of all meetings of the Committee, may if he or she chooses be present at any meeting of the committee, may participate in the committee's deliberations and must be present at any examination of witnesses before the committee on any matter relevant to the committee's inquiry and must be present when the committee is deliberating on its report;
(d)the Commissioner enjoys priority in the examination of any witness, at any time, if her or she requests it;
(e)the committee is to include in its report any document which the Commissioner asks to be included, including his or her own report, if any, on the terms of reference of the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: "(3A) That the committee act in accordance with the following principles:

(a)that it at all times take care to protect, so far as it is proper and reasonable to do so, the privacy, confidentiality, rights and reputations of individuals, whether appearing as witnesses before the Committee or otherwise; and

(b)that it summon witnesses to appear personally only when satisfied that the circumstances demand it, that, so far as is possible, witnesses be given notice of the matters proposed to be dealt with, and that witnesses be given an opportunity to reply in writing before appearing to give evidence; and

(c)that it give specific consideration in the case of each proposed witness to the desirability of hearing evidence in camera, if it is proper and reasonable to do so, and that each witness be given an opportunity to apply for any or all of his or her evidence to be given in private.

While I support the terms of reference as presented and the principles underlying them, which I will discuss later, I believe they need altering in two ways. First, we need to get out of the catch-22 situation set up by the government and the Australian Democrats which makes the accountability package conditional on the abandonment of this inquiry. My amendment no. 1 allows for the measures as well as the inquiry, instead of without it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very helpful.

—Thank you very much. The first amendment inserts a preamble at the beginning of Senator Hill's motion to acknowledge the government's move to make important changes to the Audit Act, to bolster the powers and independence of the Auditor-General early in the spring session of this year; to set a timetable for responses to the House of Representatives standing committee report into the sports rorts affair, and to implement a code of conduct for ministers.

PARA.TAB: These make up three of the four initiatives that I understand were agreed to between the government and the Australian Democrats. It would be quite understandable for the public to think that all such measures should be a matter of course. None of these measures should require some specific agreement between parties outside this chamber. They certainly should not then be used as they are used and were used to threaten us against proceeding with a full inquiry into this affair.

The fourth measure, a register of senators' interests, is one that has our full support. It is a matter that has nothing to do with the issue at hand. Introducing it at this juncture is purely an attempt by the government to regain some of the high moral ground. If senators wish to implement such a register, then I hope that they will support the motion, of which I gave notice this morning, when it is moved on the next day of sitting.

The second amendment serves to clarify the role of the commissioner assisting the committee, and to enhance the objectivity of the committee's direction and focus. It deals with ensuring that the commissioner to be appointed by the committee has a clear role in the taking of evidence by the committee, and in the deliberations of the committee. This will serve the useful purpose of avoiding the muck-raking that people have expressed concerns over—but I also add that you cannot trawl muck if there is not any muck to trawl. So the government should be reassured about that.

We have supported the formation of this committee on the basis that it really can get down to some objective analysis of the issues at hand. The only way of doing that is to ensure that the commissioner has a specific role. The principles underlying the Greens (WA) support for this motion revolve primarily around the fact that this government has shown a consistent disregard for accountability to the people through the parliamentary process.

The way in which it has addressed the issue of the sports grants is only one recent example. We see it at all times when the role of the Senate, as a house of review, is disregarded or made fun of, or even attempted to be threatened. We see it at every point where this government refuses to table matters that are requested before this chamber. This is simply one more example, and it is one more opportunity for the government to address that inconsistency of accountability that it demonstrates to the people of Australia.

There has been no admission of guilt; no acknowledgment that improper, if not corrupt, conduct has occurred. It is the sheer arrogance of an executive which allows the allocation of $30 million of taxpayers' money, and smiles in the face of a total absence of justification and documentation, and simply scapegoats the minister for incompetence.

By the way, is that incompetence in covering tracks, or in failing to be able to explain away the unexplainable? Any individual taxpayer who has answered the taxation department's queries, and any community group that has been hauled through bureaucratic hoops to account for every cent of federal government grants is outraged at the obvious disregard and abuse of government responsibility that has been demonstrated.

The community is familiar with pork-barrelling. The people know it has been tried on by almost any major party with sufficient resources at its disposal. This inquiry is not simply an inquiry to expose this practice, or allow anyone to hold the high moral ground and use the information in a party political way.

Senator Kernot spoke of the need for accountability. The honourable senator also referred to the change of Western Australian state governments as a result of exposure of corrupt practices referred to as WA Inc. She failed to mention that without the royal commission into WA Inc. the matters which were brought to light might never have become accessible to the community.

The package agreed to by the government and presented in the Democrats' amendments is worthwhile and should be supported. However, three questions need to be asked: why have the Democrats not already done this; why is this package to be conditional on not having an inquiry; and why, if the government is demonstrating such a desire for accountability, is it not moving the amendments? It needs to move the amendments itself to demonstrate the genuine political will for such accountability.

Finally, if we let the government arrange a package to get out of facing the parliamentary committee process which it consistently flouts, we will have done nothing to stop the arrogance of the executive, as demonstrated by the way the Labor Party has utilised taxpayers' money and by its weak response to the House of Representatives committee. The House of Representatives inquiry particularly highlighted the need to identify and put in place more transparent processes and better accountability mechanisms.

The inquiry that has been proposed in the motion before this chamber—to which motion I have moved amendments—seeks to do two things. The first is to clarify in a more objective way what the House of Representatives inquiry failed to do. If we do not address it, we are simply placing a bandaid over a weeping wound. Secondly, there is a need to isolate some of the information, not necessarily in the party political way it was exposed on that committee, but with the assistance of experienced counsel who can focus on the issues and, whether there is new information or not, establish a more objective basis for making positive changes in the future. This inquiry would set in place procedures which will prevent the recurrence of such slurs being placed on the allocation of funds to community groups.

Senator Gareth Evans asked what a new committee could do. My answer is that this new committee gives the government yet another chance to show its commitment to accountability and transparency of government and to show its accessibility to parliamentary scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Hill and the views that he put to the chamber. In parts of her contribution to this debate, Senator Chamarette went to the very central issue involved—government accountability. We do not want to put a bandaid over a weeping wound; we want to deal with the problem as it now is. Senator Chamarette moved some amendments and we will be supporting them.

PARA.TAB: I listened very carefully to Senator Kernot's speech. I regret to say that Senator Kernot does not seem to have learned the lesson that should have been learned from the so-called Marshall Islands affair. Mr President, you will recall that there was a very prolonged debate in this chamber about the Marshall Islands affair. Senator Gareth Evans constantly attacked us for dealing in political muckraking, for trawling, for covering our hands with political slime and so forth but at the end of the day Senator Richardson had to go. The government did not admit—

TALK.START.PARA: —Only because he misled the parliament; not because of anything you did.

—Mr Keating did not admit any guilt, but the fact is that it was causing damage to the Labor Party's standing. Senator Richardson, after a relatively short term in the wilderness, is now back as a senior member of the cabinet. The reason the Australian Democrats did not support an inquiry into that matter was that Senator Evans suddenly came up with the brilliant idea that the issue was not to go trawling to find out what the problems were and to get involved in muckraking. As Senator Evans put it at the time, `Let us deal with the future. What we need is a ministerial code of conduct'. Senator Coulter, the leader of the Australian Democrats at that time, reversed his position and said, `We will not support an inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair.
