What we will do is support'—would you believe it—`an inquiry into a ministerial code of conduct chaired by Mr Leo McLeay'. Of course, nothing happened as a result of that particular inquiry. I suspect that had we had the full inquiry, had we found out the full facts of the case, this particular scandal would not be before the parliament today.

PARA.TAB: The issues will not be resolved by Senator Coulter and Senator Kernot receiving certain assurances and support from the government for particular changes. I have looked at the letters which have been tabled, exchanges between Senator Kernot and Mr Beazley, and all they give us is some idea that the government will move in a particular direction. But we do not know what that direction is. Senator Evans will not tell us. We do not know what Senator Evans has promised Senator Kernot and others. As Senator Chamarette put it so well, if he was fair dinkum about accountability, if he truly recognised the problems thrown up by the various reports of the Auditor-General and the House of Representatives committee of inquiry, he would put those proposals on the table.

But Senator Evans, in an astonishing twist to this debate, has said that he has a package that he will put on the table but that no-one trying to weigh up this issue, particularly on our side, will be able to see these proposals until this particular motion is lost. We are simply not prepared to buy that.

Senator Evans has said that we are muckraking and trawling—exactly the same approach he took in relation to the Marshall Islands affair. We saw it again in relation to the Brian Burke affair. It is the typical government response. If Senator Evans and others in the Labor Party believe that this inquiry will show up nothing, what on earth are they worried about? I suspect that there is a prima facie case for very serious concern on the part of the Labor Party and that is the reason it does not want an inquiry. For the sake of accountability in government we must root out this cancer at the heart of the system once and for all.

The sports rorts issue is not one which can be resolved by simply saying that it has been mishandled by a minister and that it is sufficient that the minister has been removed. Senator Evans was very careful not to admit that there was any bias in this system. I believe the reason Senator Evans was very careful not to admit there was any bias, despite the overwhelming evidence to the contrary, is that he knows what such an admission would mean.

I believe that there has been a deliberate attempt under this program to rort the electoral system—to use massive amounts of taxpayer money in the lead-up to an election to secure a major advantage. Just look at the scale of this sports rorts program. In 1990 all the political parties together, including the minor parties, spent a record $32 million. After the 1990 election the Labor Party came back into this chamber and said that this was straining the electoral system; hence we had the proposal to ban political advertising on television and radio. The Labor Party felt that elections were becoming too expensive.

As to the 1993 elections—and we have not got the final figures out, as far as I am aware, of what the political parties spent—there have been reports that the amount was significantly less than in 1990 and probably in the order of $25 million for all political parties. This program totalled $30 million, and a majority of this money was poured into Labor Party marginal seats.

In the seat of Swan—which was won by fewer than 300 votes—a massive $617,000 was poured in. That was probably four or five times the amount the two political parties spent together in that electorate. The sports rorts program was featured prominently in Mr Beazley's election posters. In the marginal seat of Melbourne Ports, which the Labor Party was concerned about losing, well over half a million dollars was provided by Mrs Kelly to shore up the support of the local member, Mr Clyde Holding. One project was valued at over $200,000—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a nonsense!
—Senator Zakharov, it has been documented. There is no argument about that. A massive amount of money was poured into Melbourne Ports. The report showed that.
—It was a need.

—Senator Zakharov said it is about need. There was a category 3 application which alone totalled $200,000 to Melbourne Ports. A category 3 application is one that the department says, among other things, lacked relevant information. Community need had not been established. That is what a category 3 application is. Also, other selection criteria were not satisfied. Despite all this, the particular project was funded.

PARA.TAB: I put it to you that this is not just a simple program that has got out of hand and the government has indulged in a bit of pork-barrelling here and there. This has been a massive program used in the three or four months up to an election to focus substantial amounts of money into Labor Party marginal seats. That has been established, and there is no argument about that. In a typical seat, probably a political party is lucky to raise between $60,000 and $100,000. It is a general target for fund raising. In the Labor marginal seats, as Senator Hill said, these programs alone average $326,000, which is three times the amount that a political party is able to put its hands on to run the campaigns in those seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Loosley is sensitive about this, and he knows more about election campaigning than most people in this chamber. Mr Beazley alone spent out of this program $617,000. As I said, it was very interesting in the debate that Senator Evans was constantly asked whether there was bias in this program. Senator Evans refused to answer that question and admit bias, as indeed did Mr Keating, who as recently as Tuesday night declared—this is the Prime Minister, the man who sets the standards in this country for government—that Mrs Kelly had done nothing improper.
—That's true.

—That's true, says Senator Loosley, there was nothing improper. Mrs Kelly, according to Mr Keating, had done nothing incompetent. All Mrs Kelly had to do, which she has done, is to resign for the good of the party—that is all. Mrs Kelly has gone, and Senator Richardson has gone, simply for the good of the party. There has been no public admission by the Prime Minister about the nature of this program and no recognition by Senator Evans who, I admit, went slightly further than Mr Keating. He did concede that. I accept that Senator Evans went further than Mr Keating, saying that there had been maladministration. Mr Keating said there had not been. Here we are at the heart of this government. There is no particular recognition of what has happened. In fact, we are already seeing the start of the re-writing of history, the cover-up. The Labor Party hopes this can be put behind it and the cancer at the heart of the Labor government will not be exposed and rooted out.

PARA.TAB: The House of Representatives inquiry into this matter which Senator Evans relied upon quite heavily in his remarks, frankly failed to bring to account those responsible for the appalling administration of this program. Indeed, Mr President, you will recall the reporting date of this inquiry was brought forward in order to truncate the inquiry, so particular witnesses were not able to appear before it. For example, Mr Ken Bennett, who played a major role in this particular program, the former Labor Party National Secretary—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong!
—who is a senior adviser to the minister, assisted in the selection process.
—Right!

—Right. The man who assisted in the selection process—and I thank Senator Faulkner for that—was not able to be called before the committee to obtain evidence from him as to precisely what happened. The committee refused permission to call the former secretary of the department, Mr Blunn, who was in control of the department when this particular program was being administered by Mrs Kelly. Equally important, the department was about to supply a wide range of documents to the committee. The reporting date was brought forward, and those documents have never been seen and never will be until, I hope, this particular inquiry is established.

PARA.TAB: There was, finally, a refusal by the committee to allow the recall of the minister. This inquiry was a desperate attempt to limit the damage to this government, and so it was rushed forward, witnesses were prevented from being called, and papers which were about to be delivered from the department were never seen. If Senator Evans were fair-dinkum about finding out what was at the heart of this inquiry the Labor Party members would have been prepared to allow these particular events to take place, but he and the Prime Minister moved rapidly to truncate the inquiry.

There are many questions which have not been answered. I suspect that, in the minds of many people in the community, one of the questions is why Senator Richardson was promoted when he conducted the sports rorts program in a similar way to Mrs Kelly. She, of course, has been sacked.

Why did Senator Richardson decline to tighten up the guidelines for this program when he was advised by the department, as exposed on the Auditor-General's report at page 40? The reason he did not, as the architect of this program, was that he knew what a powerful weapon this program was in the run-up to an election in Labor marginal seats. Senator Richardson refused advice to tighten up the guidelines. What was the role of ALP members of parliament and candidates in the selection of these programs? This would establish what Senator Evans refuses to want to have established: was there bias in the program? Of course, that would be interesting.

What was the role of Mr Ken Bennett who, as Senator Faulkner has kindly pointed out, was the senior adviser to Mrs Kelly and was formerly the chief marginal seats strategist for the ALP? What was Mr Bennett's role in this program? In 1992, $30 million was allocated for a two-year program and it was to last until 30 June 1994. The money was to be spread out and—one would presume—the projects would be carefully assessed.

We did not get a two-year program. This money was spent before the 1993 election in a three-month period between November and January. This is not an ordinary program which has gone wrong; this is not pork-barrelling as it has often described; it was a major election weapon. Vast amounts of taxpayers' money were poured into marginal Labor seats.

I believe the democratic process has been rorted by what has happened. That is why we have to make this government fully accountable. Let us see whether there was bias. If there was bias in this system, it will prove conclusively how the election was stolen. Even with all the figures and statistics before Senator Evans, he cannot bring himself to agree with Senator Hill and me that this program was biased.

I believe we have seen political manipulation on a grand scale. There is a prima facie case for claiming political corruption on a grand scale. That is why we need a major inquiry. Nothing is more important in this country than the democratic process. Once a government gets its hands on the levers of power and so rorts the democratic process, this country is heading down a very serious road.

We have to find out what happened. Who told Mrs Kelly to spend all the money in the three-month period? Was it Mr Keating? Did Mr Keating go to Mrs Kelly and say, `You have $30 million to spend. I am calling the election in March. Spin out this money as quickly as you can into Labor marginal seats.'? Was it the then Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, or was it Senator Richardson? Was it a cabinet decision? Why is the Labor Party so worried?

TALK.START.PARA: —Prurient political interest.

—We have noted in the Brian Burke affair, the Marshall Islands affair, the Keating piggery affair and, indeed, the sports rorts affair that it is called prurient political interest and political muckraking. Those arguments from Senator Evans are becoming very tired. As each one falls over we expose exactly what this government has been doing and seeks to do.

PARA.TAB: I believe an inquiry will have a number of major effects. Firstly, it will prevent this abuse of the electoral system ever happening again. No minister, no government, no Prime Minister will be game to head down that track again. That is one fundamental reason it is important to have this inquiry. The Auditor-General has warned that unless clear action is taken, the standards and accountability of our system will be permanently damaged.
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner is again attacking the Auditor-General. The government does not like the Auditor-General. Secondly, we must have this inquiry to ensure that those who planned and developed this program will be brought to account.

PARA.TAB: At the moment all these senior men in the government are prepared to hide behind Mrs Kelly, and she takes the fall. But what role did the Prime Minister play? Did Mrs Kelly decide on her own behalf to spend $30 million in the two months prior to March? Does anyone believe that Mrs Kelly took that decision on her own? Of course she did not. I suspect it was taken at the highest level.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite are happy for Mrs Kelly's reputation to be destroyed and for her to take the fall for them. Senator Loosley and Senator Evans are happy for that to happen, but maybe the question that Senator Harradine and other senators in this chamber are going to have to reflect on is this: did Mrs Kelly really take this decision on her own?
—She might write that in her memoirs.

—That will be interesting. What will happen in the cool light of day, when the invitations to the Lodge no longer come, when her colleagues decide that she is no longer relevant and would prefer to forget that she ever existed? There are a few who owe their seats to Mrs Kelly. One cannot spend $600,000 in the seat of Swan and not affect the outcome when it is so close—

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr hides behind this. Those opposite are all happy for Mrs Kelly to take the fall. On the other hand, the Prime Minister is more than happy to promote Senator Richardson—the architect of the scheme. Of course those opposite do not want this inquiry.

PARA.TAB: This is a real test for the Senate. In light of the seriousness of what we know already, the Senate can go no other way than to have a full and proper inquiry. Senator Chamarette's motion has answered at least some of the concerns raised by Senator Kernot about the conduct of this inquiry. I suspect they are not needed, but obviously the motion gives Senator Chamarette comfort.

I put it to Senator Kernot that we had a forward looking approach in the Marshall Islands affair. We were not going to muckrake and the government undertook to behave itself in the future. Two years down the track Senator Richardson is back in town and we have the sports rorts affair. I do not believe that the Senate can wash its hands of this matter. It is a major test for the Senate. For those of us who value our system it is absolutely vital that we go to the heart of this affair. If Senator Evans is so confident that an inquiry would turn up nothing, the Labor Party itself might be concerned about having some of its time tied up in this affair, but it would not fight it too hard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a waste of taxpayers' money.

—Senator Loosley says, `It's a waste of taxpayers' money'. Mr President, you will be amused to hear that during the Watergate affair something was developed called the Nixon defence. That defence was essentially—

—On a point of order, Mr President. Senator Kemp has been rambling on for a very long time. My point of order is on the basis of relevance. His speech is not addressing the substantive motion or the amendment that is before the chair. We have been very tolerant but I would ask you, Mr President, to call him to order. He is now away with the fairies.
—I think the main theme of the address was relevant but, Senator Kemp, you are certainly wandering now. I hope you will come back on track.
—Mr President, I am indebted to you because I can show you—
—You are a defender of Nixon!
—I suggest you speak through the chair and that might overcome the problem—not just respond to every interjector who interferes.

—That is what I am doing. The argument that was launched by Mr Nixon was, `Let's get back into the main picture. There are huge national issues facing this nation. What are we doing getting tied up in this silly affair called Watergate?'. That is the Nixon defence. Senator Faulkner knew what I was talking about, and he rapidly rose to his feet. This is a fundamental issue. I believe that the Senate now has the chance to expose exactly what happened in this sports rorts affair, how the electoral system was corrupted and who was responsible for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —This indeed is another unseemly, partisan political exercise that we have come to know from the opposition. We are really used to this. It is yet another attempt to subvert the workings of the Senate to achieve no other end than the narrow and opportunist one of damaging the government. There has already been intense scrutiny of this matter. It is clear that the only motivation of the opposition is to generate heat, not light.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite are about more controversy, not resolution. The Auditor-General's report has fully canvassed the financial aspects of the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program. What is the Senate saying to the Auditor-General now by moving to establish its own inquiry? Is it saying to the Auditor-General that his report is inadequate? Is it saying to the Auditor-General that he did not take sufficient care? Is it saying to the Auditor-General, `You didn't cover all the angles'? None of these questions hold water and honourable senators know it.

That substantial report by the Auditor-General was followed by a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, which again fully canvassed all aspects of ministerial responsibility and process. The committee was given access to all information that it sought and thoroughly and properly examined all the issues involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not think that Senator Faulkner himself is effectively addressing the issue. The report from this committee, as I pointed out, was rushed forward. The inquiry was truncated.
—Throw him out.
—That is exactly what you did during my speech, Senator Faulkner. You are a little bit sensitive now, aren't you?
—Order! There is no point of order in what you have said.
—Sit down, you great galoot!
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I believe that Senator Faulkner used unparliamentary language in what he said. I think he should withdraw it.

—I withdraw. What would the Senate be saying to the House of Representatives? It is very hard to argue that the House of Representatives committee report was not thorough enough when it resulted in the resignation of a minister.

PARA.TAB: The report was so even-handed that the opposition members on that committee really had to scratch to put in the politically obligatory minority report—they really had to scrape the bottom of the barrel to come up with a minority report. So are we really saying that this Senate could do any better? Even though the Senate has had some delusions of grandeur since the election, it is very hard to see what could be covered by any Senate committee that was not dealt with by either the House of Representatives committee or by the Auditor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a triplication.

—That is right. I note that the motion extends the inquiry to include ministers' advisers. Senators should think very carefully before a precedent like this is set. Mrs Kelly, rightly, as demanded by this mob over here, accepted full responsibility for the processes of her office—full responsibility! A witch-hunt against ministerial staff would place totally unreasonable pressures on staff who do operate under ministerial direction.

PARA.TAB: So what, exactly, would a Senate inquiry do that has not been done before, except cost taxpayers an enormous amount of money for no additional result; except further the public's image of squabbling members of parliament and senators wasting their money and wasting their time. It is not as if this government has not responded. It has responded. The responsible minister has resigned.The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has signalled strongly that all future grants programs will provide strict guidelines to evaluate proposed projects and to guide any ministerial decisions. The government response has been fearless and it has been appropriate in these circumstances.

What about the novel approach to appoint a commissioner assisting the inquiry? It is entirely unclear and, I suspect, probably deliberately so, what this person is supposed to do. This commissioner will not have a power of his or her own to demand answers to questions or access to documents. Given this lack of powers and privileges, why is the opposition proposing the appointment of a commissioner? Again, the only possible and reasonable answer to that is, again, for crass political purposes.

The opposition proposes to draw on the prestige and standing of a judge or a former judge to lend an air of legal credibility to what, of course, will be a complete sham of an inquiry. The opposition expects an eminent judicial person to sit mute during these proceedings and provide some sort of cloak of respectability to what will, I think, be an utterly grubby show trial. The opposition appears to have no problems with planning to subvert the dignity and standing of a former or serving judge as commissioner.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's outrageous.

—That is what it is all about, Senator, and it needs to be identified in this debate. Frankly, it is hard to see any chief justice in any Australian jurisdiction agreeing to release a serving judge for what I think is a highly political and completely deceptive purpose. I do not think that the public standing of judges and the law should be suborned in that very grubby way. I really suggest that all opposition senators should think very seriously about what they are doing and about the precedent that they are establishing.

PARA.TAB: The motion as moved by Senator Hill is extraordinary in its unrepresentativeness. What is being proposed is just amazing. The committee being put forward by Senator Hill is a committee of seven: two from the government, three from the opposition, one from the Australian Democrats and one nominated by the Western Australian Greens and Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for General Business has expired, but I understand that there is agreement that we go on. Is leave granted to extend the period of the debate? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

—I was saying that the committee is very unrepresentative in structure. This is a very important issue and needs to be addressed. The government of this country, with nearly 40 per cent of the total number of senators in this chamber, is graciously given under this proposal two out of the seven positions on this committee. That is a travesty. It is unfair, it is unreasonable and it does not reflect any proportion of representation of senators in this chamber. It could not be defended by a fair-minded person.
—You have got the Democrats on your side.
—I have said it is unrepresentative, and it is.
—The House of representatives is unrepresentative as well.

—The honourable senator raised the issue; that is right. Senator Harradine and the two Western Australian Green senators represent three senators in this chamber. That is 14.2 per cent, however, of the representation on the committee. The government represents 30 senators; it has 30 seats in this chamber. We have 28.5 per cent of the representation on this committee, even though there are 39.4 per cent of senators sitting on this side of the chamber. No reasonable person can defend that. It is indefensible. It is an extraordinary precedent to establish in relation to Senate committees, which have traditionally always been structured in that a government majority is protected on them by the election of a government chair. That has been how this chamber has worked for decades. Sure, in the area of select committees it has changed recently, but nothing like this has ever been proposed or accepted before. It ought not to be accepted on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: I listened closely to Senator Chamarette's contribution. I am disappointed that she did not opt for a course of seriously negotiating with the government about issues of concern such as ministerial accountability but negotiated with the opposition on this matter. At least the Australian Democrats adopted the course in good faith of negotiating with the government to see some constructive and substantial change come about. The Australian Democrats approached this with a more open mind and I believe that at the end of the day their approach is more likely to see the desired result, whether or not there is a significant difference in the result that either Senator Chamarette or the Australian Democrats want to see at the end of the process.

I speak in this debate not only, obviously, in my role here as Manager of Government Business and someone who always has to go to the barricades in debates like this, but also as the new Minister for Sport and Territories. I think that what I might say about the future administration of that department may have some relevance.

In my other ministerial and portfolio responsibilities, I apply principles of absolute accountability and transparency to any grants programs. Every senator in this chamber knows that the runs are on the board in that regard. No senator in this chamber has ever questioned that. I will extend these principles of operation to my new portfolio of sport and territories. The guidelines will be well and truly laid down for any grants scheme. My involvement as minister will be clear, it will be laid down and it will be transparent. So I say to honourable senators, what is to be gained?

What powers would a Senate committee have that other investigations did not have? Would it be compellability of witnesses? Both the previous inquiries had that power. So I ask: what is new in that regard? Would it be access to the former minister? There is nothing new in that, either, because Mrs Kelly appeared before the House of Representatives committee and answered questions literally until the committee members dropped, literally until they ran out of questions, and literally until they ran completely dry, and every senator in this chamber knows it.

Nothing will be gained from an inquiry except to bring this Senate into disrepute. I know that that is not Senator Chamarette's aim or objective, but it will be the result of yet another inquiry that, without any doubt, will turn into the usual witch-hunt, rounding up the usual suspects.

For these reasons, the government is strongly opposed to such an inquiry. Frankly, from the point of view of a new minister, I want an opportunity for my portfolio to be administered in a proper, appropriate and open way. In fact, I would prefer to see my departmental officers back in the department getting on with plans for the future, not standing around outside a committee room here in Parliament House waiting to answer the same questions that have been asked and answered before.

The secretary to the department and the former minister have both indicated that the recommendations of the Auditor-General will be fully implemented in relation to the payout of grants under the existing program and in relation to any future program. A revised fraud control program recommended by the Auditor-General is already in preparation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't we see the government's proposals?
—No further program—
—Can we see the government's proposals?

—Just listen. No further program will be considered without a thorough evaluation of any existing program. Any similar program in the future would operate on the basis of an analysis of applications by the department and recommendations from the department to the minister. I stress that, as Minister for Sport and Territories, I will be operating on the premise of complete accountability and transparency of process in all funding programs of this sort.

PARA.TAB: Recommendations for improved administrative processes within the department are all in the course of being implemented. I say to honourable senators who are considering their position on this issue—which is no-one on the other side of the chamber—that if we are serious these are the things we would want officers of the department to be concentrating on. That is what they should be on about now. That is what should be the priority of those public servants, not wasting their time and wasting taxpayers' money in yet another Senate inquiry.

I think that the time has come for us to call a halt to this process which has now, with the resignation of Mrs Kelly, reached its natural end. Let me, as the new minister, get on with the job that needs to be done, which is one that I am committed to doing and doing properly. Let us not be involved in yet another time wasting, muckraking, fishing expedition that is nothing more than a political exercise that lacks credibility but will be a forum for allegations and rotten dirty politics that we have all had enough of.

I ask senators to reject Senator Hill's motion. Opposition members have this scalp on their belts, which is what they have argued for months. They have a substantial proposal and commitments given by the Prime Minister and by the Leader of the Government in the Senate about future operations in relation to ministerial accountability and have heard from me today about the way that the department will be administered under my stewardship. Therefore, those opposite should forget the grubby political exercise and get on with the job at hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on our side welcome the commitment that Senator Faulkner has made. By way of interjection, I asked him on a number of occasions during his speech in which he said he was going to be open, accountable, transparent and a good boy, whether or not in those circumstances he would need a code of conduct. He chose to ignore the interjections but he has succinctly put the case why the code of conduct proposal is quite similar in many ways to the directors' duties list idea that was put into the Corporations Law. As you know, Mr President, there was enormous debate on the topic. When people start codifying what is correct in a code of conduct for the sorts of things ministers should or should not do, they end up leaving out more than they put in and get themselves into a very complicated situation.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to see that out of all of the findings of the WA Inc. royal commission, one of the most crucial recommendations was reform of the upper house in Western Australia. In other words, it did not say we need codes of conduct or instruments such as that. What it really said is that we need a strong and democratically elected upper house. I will not go into that issue too much because I might get myself off-side with some of Senator McGauran's colleagues in Western Australia, and I believe Hendy Cowan is in the building today.

It was interesting to see that the WA Inc. royal commission said that what we need is a strong, effective and democratic upper house. That is something that I think we have here, and that is one of the threats that Senator Gareth Evans and some of his colleagues have hanging over this chamber. It is not only the Prime Minister saying, `We want to abolish the Senate'. He knows he will never be able to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, as Senator Kernot says by way of interjection, Senator Evans has a threat hanging over the minor parties and independents to change the voting system to try to create a system that would ensure that the major political parties won all the seats and the Independents and the Greens would not get in.
—He can only do it if you vote with him.

—I assure Senator Kernot that, no matter what my party decides, I will never vote for that system. Can I say—I will try to be brief because the debate has gone for a long time—that in my mind Senator Evans lost the high ground and the principle of this debate when he said that principle changes are required for accountability within government. However, he said, `We will only get those accountability changes if we don't have this inquiry'.
—That is a high principle, isn't it!

—That is a very high principle. It is interesting that after the Democrats went to Mr Beazley the other day and said, `We want a discussion about accountability', Kim Beazley and Mr Keating went back to their 1984 files and pulled out the old book about accountability. They blew the dust off it and said, `Right, what can we do?'. Senator Kernot said, `We want a code of conduct, and we want to do this and we want to do that'.
—That's just how it happened!

—Yes, it was. I am sure it was very similar. Senator Kernot's accountability requirements were so tough that they had a couple of meetings, wrote some letters and the government embraced it and said, `We will do that. This is going to be really tough on us. We'll be accountable'. That was the way the process was.

PARA.TAB: What we are really facing tonight is the decision about whether or not the Senate will fulfil its proper role. The decision will be made here in the next half hour to an hour, and senators will be judged forevermore on whether they uphold the Senate's role as a house of review. The House of Representatives committee did not fulfil its function. It did not call crucial witnesses because the committee voted on political party lines not to call certain witnesses. That is wrong.

There are many things that a Senate inquiry needs to examine that the House of Representatives inquiry, and, indeed, the Auditor-General's inquiry, did not address. That involves looking behind the veil of the process to see where the fraud existed. The Auditor-General said, `We could not see where there was any fraud'. He made it quite clear. He said, `We could not investigate these matters because there was nothing there, but the Senate committee should be looking there'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because there was no documentation.

—Exactly. So we need to address these matters. I do not know whether it is the Hansel and Gretel story, but it is like the little boy who left a trail of breadcrumbs behind and, of course, could not find his way home because the breadcrumbs had gone. Somehow we have to retrace that path and look not for the breadcrumbs—because they are not there—but look at where the path leads.

PARA.TAB: Even when Mrs Kelly resigned, it was not on an admission that she had done anything wrong. It was just because she was causing damage to the Australian Labor Party. This is not the issue. The Kelly resignation is not an issue. The issue has been bubbling around. It has taken years and years. We worked on an estimates committee back on 11 September 1990. I was the first person to write the names of marginal seats in Western Australia against grants and I came up with the figure of 85 per cent going to Labor seats. Then Senator Baume took up the cudgels from there and did it year in, year out.

The parliament knew that this issue was there and it was not until the Auditor-General came up with a report that anyone out there in the real world took any notice. One of the roles of the Senate is to keep pushing these things. The Democrats' record of getting Senate committees to look at things is not a very good one.

TALK.START.PARA: —The system is in place. You used it.

—The Democrats are blocking the Senate fulfilling its function by going back to this. Let us just remember that on 16 July 1992 we wanted to refer the matter of John Curtin House Ltd to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. We keep asking questions here and Senator McMullan says that it is not an issue and that it will all go away. This month the government has admitted that there is so much at stake in that leasing deal that it has set up its own inquiry. That was just because we were so persistent, but in July 1992 the Democrats said, `No, we don't want to have an inquiry'.

PARA.TAB: People like Senator Parer, former Senator Bishop, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and me have worked non-stop since 1992 and, finally, the government has set up an inquiry. But the Democrats said back then no, they did not think it was an issue. In fact, I had to beg for their support to get Senator McMullan to table documents about Centenary House and Senator Spindler actually changed his mind during the debate. The documents tabled by Senator McMullan proved again that officers of the Australian

SPEECH.PARA: Property Group had potentially misled the Senate on that issue. At some stage during that debate Senator Spindler said that he would not support the tabling of the documents.

PARA.TAB: We have already mentioned the Marshall Islands affair. On 22 November 1993 the Democrats said no to referring the sports rorts affair back to the estimates committee. They said, `No, it is just a political trawling exercise; we will not be a part of that'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all the ones we've said yes to? You're being a bit selective.
—It actually suits my argument to look at the ones where you have stopped.
—That's right.
—Order! Address the chair and do not get baited by interjections.

—It is hard, but I will try to look over there. We are looking at examples where the Democrats have said no, but pressure applied by hardworking backbench senators has ensured that an inquiry has ensued. They have often been independent inquiries from outside the building, conducted more often than not by the Auditor-General. The Democrats have said, `No, it is a political fishing exercise', but subsequent inquiries have found that the government has deep problems, maladministration and, indeed, political corruption. The reference of the dismissal of the Prime Minister's Lodge staff and the Thai teak table are other recent examples. I will go no further on that because I do want to cover some other ground.

PARA.TAB: One of the other important issues is the whole attitude of the government to the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General has been one of the most ostracised people in this town for the last 12 or 18 months. All of a sudden, Mr Keating and Senator Gareth Evans have said, `We want to support the Auditor-General, we want to give him more access, more resources'. This is the government that is running down the resources of the Auditor-General's office as a result of a nine per cent increase every year on this terrible lease deal on Centenary House. According to all the evidence possibly available in Canberra—after a lot of work we now have every bit of evidence—the rent is 20 per cent above the market. Over the next 15 years the Auditor-General will be paying to the Australian Labor Party $15 million more than it should be because of the high rent. That is not the total amount; that is just the over-the-market aspect of the rent deal.

Hopefully, the inquiry will force the government politically to renegotiate the lease. We are talking about the cost of setting up a Senate inquiry, yet the Australian Labor Party will receive over the course of the next 15 years $1 million too much each and every year. I am totally happy for the Auditor-General to lease offices at Centenary House. I do not mind as long as the deal is fair. As long as the Australian taxpayers are paying a fair rent and there are fair rent reviews and it is all open, accountable and transparent, I am quite happy about it. But the deal now is that $1 million a year is coming out of the resources of the Australian National Audit Office and going to the Australian Labor Party. We are not talking about a few hundred thousand dollars for a Senate inquiry; we are talking about $1 million every year coming directly out of the audit office's ability to conduct these sorts of inquiries. Let us face up to that issue.

The other issue in relation to the Auditor-General—all of these great new found friends of the Auditor-General in Mr Keating and Senator Evans—is that on 29 September last year I asked a question of the Auditor-General at a hearing of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and he said that he had found an enormous spate of government departments, in seeking advice of the Attorney-General's Department about the powers of access of the Auditor-General, trying to stop having to provide advice to the Auditor-General.

On page 5532 of the Senate weekly Hansard of 21 December 1993, I asked—and I am happy to table this—what departments sought advice. There were nine separate occasions in the past 18 months where the departments of the Commonwealth had sought advice from the Attorney-General on the powers of access of the Auditor-General. If we go back before that, we find that there are almost no occasions. People respected the Auditor-General's right to get information. But in the past 18 months, the Auditor-General has had to have battles with the Attorney-General's department on rights of access.

Some of the departments that sought access advice include DEET; the Department of Finance; the Australian Government Solicitor; and the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories was the big one that sought advice about the powers of access. But there were some nine separate occasions in the last 18 months where the government has been trying to stop the Auditor-General coming and looking at the books. That is how committed it is to the powers of access of the Auditor-General.

I am being wound up by both my leader and Senator Gareth Evans, so I will quickly conclude. I said I would be 10 minutes and I have run a little over that time. If we want to save money by not setting up this inquiry, we may as well say that we should close down the whole Senate. I remember former Senator Chaney said that the Senate and the parliament are very important and very powerful, but very few people ever use their powers of investigation effectively.

What happens if we do not use these powers, if we do not do our job, if we do not enforce the powers of the parliament to make the executive accountable? Senator Chamarette made this point most eloquently in a very good speech on accountability and the relationship between the parliament and the executive. Well, if that happens, we may as well not have a Senate. We can save the taxpayer a lot of money by not having a Senate at all. If Senator Kernot is worried about spending a quarter of a million dollars on a Senate inquiry, then let us not have it. Let us have no inquiries or committees but just close the place down. Let us all go home and leave it to Paul Keating, the Prime Minister. Let him run the show from the House of Representatives and see what we get.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you give me a cast-iron guarantee you will never vote with them to change the voting system?

—I give Senator Kernot a cast-iron guarantee that I will not be voting to change the voting system to Senator Evans's method or the proportional representation system that we have now. It is very important and it is absolutely vital to the whole process. The deal that Senator Evans has offered is basically about accountability procedures that we have not seen, and we will get them only if we do not have an inquiry. It is a terrible deal and it is most important that the processes of the Senate to make this executive accountable are put in place.

PARA.TAB: Ros Kelly's resignation is not the solution to this problem; it may well be a symptom. It is a deep disease, to use Senator Kernot's words. But Mr Beazley and the Prime Minister are the wrong people to talk to about solving the disease. They have been there for 11 years and they do not have any respect for accountability processes. The Senate can uphold those processes but needs the support of a majority of senators to uphold them.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most curious statements in the debate thus far is the statement by Senator Gareth Evans that they are about good government. That statement was made in the midst of a debate on what has become known as the sports rorts affair. If they were about good government—
—We are now about good government.
—If they were about good government, we would not be where we are now.
—Present tense; Brian.

—Present tense? That is an amazing change. Having regard to the history of this particular affair, Senator Evans's statement takes the cake. I acknowledge that from now on he is about good government; I acknowledge that that is what he has said. We will see.

PARA.TAB: We are here today having had the Auditor-General's report and the examination at the Senate estimates committee. I place on record my appreciation, as a member of this chamber, for those of our colleagues who raised these matters at the estimates hearings, where they should have been raised. After those matters were raised we had the inquiry by the House of Representatives committee and we have now had the resignation of the minister.

It has been suggested that the considerations of the House of Representatives committee were inadequate. I note—indeed, it has been noted by everybody—that certain witnesses were not called by that committee. The decision not to call those witnesses was made by a majority of the members of that committee.

The question posed by Senator Hill was whether that committee faced the real challenge, which was, as Senator Hill put it, to determine whether this was a case of maladministration or whether it was a case of political corruption. It is clear that the House of Representatives committee did not determine that particular issue. It hardly even determined the maladministration issue, to be quite frank. As I said, the net result of the action taken by the parliament was the resignation of the responsible minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Irresponsible.

—The irresponsible minister, says Senator Coulter. The question is whether that resignation satisfies the obligation under the Westminster system of the executive government's being accountable to the people through the parliament. Unless there are very serious proposals to the contrary, we would normally regard that as having satisfied that situation, provided the government of the day takes immediate steps to prevent such occurrences in the future.

PARA.TAB: The question in my mind, and in the minds of everyone around here, is whether any other purpose is served by requiring that responsibility on the part of the government—to be fully accountable to the public through the parliament. That is very close to our responsibilities as a Senate, to our audit and control functions—the classic Bagehot proposals for a house of review. Obviously we all take that very seriously obviously otherwise we would not be debating this matter with such intensity and giving so much consideration to it. I believe we all take seriously our functions of audit and control of executive government decisions and actions. The question now is how to make the government honest—how to back Senator Evans's discovery that this government is about good government.

I know that Senator Evans has agreed to the strengthening of the Auditor-General's role. Besides accepting the 19 or so recommendations of the Auditor-General in respect of this matter and the four or five recommendations of the House of Representatives committee, the government has stated it will redraft the Audit Act—there is now a draft in the hands of the public accounts committee—to strengthen the role and independence of the Auditor-General in line with the joint committee's report No. 296. Very important reforms were suggested in that report. I know consideration has been given to those matters by the opposition. Senator Watson, for example, has a private member's bill dealing with some aspects—

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been on the Notice Paper for about two years and this government won't do anything about it.

—I acknowledge what Senator Campbell says. It probably takes something like this to get the government moving. But what we want is honest and open government. We should put ourselves in the shoes of a number of those managers of sporting organisations who pored for hours over their applications, thinking they would be dealt with on their merits. How do we reckon they feel?
—Let's go and find out.

—We would certainly find out how they feel, but that is not going to do anything into the future. Senator Kernot says this is symptomatic of a disease, presumably a disease of the government—and a lack of accountability—and one of the cures is for the government to vote for her amendment. Frankly, with regard to amendments and motions—I am not talking about amendments to legislation because they have to be carried out—there have been decisions after decisions by this chamber that the government has ignored. Who is to say that the government will not ignore these?

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the government had representatives on this committee that recommended the strengthening of the Auditor-General's role, his independence and the important issue of funding to allow him sufficient funds to operate in an independent way; in other words, to be a help to the parliament and to the public in the role of auditing executive government decisions. There were government members of that committee. In fact, the chairman of the committee at the time is now a government minister. I do not want to quote back to Senator Gareth Evans some of his statements about the Auditor-General. He used to laud him; he supported very strongly the role of the Auditor-General.

Now, at last, Senator Gareth Evans sees the need to do this. If the action that has been taken by the parliament had not been taken, he would not have seen the need to do this because the government, as somebody said, has been shafting the Auditor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said it.
—I said it, did I?
—You did.
—Senator Campbell said it.

—Senator Campbell did not use the word `shafting' but he said, quite correctly, that the Auditor-General has been shunned around this place—his life has been made most difficult and his work has been made almost impossible by the actions of the executive government. That absolutely has to stop. In my view, the recommendations of this committee should be adopted and fully implemented. It is no good the Prime Minister saying that we are standing over him to ensure that that takes place, or that in some way we are just attacking the government. No. I remind the government that some of its own members were on the committee which made this report.

PARA.TAB: I have noted reports of the Auditor-General which are most critical of government actions. I know that, normally speaking, in the Auditor-General's reports there are responses by the various departments, and sometimes there is a response by the minister. In the Auditor-General's report No. 9, there is a response by the department and partly by the minister. My view is that, if the Auditor-General requests a government response to any of his reports, the government should be mandated to table in the parliament such a response. That would be a very important advance because it would require the government, as distinct from the minister, to respond and it would require it to do so within a set period.

The government was not going to respond to the Auditor-General's report on the sports program. If that report had not been taken up by the parliament, the government would not have responded to it. But if we require the government to respond to a particular report at the request of the Auditor-General, the government ought to be required under the act to table that in both houses of parliament. Then we can pick it up; it is out in the open.

It is not only matters to do with the auditor that I have been concerned about for a considerable period of time. I have also been concerned about our audit role and, as mentioned by Senator Chamarette, the failure of the government to table documents—the sort of obfuscation that we get from the government. I have a notice of motion which was given in the parliament in December 1993—and I have discussed this with Senator Gareth Evans. That requires to be laid on the table an indexed list of every file title held by each government department grouped under classifications such as policy, legislation, advising, general matters, administration, or such other classifications as are commonly used across departments.

I believe that, in order for us to ask the right questions, we have to know what is going on in the various departments and, of course, sometimes we do not know. But if we get the file titles, we will at least get an indication of what is going on. That will, in my view, enhance our role as a Senate. I believe that the government is favourably considering that particular matter.

I have said to Senator Evans that these are vital questions and vital issues for open government and for enhancing our role as a Senate. He said that he will make a statement after the votes have been taken but, as I said, the Senate votes and frequently makes decisions in general business time. The government ignores it. Let Senator Evans, the Leader of the Government, get up after the motions have been put and carried or rejected and tell the Senate that he is prepared to do what he said he would do—that is, state the government's position in respect of the Auditor-General and the other relevant matters. Irrespective of whether the amendment is carried or lost or whether the motion is carried or lost, Senator Evans must do that in order for the government to maintain—perhaps `maintain' is not the appropriate word, but I will use it—credibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support Senator Kernot's amendment. I make the point that was made in Senator Kernot's opening remarks that there is no doubt that there was bias in the allocation of the sports grants. There is also no doubt that there was inadequate administration and documentation in relation to those sports grants and, of course, the story of the big whiteboard has now gone into folk history with a great deal of amusement—and, no doubt, on the part of the government, chagrin.

PARA.TAB: A number of other speakers on the opposition side have already stated that those are matters of fact. I think therein lies a considerable problem. Senator Kemp, for instance, said, `We have seen political corruption on a grand scale'. He is not in any doubt whatsoever about what the facts are. The question must therefore be asked: why does he now want to go on to further investigate this matter when he has already made up his mind? It seems to me that he, having spent almost half an hour going over the known facts, has demonstrated exactly what Senator Hill's motion is about: going over those facts in the lead-up to a number of by-elections to keep this issue alive as long as possible while there is the possibility of damaging the government's position.

The alternative put up by the Australian Democrats, as Senator Kernot has said, is to take a prospective look at ministerial behaviour rather than a retrospective look—not to rake over those matters which are already known, are on the record and have been established; rather, to ensure that, in the future, ministerial behaviour is above reproach. One finds further evidence of the opposition's intention—I do not think this has been mentioned in the debate so far on Senator Hill's motion—in item (11) of the motion, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it . . .

Clearly, with the dominance on that committee of the opposition, one can imagine the muck-raking going on and the way in which those opposite would use that evidence on a day-to-day basis to achieve political purposes.

PARA.TAB: Having been chairman of the Select Committee into the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council—a committee which was fraught with exactly the same political divisions as I am sure Senator Hill's proposed committee would be fraught with—I remind Senator Chamarette in particular that she should know how extremely difficult, almost impossible, it would be to take a prospective view.

On one occasion, in responding to a proposal from the government to not publish certain information, Senator Bishop said, `If I were on your side, I would do that too'. In the debate this afternoon, we heard Senator Evans use exactly the same remark—`If I were on your side, I would do that too'. In these circumstances, I can assure—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I should now propose that the Senate do now adjourn. But, with leave, if there is agreement between everybody, we can suspend that. Is leave granted?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was pointing out that the committee inquiring into the Loan Council was created under precisely the same circumstances. It was an extremely difficult committee in which to take a prospective view, for precisely the same reasons that this committee proposed by Senator Hill would find it very difficult to take a prospective view. I believe it is naive of the Greens to think that politicisation of this committee will be avoided in this case. It is idealistic but is certainly not realistic. In June 1992 I put this motion before the Senate:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate recommends to the Working Group to Develop a Code of Conduct for Senators and Members, that it gives priority to developing a Code of Conduct for Ministers, and that the terms of such a Code of Conduct be transmitted to both Houses of Federal Parliament on or before the first day of sitting in 1993;

That the Senate calls on the Liberal Party, as a matter of urgency, to appoint a Senator to the Working Group to Develop a Code of Conduct for Senators and Members, as it was requested to do in 1991, thus allowing the Working Group to meet for the first time.

SPEECH.PARA: I could quote at some length the debate which occurred on that occasion, but I simply point out that that committee, which was first mooted in 1989, was frustrated by the failure of the Liberal Party to appoint people to it. It was further frustrated by the reticence of the Liberal Party to participate properly in it. That committee could well have developed precisely the sort of code of conduct that we are looking for here. So it is rather rich for the Liberal Party now to say that it wants to set up a committee to inquire into something. We simply reiterate the point that we want to take a prospective look, and want to ensure as far as possible that this does not occur in the future, rather to than retrospectively—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you said after Marshall Islands.

—Which Senator Kemp and his side frustrated. I think the proposal which Senator Kernot has put is an extremely good one because it looks at this matter prospectively. It will set up a parliamentary review process as well as strengthen the position of the Auditor-General. That is the way we should go. I certainly urge Senator Chamarette to support the amendment moved by Senator Kernot.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Kernot's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Senator Chamarette's amendment be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement setting out the government's intentions in relation to the matters we have just debated.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, taking into account the matters raised during this debate, and in particular the terms of the Australian Democrats amendment which we did support and the matters raised by Senator Harradine, may I say that it is the government's intention to act as follows in relation to the accountability issues that have been central to this debate.

PARA.TAB: We will act to accept the recommendations of the Auditor-General in Audit Report No 9 and the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the community, cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program, and report to parliament on their implementation and applicability to similar programs by 13 May, 1994.

In relation to the Auditor-General, we will table in both houses of parliament a response, within three months, to any recommendations contained in Auditor-General's reports which require a government response. We will act to re-draft the foreshadowed legislation to update the Audit Act, to strengthen the definition of the powers and the mandate of the Auditor-General along the lines proposed in Report 296 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. We will act to introduce, if possible, within one month, such re-drafted legislation and ensure that it is debated in both houses early in the spring session of 1994.

We will specifically consider during that re-drafting process a number of matters. First, the establishment of an independent audit committee of parliament to provide advice to the Auditor-General on the parliamentary priorities on audits and recommendations to government on the appropriation of the Australian National Audit Office; secondly, provision for the appropriation for the Audit Office to be an appropriation of parliament with the practice of cost recovery of financial statement audits from departments ceasing and the ANAO getting a comprehensive, single line budget; thirdly, the audit office being mandated as the sole auditor of all government departments, statutory authorities and GBEs without exception; and, fourthly, the Auditor-General becoming a statutory officer of the parliament and a separate statutory authority.

Lest there be any misunderstanding, might I repeat that these are matters in respect to which we undertake to consider during the re-drafting process, and there is no magic or mystery about that. That is the basis of the agreement which was recorded in Mr Beazley's statement to the Australian Democrats. We would expect to go down most, if not all, of those paths, nonetheless, in that consideration process.

Further, in relation to the Auditor-General, I undertake on behalf of the government that we will review the forward estimates and funding for the audit office for 1994-95 following the outcome of the inquiry into the conduct of officers and departments concerned with Centenary House. We will act to request the Presiding Officers to immediately reconvene the parliamentary working group established to develop a code of conduct for ministers, members and senators and to request that committee to produce a report no later than the commencement of the spring session on 23 August, addressing the question of a ministerial code of conduct including the proper extent of ministerial discretion in disbursing funds under discretionary programs.

We did not pass the amendment so we have not got our guillotine. We will still move to bring on for debate the question of the establishment of a Senate register of pecuniary interests on 14 March, or as soon as possible thereafter. Finally, we will support, subject to further discussion on detailed drafting, motion No. 544, notice of which was given by Senator Harradine on 16 December 1993. That motion would require publication by way of tabling in parliament of departmental file titles relating to policy matters, legislation and the like. I make this statement with these specific commitments in order to put beyond any doubt the government's willingness to act in all the ways that I have stated to improve the equality of administration and accountability in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being well past the appointed time, I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two nights ago during the adjournment debate I raised some matters regarding the former Premier of Western Australia—
—What happened to standards for senators?

—What about people interjecting from their own seats? I raised matters relating to the convenient memory loss of the former Premier of Western Australia, Dr Carmen Lawrence, when it came to $5,000 of taxpayers' money that sat in her private bank account for nearly two years. It was not until there was a police investigation that she was able to remember that the money was there and pay it back. It is very hard for most people in Western Australia to understand how anyone could possibly have $5,000 in a private bank account and not know it is there. That debate has been gone over many times in the minds of Western Australians. It goes to the credibility of Dr Carmen Lawrence who is now running for election to the federal parliament.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, that debate leads us to the very nasty circumstances surrounding John Halden MLC, who is now the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in the Western Australian Legislative Council. John Halden is now infamous for the action he took in bringing to the Legislative Council in late 1992 a petition of last resort from Brian Easton. Brian Easton is a former head of the Exim Corporation, one of the disgraced WA Inc. companies established by Brian Burke. At one stage he was also a Public Service commissioner under the Burke government. One of the extremely sad elements of this sordid tale which has now moved into the political arena because of the actions of John Halden is that it all came from a—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Campbell has just mentioned a matter that has moved into the political arena. A privileges committee inquiry of the Western Australian Legislative Council—headed, incidentally, by the now minister for health, Mr Peter Foss—was conducted, which cleared Mr Halden of any breach of privilege. I ask you to rule that what Senator Campbell is doing is reflecting—
—What is the point of order?
—Order! Senator Campbell!
—What Senator Campbell is doing is reflecting upon a member of another house and he is doing it incorrectly and distorting the story.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order under standing order 193(3), which says that a senator shall not impute improper motives to members of a state parliament. Unquestionably, Senator Campbell is doing that. The things that he said about Mr Halden are such that, had they been said about any member of the opposition, they would have led to howls of concern and demands for them to be withdrawn. If it is unparliamentary to call somebody an ignoramus—which I was required to withdraw with regard to an opposition senator—then those things which have been said about Mr Halden cannot possibly be parliamentary.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you know my views about unparliamentary language. I think we take much too narrow a view, but we have to take a consistent view. It seems to me inconceivable that Senator Campbell can speak in this way about Mr Halden and be in order. In view of what Senator McKiernan has raised, it is probably a reflection on the decisions of the privileges committee of the parliament of Western Australia to proceed in this way and to imply things of the nature that Senator Campbell has implied—when the privileges committee decided otherwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of order as it applies to standing order 193(3) is upheld, so I would ask you, Senator Campbell, to refrain from references of the sort you made earlier to a member of parliament of another state.
—I accept your ruling, Mr President, but I do not seek to impute motives at all—
—Mr President, I take a point of order, which is that I believe Senator Campbell should now be asked to withdraw his remarks about Mr Halden. I ask you, Mr President, to rule accordingly.
—I think that is consistent; and I would ask you, Senator Campbell, to withdraw those references.

—I am happy to withdraw any remarks that impute a motive to Mr Halden under the terms of that standing order, but I am sure, Mr President, you will have a lot of trouble finding where they are. The sad fact about this case is that it all came from an extremely nasty experience in the Family Court of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I said earlier today that, had Senator McKiernan been aware—it is a hypothetical situation because Senator McKiernan has nothing to do with it at all—of all the circumstances surrounding the tabling of a petition by Mr Halden, because of his experience on the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, he would have had nothing to do with it and would have advised Mr Halden not to table it. I made that quite clear earlier today. I raised a point in the adjournment debate the other night which was challenged by Senator Schacht. The only reason I am speaking tonight is that Senator Schacht impugned—
Senator McMullan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not, and Senator McMullan can say that all he likes—
—I can, and the whole of Australia will agree—17 million to one.

—Okay. He is so wise. If Senator Schacht had not spoken on the adjournment two nights ago I would not be speaking tonight. He said that what I raised was the most disgusting thing he had heard in 25 years. He imputed a whole load of motives to me on that night—and I did not hear any ruling under standing order 193 then. The point at issue is whether or not the then Premier, Carmen Lawrence, was aware of the contents of the petition, which went to the facts in question in a protracted case before the Family Court and the facts surrounding that petition before it was tabled. In the first instance, when the Premier was asked by the media and in questions in the Legislative Assembly about it, she said she was aware that the petition was being tabled but was not aware of the facts surrounding the petition.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, in a number of statements to both the media and the Legislative Assembly, Dr Lawrence slowly but surely admitted that she had general knowledge of the facts but had been assured by Mr Halden that he had consulted the clerk of the Legislative Council and that, in so doing, the petition was all hunky-dory. We must remember that at this time the premier was under investigation by the police in relation to $5,000 in her private bank account. We must remember that it was very much in the Labor Party's interests to try to neutralise the very damaging political effect of that investigation. The investigation subsequently found that former Premier Lawrence had $5,000 in her private bank account that she had forgotten about and there was enormous motivation for the Australian Labor Party in Western Australia to find an issue to neutralise the effect of that. It was at that time that Mr Halden, now the leader, tabled that petition.
