TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 1 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did three Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) officers attend the premises of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd on 15 September 1993; if so, who authorised the visit, on what authority, and what was the purpose of their visit.
(2) Was any notice given to the company that the visit was to occur; if not, why not, and is this normal practice.
(3) Is there a written report of the visit by the CAA officers to Devonport Aviation; if so, please provide a copy.

(4) Did the three CAA officers interfere with documents in the office of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd, contrary to specific requests by the company officials, and on what authority was this action taken.
(5) Was the company subjected to investigation for any breach of the law; if so, please give details.
(6) Have any charges subsequently been laid.
(7) Did the CAA officers have any authority to search the premises of the company; if so, what was the authority and who issued it.
(8) If it was a statutory authority, please indicate how relevant sections apply to the circumstances of the incident on 15 September 1993.
(9) Has the authority received any complaints about the conduct of the CAA officers during their visits; if so, what is the nature of the complaints, and what is the CAA's response to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Three Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) officers did attend the premises of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd on 15 September 1993. The visit was authorised by the then Acting District Flight Operations Manager of the Moorabbin District Office of the Directorate of Aviation Safety Regulation (DASR) of the CAA.

The reason for the visit was to ascertain whether or not Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd was conducting Commercial Operations while the company's Chief Pilot was subject to flight crew licence suspension by the CAA. Information had been received by officers of the DASR Moorabbin District Office that Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd was conducting Commercial Operations while its Chief Pilot's Commercial Pilot Licence was suspended.

A letter from the CAA to the Chief Pilot of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd, dated 26 August 1993, stated that the Chief Pilot's Commercial and Private Pilot's Licences were suspended for the purpose of an investigation. The Chief Pilot had been informed by the then Acting District Flight Operations Manager by telephone on 26 August 1993, that a letter suspending his Commercial and Private Pilot's Licences would be dispatched by certified mail that day.

The Chief Pilot's Commercial Pilot Licence suspension meant that he was unable to fulfil the duties of the Chief Pilot of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd for the period of that suspension, and Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd was therefore unable to conduct Commercial Operations without the appointment of an Acting Chief Pilot approved by the CAA. As Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd had not applied to the CAA for the approval of an Acting Chief Pilot and CAA officers had received advice that Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd was continuing operations, the decision to visit the company was taken.
(2) Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd was not informed prior to the visit on 15 September 1993 by authorised officers of the CAA.

The visit by authorised officers of the CAA was to ascertain whether or not the company (Devonport Aviation) was acting in breach of the Civil Aviation Act, Regulations or Orders, and the fact that no prior notification of the visit had been given to the company was normal practice in the circumstances.

(3) Yes. The then Acting District Flight Operations Manager and the Investigation Officer sent reports of the visit to Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd to the DASR Regional Administration Manager, South-East Region, on 16 September 1993.

The complaints made by Devonport Aviation are currently under investigation, and the release of these documents to any party at this stage may prejudice the outcome of that enquiry. Consequently, it is not the intention of the Authority to release the reports at this stage. However, once the investigation has been completed, further consideration can be given to the release of these reports.

(4) The authorised officers, who attended the premises of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd on 15 September 1993, state that an employee of Devonport Aviation gave approval for the examination, by the CAA officer, of certain documents belonging to Devonport Aviation.

The authorised officers state they did not examine or interfere with documents in the office of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd contrary to any specific request by employees or officers of Devonport Aviation.

(5) During the visit to Devonport Aviation on 15 September 1993, certain documents belonging to the company were examined. Various pieces of information obtained by CAA officers around that time were also considered. As a result it was determined not to undertake a formal investigation in order to establish whether there had been any breach of the Civil Aviation Act, Civil Aviation Regulations or Civil Aviation Orders by the company. Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd has not been subjected to any investigation for any breach of the law, arising from the visit on 15 September 1993 by authorised officers of the CAA to the premises of Devonport Aviation.

(6) As stated in (5), there has been no formal investigation and no charges laid against Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd arising from the visit on 15 September 1993, by authorised officers of the CAA, to the premises of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd.

(7) The CAA's authorised officers, who attended the premises of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd on 15 September 1993, state that they did not conduct a search of the premises of Devonport Aviation, they did not request approval from the occupier of the premises to search the premises, and they did not request approval from a magistrate to search the premises.

(8) To reiterate (7), the CAA's authorised officers, who attended the premises of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd on 15 September 1993, state that they did not conduct a search of the premises of Devonport Aviation, nor did they request approval to conduct a search of the premises from any person or statutory authority.
The following Civil Aviation Regulations are relevant to the circumstances of the visit on 15 September 1993:

Civil Aviation Regulation (CAR) 305(1) (in summary) provides that an authorised person will have access to any place to which access is necessary for the purpose of carrying out any powers and functions vested in him under the Regulations. CAR 305(1A) makes it an offence to prevent or hinder such access, and CAR 305(2) requires the authorised person to produce his identity card.

(9) On 17 September 1993, a solicitor acting for the Chief Pilot of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd, wrote to the Acting Chief Executive of the CAA alleging that, on 15 September 1993, officers of the Authority entered the premises of Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd against the wishes of the staff and in the absence of the company's Manager, Director or Public Officer. The letter went on to allege that the CAA officers ransacked the office, threatened employees, photographed confidential material, and sought to remove documents from the premises without permission.
The CAA officers involved deny the allegations.

In a letter to the solicitor from the then Acting Director of the Directorate of Aviation Safety Regulation, dated 18 November 1993, the solicitor was asked to provide details supporting his allegations against the CAA officers involved in the visit to Devonport Aviation Pty Ltd, or retract the allegations unequivocally in formal apology.

A letter from the solicitor to the CAA's Chief Executive, dated 22 November 1993, purports to support the allegations of 17 September 1993. The matters contained therein are currently being considered by the CAA.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 1 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the speech given by Senator Ian Macdonald on 24 November 1993, can reports be confirmed that: (a) a Commuter airline based in Wagga was reportedly observed by airworthiness inspectors as having cut down on maintenance and safety; (b) this was subsequently reported, and an air maintenance inspector tried to have the air operator's certificate cancelled; and (c) the administration of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) did nothing about it, but as a result the senior Air Maintenance Inspector was transferred in a dispute with the administration over this matter.

(2) Can it be confirmed that an Air Maintenance Inspector wrote to the Regional Manager of the CAA in Sydney recommending that Western Airlines lost its air operator's certificate because of significant deficiencies which had existed for some time.
(3) Was this recommendation in writing; if so, please provide a copy.
(4) What were the deficiencies complained of.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) & (b) The CAA's Directorate of Aviation Safety Regulation (DASR) airworthiness staff at the Wagga District Office had identified some maintenance and flight operations deficiencies within Western Airlines. A review of the airline's operating practices, standards and procedures was in train when the company voluntarily ceased its airline operations. All matters identified as deficiencies had been brought to the airline's attention by the Wagga District Office for corrective action.

(c) Following an industry complaint, the CAA conducted two internal investigations, one by the South East Regional Flying Operations Manager, and another independent one by the North East Region's Administration Manager. The North East Region Administration Manager concluded from his review that the relationship between the Regional Flying Operations Manager and the District Flying Operations Manager at Wagga had reached the stage where it was affecting the efficient operation of the Region. Agreement was subsequently reached with the Wagga District Flying Operations Manager that he transfer to the Directorate of Aviation Safety Regulation's central office in Canberra.

(2) & (3) Although there were deficiencies identified by airworthiness staff during the final months of the airline's operations, no written recommendation was received by the Regional Airworthiness Manager to cancel the airline's Air Operators Certificate.

Both Regional Airworthiness and Operational Managers met with the management of Western Airlines to discuss the identified deficiencies and the airline's operations in general. The airline voluntarily notified DASR regional management that it was ceasing operations as a maintenance organisation and as a low capacity Regular Public Transport operator. The airline has since ceased all operations.

(4) The deficiencies recorded by DASR airworthiness staff were that defects were not being recorded and pressure was being placed on the airline's maintenance staff by company management. There were also some concerns that some flights had occurred which were not recorded by Western Airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 1 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Government's decision to deregulate some mail delivery services, will this decision mean higher postal costs for users of Australia Post services in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable

PARA.TAB: The Government's postal industry reform package will still require Australia Post to make the letter service available at a single uniform rate of postage for the carriage within Australia, by ordinary post, of letters that are standard articles.

The Australia Post Board has the power under section 32 of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 to determine the terms and conditions for services, including rates of postage. However, Australia Post is subject to price controls. Rates of postage for carriage within Australia of standard articles (45 cent letters) will remain subject to a power of ministerial disallowance. The Government confirmed that the Prices Surveillance Authority will continue to scrutinise Australia Post's prices on reserved services.
Australia Post has advised that it does not expect the Government's reform decisions to have any impact on postal prices in Tasmania.
